description: Whether using for personal email or work email as large business organization, this course covers everything one needs to become a skilled and informed user of Microsoft Outlook 2016. Our hosts start with explaining the basic terminology and setup of email accounts and continue on to all areas of Outlook including managing email, contacts, calendars, and tasks. This course is specifically for Windows operating system with Outlook 2016 locally installed.

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne briefly discuss Outlook’s job, history and presence in our connected society.  Vonne describes that outlook as product appears in multiple formats:  as a standalone product, as consumer based web-based portal and even as a custom access web portal for a company’s email.  She talks little of the where outlook began and where it is today as well as describing the configuration that will be used for the show.

00:17:58.210 --> 00:18:00.110
said something about Outlook Express,
but she didn't cover it.

343
00:18:00.110 --> 00:18:01.720
So, now I've covered it.

344
00:18:01.720 --> 00:18:03.000
>> Well, Vonne, thank you again for

345
00:18:03.000 --> 00:18:06.010
even that last little tidbit of
information on Outlook Express.

346
00:18:06.010 --> 00:18:09.590
A trip down memory lane no doubt in that.

347
00:18:09.590 --> 00:18:12.620
But remember that what we're
actually gonna be doing here in

348
00:18:12.620 --> 00:18:15.660
Outlook is to make sure that you get
everything that you actually need if

349
00:18:15.660 --> 00:18:17.570
you're wanting to learn
more about Outlook.

350
00:18:17.570 --> 00:18:20.180
So make sure you watch all
the episodes that are right here with

351
00:18:20.180 --> 00:18:21.890
Vonne Smith, as well.

352
00:18:21.890 --> 00:18:23.850
That's a great place for us to sign off.

353
00:18:23.850 --> 00:18:26.860
For Office ProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

354
00:18:26.860 --> 00:18:27.840
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

355
00:18:27.840 --> 00:18:31.423
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Office 2016 shows.

356
00:18:31.423 --> 00:18:36.496
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne discuss some of the different protocols used when transmitting and receiving emails.  Vonne discusses the basic difference between a client and server.  Also, she provides a brief description of emailing protocols like POP3, IMAP, MAPI and SMTP too.
episodes.title: Email Terminology
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.861
[MUSIC]

2

Welcome to another great episode

3
00:00:09.154 --> 00:00:13.342
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong and

And we're gonna be learning a little
bit more about some of the different

terminology that we have to understand

00:00:20.492 --> 00:00:21.479

Vonne, welcome back to the show.

8

So yes, terminology,
I'm kinda big on this because I've been

And they go, actually, I don't remember.

15
00:00:45.225 --> 00:00:45.989
[LAUGH] And

I just thought it was always fun to try
to learn as many acronyms as I could.

To just be able to talk
the talk with you all and

00:00:54.648 --> 00:00:58.858
know what you guys are talking about

>> It's amazing what you

magnetic letters on the refregerator.

21

>> [LAUGH]
>> To actually be able to do this, so.

22
00:01:04.228 --> 00:01:05.122
>> Yeah.

23
00:01:05.122 --> 00:01:09.042
Okay, Vonne, what are we actually looking
at when we start talking about this idea

24
00:01:09.042 --> 00:01:10.400
of the terminology?

25
00:01:10.400 --> 00:01:12.320
What type of terminology
are we talking about here?

26
00:01:12.320 --> 00:01:13.820
>> Well,
we're gonna start from the very beginning.

27
00:01:13.820 --> 00:01:17.162
So I have a PowerPoint presentation and
we are not doing PowerPoint,

28
00:01:17.162 --> 00:01:18.324
we're doing Outlook.

29
00:01:18.324 --> 00:01:20.590
[LAUGH] I tried to say
that a couple of times.

30
00:01:20.590 --> 00:01:24.550
So let's just jump right
in about Email Terminology.

31
00:01:24.550 --> 00:01:26.050
So let's start at the very,

32
00:01:26.050 --> 00:01:31.020
very beginning about server and clients,
cuz you hear these terms all the time.

33
00:01:31.020 --> 00:01:32.656
And so what is a server?

34
00:01:32.656 --> 00:01:36.363
A server is just really a special
computer, if you wanna say,

35
00:01:36.363 --> 00:01:38.440
that serves other computers.

36
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:42.070
And you, I would say,
if you're sitting in an office and

37
00:01:42.070 --> 00:01:47.000
you are in a networked environment to
where you have maybe a file server.

38
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:49.940
There's email servers,
there's mail servers.

39
00:01:49.940 --> 00:01:52.720
Well, I guess email and
mail servers [LAUGH] are the same thing.

40
00:01:52.720 --> 00:01:56.985
You have different types of servers
that do different functionalities.

41
00:01:56.985 --> 00:02:02.460
And so, if you're sitting at your desk,
you're at the client, you're at your own

42

machine, that is connected to that server,

43

That your computer can talk to the server

44

And so, and I also think of servers,

45
00:02:15.440 --> 00:02:19.730
it's almost like servers in a restaurant,
right?

46
00:02:19.730 --> 00:02:22.850
You have some people that
are just food runners, and

47
00:02:22.850 --> 00:02:24.560
then you have some people
that take your orders.

48
00:02:26.100 --> 00:02:28.729
What were those,
the wine people called, with the fancy-

49
00:02:28.729 --> 00:02:30.376
>> No, now you're talking way above me.

50
00:02:30.376 --> 00:02:32.922
[LAUGH]
>> Talking about terminology,

51
00:02:32.922 --> 00:02:34.366
I can't remember what that name is.

52
00:02:34.366 --> 00:02:38.345
The guy that's the wine guy and
they come around.

53
00:02:38.345 --> 00:02:39.142
>> The guy in the beer truck.

54
00:02:39.142 --> 00:02:41.078
[LAUGH]
>> I don't know.

55

>> [LAUGH] The guy in
the beer truck works too, so.

56
00:02:43.233 --> 00:02:48.235
But they all have different reasons

57
00:02:48.235 --> 00:02:49.986
And clients are people in the restaurant.

58
00:02:49.986 --> 00:02:54.575
So that's always what I kinda think of and
that your server coordinates between

59
00:02:54.575 --> 00:02:58.765
the cooks in the back that get your
food to you, and then brings it to you.

60
00:02:58.765 --> 00:03:00.605
You don't talk directly to the cooks.

61
00:03:00.605 --> 00:03:03.515
You talk to the server, and
then the server talks to other people.

62
00:03:03.515 --> 00:03:08.163
And so that's what I kind of equate

63
00:03:08.163 --> 00:03:08.985
>> And now, Vonne,

64

if I can kind of add in just a little
bit to try and I hope to help out here.

65
00:03:13.975 --> 00:03:16.660
Most of the time when you hear this right?

66
00:03:16.660 --> 00:03:19.840
It sounds confusing because the people
that talk about it understand what's going

67
00:03:19.840 --> 00:03:23.350
on, and you may be looking at it like,
I don't have a clue.

68
00:03:23.350 --> 00:03:25.910
I really don't have a clue
what's going on here.

69
00:03:25.910 --> 00:03:29.664
But let's try to distinguish this

70
00:03:29.664 --> 00:03:32.913
A server is a computer that you and
I, as humans,

71

we don't have to interact with
it to make it do its job.

72
00:03:37.180 --> 00:03:41.360
When we talk about a server, it's going

73

The client,

74
00:03:41.960 --> 00:03:46.550
though, is when you sit down at a computer
and you have to interact with it.

75
00:03:46.550 --> 00:03:49.630
So, whether we're talking about
the software that's on it, or

76
00:03:49.630 --> 00:03:52.150
whether we're talking about
the physical machine,

77
00:03:52.150 --> 00:03:55.287
when I set up an actual server itself,
I'm installing software.

78
00:03:55.287 --> 00:04:00.272
And once I install it and I configure
it the way that it needs to work,

79
00:04:00.272 --> 00:04:04.880
I can just wash my hands of it and
say, you do your job.

80
00:04:04.880 --> 00:04:07.620
I don't ever have to touch it
again unless something goes wrong.

81
00:04:07.620 --> 00:04:09.990
>> Yeah. [LAUGH] >> But overall,
though, I really don't.

82

But in what we're gonna
be taking a look at,

especially with Outlook,
Outlook is considered a client itself.

84
00:04:16.600 --> 00:04:19.750
Which means that somebody

85
00:04:19.750 --> 00:04:22.410
It's not just going to go and get email.

86
00:04:22.410 --> 00:04:25.560
It's not just gonna go and
do the things that it needs to do.

87
00:04:25.560 --> 00:04:30.750
Somebody has to say, yes,
get that, do this, run this.

88
00:04:30.750 --> 00:04:33.150
Make sure that this actually happens here.

89
00:04:33.150 --> 00:04:36.394
So that's what you're normally doing
when you're sitting at your computer and

90
00:04:36.394 --> 00:04:37.926
you're getting emails that come in.

91
00:04:37.926 --> 00:04:42.227
Or when you're sending, the software
on your computer is not gonna go,

92
00:04:42.227 --> 00:04:46.180
I think I'm just gonna
send Vonne Smith an email.

93
00:04:46.180 --> 00:04:49.670
It's me that says,
I need to send Vonne an email.

94
00:04:49.670 --> 00:04:53.510
And I go and I interact with
that software on that machine.

95
00:04:53.510 --> 00:04:56.730
And then that says, all right,
I'm gonna send this email.

96
00:04:56.730 --> 00:04:58.165
But when you do,
it's gonna send it to the server.

97
00:04:58.165 --> 00:04:59.585
The server's gonna say,

98
00:04:59.585 --> 00:05:03.780
I'll take care of giving it to Vonne,
you stay out of this process, Ronnie.

99
00:05:03.780 --> 00:05:05.520
I know the job that I'm doing.

100
00:05:05.520 --> 00:05:08.554
So that's kind of the easiest and
basic way.

101
00:05:08.554 --> 00:05:11.409
And that's why your server
analogy at the restaurant works.

102
00:05:11.409 --> 00:05:14.095
We're not really paying for the waiter.

103
00:05:14.095 --> 00:05:15.287
I know it seems strange, right?

104
00:05:15.287 --> 00:05:17.397
We're really paying to get the food.

105
00:05:17.397 --> 00:05:20.260
We're really paying for
the end result that what we want.

106
00:05:20.260 --> 00:05:24.300
The servers really help us to do that,
to get the end result.

107
00:05:24.300 --> 00:05:26.908
And even though we might interact
with a waiter a lot of times,

108
00:05:26.908 --> 00:05:30.118
if the waiter wasn't there, we'd
probably still go to that restaurant and

109
00:05:30.118 --> 00:05:31.338
eat when it comes down to it.

110
00:05:31.338 --> 00:05:32.200
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

111
00:05:32.200 --> 00:05:34.080
that's what server really helps us do.

112
00:05:34.080 --> 00:05:36.425
I hope that kind of clarifies
it a little bit more.

113
00:05:36.425 --> 00:05:37.170
>> Yeah,

114
00:05:37.170 --> 00:05:41.550
that's a great description of it because
I think it's something that's basic.

115
00:05:41.550 --> 00:05:45.540
And it's so basic, but yet
if you don't understand,

116
00:05:45.540 --> 00:05:49.370
then your IT people are throwing all these
terms and you're just like, wait, what?

117
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:52.335
Yeah, just like you're talking about, so

118
00:05:52.335 --> 00:05:55.056
I really like that you're saying you
as a client, you have to do something.

119
00:05:55.056 --> 00:05:59.566
But the server,
it does normally work until it goes down.

120
00:05:59.566 --> 00:06:02.361
You hear, the servers are down and
that's when the IT people come in and

121
00:06:02.361 --> 00:06:03.288
they go ahead and fix it.

122
00:06:03.288 --> 00:06:07.120
And they do break, but for
the most part, they're set to run.

123
00:06:07.120 --> 00:06:08.410
>> Yeah, and that's the key, right?

124
00:06:08.410 --> 00:06:12.660
Is that we really don't have to have a lot
of interaction to make it do its job.

125
00:06:12.660 --> 00:06:14.310
It says, turn me on watch,

126
00:06:14.310 --> 00:06:19.140
what I'll do and you just configure
me to operate the way that needs to.

127
00:06:19.140 --> 00:06:20.656
If a glitch happens, come in and fix me.

128
00:06:20.656 --> 00:06:22.897
But besides that, let me do the job.

129
00:06:22.897 --> 00:06:25.125
And so nobody's actually there.

130
00:06:25.125 --> 00:06:29.144
There's not a guy sitting there at that
server saying ,this goes to Vonne Smith,

131
00:06:29.144 --> 00:06:30.726
this email goes to Ronnie Wong.

132
00:06:30.726 --> 00:06:35.142
Cuz we pay that guy a ton of money as much
emails are being moved around to do all

133
00:06:35.142 --> 00:06:36.965
that stuff, there's no way.

134
00:06:36.965 --> 00:06:37.700
>> [LAUGH]
>> That server,

135
00:06:37.700 --> 00:06:41.130
we turn it on and
it looks at it at lightning fast speeds,

136
00:06:41.130 --> 00:06:44.860
handles it within microseconds
if not milliseconds.

137
00:06:44.860 --> 00:06:47.060
And it's doing a great job doing it.

138
00:06:47.060 --> 00:06:50.790
That's why we appreciate the setup
the way that we have it now.

139
00:06:50.790 --> 00:06:53.424
Because it really does help to
make things much more efficient.

140
00:06:53.424 --> 00:06:57.062
>> Yes, and we appreciate all those IT
guys for setting it up, like Ronnie.

141
00:06:57.062 --> 00:06:59.663
>> [LAUGH]
>> I break it more often than I set it up.

142
00:06:59.663 --> 00:07:01.615
>> [LAUGH]
>> Come on,

143
00:07:01.615 --> 00:07:03.299
give yourself more credit than that, so.

144
00:07:03.299 --> 00:07:04.506
>> I do.

145
00:07:04.506 --> 00:07:07.687
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

146
00:07:07.687 --> 00:07:08.358
>> All right,

147
00:07:08.358 --> 00:07:12.657
so talking about more terminology,
now we've set up that we're client and

148
00:07:12.657 --> 00:07:13.933
Outlook is a client and

149
00:07:13.933 --> 00:07:18.740
that it goes to some type of server that
handles all of our mail and everything.

150
00:07:18.740 --> 00:07:21.920
So then there's some other terminology
that we're going to encounter.

151
00:07:21.920 --> 00:07:25.585
We're talking about email in general,
and this is not just for Outlook.

152
00:07:25.585 --> 00:07:27.732
This for just any email.

153
00:07:27.732 --> 00:07:32.096
So you have POP, IMAP,
Exchange, and SMTP, all right?

154
00:07:32.096 --> 00:07:32.763
So what do these all mean?

155
00:07:32.763 --> 00:07:38.697
So you could see that POP,
that stands for Post Office Protocol.

156
00:07:38.697 --> 00:07:41.203
And 3 is just because there was
multiple versions of it and

157
00:07:41.203 --> 00:07:44.644
3 is the last version that kinda stuck and
they haven't really gone past that.

158
00:07:44.644 --> 00:07:49.534
I think there is something that POP4,
but it never really came into fruition.

159
00:07:49.534 --> 00:07:53.275
So POP3 it's like, it's working, it works
great, so why don't we just keep that?

160
00:07:53.275 --> 00:07:56.982
Well, then there's also IMAP,
an Internet Message Access Protocol And

161
00:07:56.982 --> 00:08:01.229
then there's Exchange, Microsoft Exchange
Server, which we've kind of already

162
00:08:01.229 --> 00:08:05.750
mentioned in some of our other episodes,
since we are using a Microsoft product.

163
00:08:05.750 --> 00:08:09.430
And then there's SMTP,
Simple Mail Transfer Protocol.

164
00:08:09.430 --> 00:08:14.865
All right, so what is a protocol?

165
00:08:14.865 --> 00:08:16.795
And I'm actually,
I'm using my notes over here.

166
00:08:16.795 --> 00:08:18.215
And these are all in the show notes,

167
00:08:18.215 --> 00:08:23.173
that gives you address, or links to
the addresses you can find on Wikipedia.

168
00:08:23.173 --> 00:08:26.302
So a protocol is a system of rules and
telecommunications that allow two or

169
00:08:26.302 --> 00:08:29.852
more entities of communication
systems to transmit information via

170
00:08:29.852 --> 00:08:32.597
any kind of variation
of a physical quantity.

171
00:08:32.597 --> 00:08:33.777
>> [LAUGH]
>> Ooh, that's a mouthful.

172
00:08:33.777 --> 00:08:37.202
[LAUGH] It's really just how
two things talk to each other,

173
00:08:37.202 --> 00:08:38.522
that's really all it is, okay?

174
00:08:38.522 --> 00:08:41.092
And there's lots fo different
protocols that you can see right here,

175
00:08:41.092 --> 00:08:46.510
there's a POP, or post office protocol
Internet Message Access Protocol.

176
00:08:46.510 --> 00:08:49.810
It's just different ways that we
talk to people or talk to things.

177
00:08:49.810 --> 00:08:51.020
It's almost like languages.

178
00:08:51.020 --> 00:08:54.730
If we're talking in English versus
Spanish, we're still communicating.

179
00:08:54.730 --> 00:08:58.605
It just depends on which version if you
wanna say, or what language we've both

180
00:08:58.605 --> 00:09:01.849
decided on, that that's how we're
going to talk to each other.

181
00:09:01.849 --> 00:09:03.121
That's really what a protocol is.

182
00:09:03.121 --> 00:09:07.300
>> And that's a great, very simplified
description of what a protocol is.

183
00:09:07.300 --> 00:09:10.960
It is agreeing, those two machines that
may speak a different language, but

184
00:09:10.960 --> 00:09:13.110
they agree on a protocol
that they're gonna use.

185
00:09:13.110 --> 00:09:17.190
This diagram, or the slide that
Vonne actually puts up here,

186
00:09:17.190 --> 00:09:21.855
really does help us out, because it
shows us some that computers can't do.

187
00:09:21.855 --> 00:09:24.250
Vonne and I,
even if we were total strangers,

188
00:09:24.250 --> 00:09:28.550
we could set up an entire communication
process just by walking the room and

189
00:09:28.550 --> 00:09:30.250
introducing ourselves to each other.

190
00:09:30.250 --> 00:09:32.940
But from that point we're
already communicating, and

191
00:09:32.940 --> 00:09:37.150
that's because we're both listening as
well as being able to send messages to

192
00:09:37.150 --> 00:09:42.690
each other because we can talk and we
can actually hear almost simultaneously.

193
00:09:42.690 --> 00:09:46.945
Computers need to be told how to do that,
and the problem is it's not like us where

194
00:09:46.945 --> 00:09:50.024
we're learning and
we can understand that after a while.

195
00:09:50.024 --> 00:09:54.850
For example that SMTP down there Vonne,
that is used for sending messages.

196
00:09:54.850 --> 00:09:56.780
If I want to send a message, or-
>> Like this.

197
00:09:56.780 --> 00:09:58.020
>> Yeah, there you go, yeah.

198
00:09:58.020 --> 00:10:01.120
If I want to do that,
then I have to use that protocol.

199
00:10:01.120 --> 00:10:04.180
But receiving messages,
they have to be different,

200
00:10:04.180 --> 00:10:08.530
so that's what we're doing here, is we're
actually showing that particular process.

201
00:10:08.530 --> 00:10:11.030
Is that hey, here's how it has to work,

202
00:10:11.030 --> 00:10:14.412
and if you have different systems
that are all over the world.

203
00:10:14.412 --> 00:10:16.380
They've gotta be able to
use that same language, and

204
00:10:16.380 --> 00:10:18.210
that's why these protocols
are very important.

205
00:10:18.210 --> 00:10:21.840
>> Exactly, like you just said that these
protocols of where there is two way

206
00:10:21.840 --> 00:10:28.380
communication, but the way it goes out is
using that simple mail transfer protocol.

207
00:10:28.380 --> 00:10:31.699
So your outgoing has to go to the SMTP.

208
00:10:31.699 --> 00:10:34.981
And then you also hear,

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show how to get an email account setup on outlook.  They demonstrate the dialog boxes you’ll see during a routine setup. She then shows how to do a manual setup within outlook as well.  Lastly, she discusses the process of removing an account from outlook.

that's not a very good name is it?

449
00:23:15.700 --> 00:23:19.550
So if you click on it, you have options
down here to then well, Rename.

450
00:23:19.550 --> 00:23:21.910
Because maybe I want to name this Von's,

451
00:23:21.910 --> 00:23:25.060
well let's not capitalize the o,
Von's Stuff.

452
00:23:26.220 --> 00:23:28.280
There we go.

453
00:23:28.280 --> 00:23:28.780
Perfect.

454
00:23:29.950 --> 00:23:32.720
So, we're going to go ahead and
click okay, and

455
00:23:32.720 --> 00:23:33.950
then you can see that's the name.

456
00:23:33.950 --> 00:23:35.220
I have a group.

457
00:23:35.220 --> 00:23:41.190
Now you have to be selected here,
before you can start adding your commands.

458
00:23:41.190 --> 00:23:43.790
Remember I said you have to have a group,
you don't have to make a group but

459
00:23:43.790 --> 00:23:46.070
you just have to make
sure that you're here.

460
00:23:46.070 --> 00:23:51.070
Cuz watch, if I click here and I say I
wanna go ahead and add a new email, and

461
00:23:51.070 --> 00:23:55.120
I click add, it's gonna say nope, you have
to be in the group before you can add it.

462
00:23:55.120 --> 00:23:56.434
Okay thank you for letting me know.

463
00:23:56.434 --> 00:24:00.972
Let me come over here to group and
I'll click on new email and now I'll add.

464
00:24:00.972 --> 00:24:04.420
And then I can start adding all sorts of
commands and I'm just gonna Honestly,

465
00:24:04.420 --> 00:24:08.147
I don't even know what I'm clicking on
anymore, I'm just adding certain things.

466
00:24:08.147 --> 00:24:12.673
And if you wanted to give your group
a different name, you can click on that

467
00:24:12.673 --> 00:24:17.860
group and you can rename and you can say
stuff cuz I don't know what else to say.

468
00:24:17.860 --> 00:24:21.540
And you can keep on going, notice you
can add more groups in your ribbon.

469
00:24:21.540 --> 00:24:24.450
You can start adding all
the different commands that you

470
00:24:24.450 --> 00:24:28.870
might have that you want to go ahead and
put in all one place and your ribbons.

471
00:24:28.870 --> 00:24:30.630
And that you could add some more things.

472
00:24:30.630 --> 00:24:36.100
I'm just gonna, I don't even know, let's
grab this one and we'll grab this one.

473
00:24:36.100 --> 00:24:37.690
Perfect, okay.

474
00:24:37.690 --> 00:24:39.970
And then I can go ahead and click OK.

475
00:24:39.970 --> 00:24:44.940
Notice that right now there's my Vonne
stuff, and I can see it right there.

476
00:24:44.940 --> 00:24:47.476
It's always going to be here,

477
00:24:47.476 --> 00:24:52.947
as a tab no matter what area I am
in in Outlook, it's gonna be a tab.

478
00:24:52.947 --> 00:24:57.087
And I could always move it over back
in that customization as like up and

479
00:24:57.087 --> 00:25:01.480
down buttons or if you want it to go
before Home instead of after Home.

480
00:25:01.480 --> 00:25:03.560
That's just where I was.

481
00:25:03.560 --> 00:25:05.850
And so you can see that I have
all the different commands and

482
00:25:05.850 --> 00:25:09.410
you can really start
customizing your area.

483
00:25:09.410 --> 00:25:12.680
Just really quickly gonna
go back over there to

484
00:25:12.680 --> 00:25:16.860
the customized ribbon to see right here,
where it says the Vonne stuff.

485
00:25:16.860 --> 00:25:20.563
The up and down arrows, that's what
I wanted to show, the bumpy arrows,

486
00:25:20.563 --> 00:25:21.354
as I call them.

487
00:25:21.354 --> 00:25:24.989
Where you can bump it all the way
up to be in front of everything.

488
00:25:24.989 --> 00:25:27.770
So, my tab will be first in all of them.

489
00:25:27.770 --> 00:25:32.510
And of course, you could always
reset this if you wanted to later.

490
00:25:32.510 --> 00:25:37.940
And that's where you can really kind of
start making your interface your own and

491
00:25:37.940 --> 00:25:41.510
how you want it to live, if you wanna say.

492
00:25:41.510 --> 00:25:44.400
Cuz this is how I want everything to work.

493
00:25:44.400 --> 00:25:46.986
There's one last thing that
I wanted to point out.

494
00:25:46.986 --> 00:25:51.697
And I remember the first time that I
installed this, cuz it's been a while.

495
00:25:51.697 --> 00:25:54.878
I was working on 2013 for
the longest time.

496
00:25:54.878 --> 00:25:56.920
And I didn't have this version.

497
00:25:56.920 --> 00:25:58.500
I didn't have it on a new laptop.

498
00:25:58.500 --> 00:26:01.070
I didn't have an Office 365 account,
all that kind of stuff.

499
00:26:02.240 --> 00:26:03.950
And this thing over here on the right,
okay,

500
00:26:03.950 --> 00:26:07.810
some of it's a little behind my head but
you see this little guy right over here?

501
00:26:07.810 --> 00:26:10.920
This bar and
I didn't even know what it was called.

502
00:26:10.920 --> 00:26:14.621
I'm like, I'm looking for it,
I'm looking in the View, I'm like,

503
00:26:14.621 --> 00:26:16.140
it's not turning off.

504
00:26:16.140 --> 00:26:16.910
Why won't it go?

505
00:26:16.910 --> 00:26:21.697
And it's there depending on whether I'm in
Calendar or I'm in Mail and I'm just like,

506
00:26:21.697 --> 00:26:24.970
I didn't even know what it's
called to get rid of it.

507
00:26:24.970 --> 00:26:27.438
Okay, because I'm like,
I don't really want that.

508
00:26:27.438 --> 00:26:30.753
It can be handy, it's kind of almost
like my Quick Access over but

509
00:26:30.753 --> 00:26:32.810
I have too many of them.

510
00:26:32.810 --> 00:26:37.120
That thing is called, well,
I don't even know what it's called.

511
00:26:37.120 --> 00:26:40.220
But it's called the Touch Mouse Mode,
okay?

512
00:26:40.220 --> 00:26:44.560
So this is really more for
if you're using touchscreen monitors.

513
00:26:44.560 --> 00:26:47.292
Because, of course,
with the new Windows operating systems and

514
00:26:47.292 --> 00:26:49.637
all the new computers,
it's all about touchscreens.

515
00:26:49.637 --> 00:26:52.495
And I read an article about
that that's why they made them.

516
00:26:52.495 --> 00:26:55.765
And I'm like, well, that makes sense but
I don't want it, so

517
00:26:55.765 --> 00:26:57.500
it told me how to turn it off.

518
00:26:57.500 --> 00:27:01.366
So I'm gonna tell you, from the Quick
Access toolbar, now mine's down below

519
00:27:01.366 --> 00:27:04.882
because remember I had shown my
Quick Access toolbar below my ribbon for

520
00:27:04.882 --> 00:27:05.480
right now.

521
00:27:05.480 --> 00:27:10.480
If I click on that,
it's right there, Touch Mouse Mod.

522
00:27:10.480 --> 00:27:13.544
If I click on that button, it's just
adding that button on the Quick Access

523
00:27:13.544 --> 00:27:16.188
toolbar, because, well,
that didn't do anything, I know.

524
00:27:16.188 --> 00:27:20.095
Because now, you can click on
the button and you drop down and

525
00:27:20.095 --> 00:27:25.224
you can see that it's going to give me
more options here of if I'm doing a mouse,

526
00:27:25.224 --> 00:27:29.680
cuz I'm on a computer with mouse,
I don't have touch screen.

527
00:27:29.680 --> 00:27:33.490
So if I click here,
notice how it takes that away and

528
00:27:33.490 --> 00:27:37.270
everything actually
condenses a little bit more.

529
00:27:37.270 --> 00:27:38.028
Di you see that?

530
00:27:38.028 --> 00:27:41.790
All of these options here, let me go
back on that and go back over to Touch.

531
00:27:41.790 --> 00:27:45.651
Did you see how much more space
is available on the ribbon now?

532
00:27:45.651 --> 00:27:47.988
All the commands are spaced out
a little bit more, cuz think about,

533
00:27:47.988 --> 00:27:51.033
cuz I know sometimes you touch things and
it's like, wait, no, that's the wrong.

534
00:27:51.033 --> 00:27:54.549
Especially my interface on my car,
the touch screen is so off, I'm like I'm

535
00:27:54.549 --> 00:27:58.354
clicking on one button and it's clicking
something over here and I'm like, arg.

536
00:27:58.354 --> 00:28:02.805
So it's just the different modes and not
only just like this bar over on the right

537
00:28:02.805 --> 00:28:07.520
hand side, but how much real estate, how
much space you have around the commands.

538
00:28:07.520 --> 00:28:11.470
So if you have a touch screen, that
might be one that you would wanna have.

539
00:28:11.470 --> 00:28:15.630
But if you are like me, I'm a mouse
person, I need to have my mouse.

540
00:28:15.630 --> 00:28:17.300
So you can switch it over here to mouse.

541
00:28:17.300 --> 00:28:19.970
It takes that little thing over there
on the right hand side away and

542
00:28:21.150 --> 00:28:24.750
you get a lot more commands on
your ribbon that you can see.

543
00:28:24.750 --> 00:28:26.140
And I think it's just a little bit easier.

544
00:28:26.140 --> 00:28:29.200
So I wanted to throw that out to you
because it bothered me when I first did my

545
00:28:29.200 --> 00:28:30.250
installation.

546
00:28:30.250 --> 00:28:35.369
So it might bother you as well, so that's
my little tip of the day for this episode.

547
00:28:35.369 --> 00:28:39.108
>> All right Vonne, well, thank you for
helping us to learn a little bit more

548
00:28:39.108 --> 00:28:43.269
about the interface before we really dive
into making sure that we can get Office to

549
00:28:43.269 --> 00:28:47.170
work the way that we want to or
Outlook to work the way that we want to.

550
00:28:47.170 --> 00:28:51.600
Having a brief and a beginning
understanding of where the things are and

551
00:28:51.600 --> 00:28:53.990
some of the terminology
in which Vonne used,

552
00:28:53.990 --> 00:28:56.710
is gonna help us especially
throughout the entire show.

553
00:28:56.710 --> 00:29:00.230
So thank you for helping us there too and
thank you also for joining us.

554
00:29:00.230 --> 00:29:03.970
But that's a great place for
us to also wrap up right here too.

555
00:29:03.970 --> 00:29:06.930
For OffficeProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong,

556
00:29:06.930 --> 00:29:07.980
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

557
00:29:07.980 --> 00:29:12.210
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Outlook 2016 shows.

558
00:29:12.210 --> 00:29:16.985
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne introduce the email interface.  Vonne navigates through the majority of the different views, folders panes and tools.  The team also describes some of the uses of the different folders too.  Vonne also describes the uses and the different way that we can customize the interface for a user to manage their own email client to suit himself/herself.
episodes.title: Email Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.028
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.028 --> 00:00:09.978
Welcome to another great episode
right here on Office Pro TV.

3
00:00:09.978 --> 00:00:12.680
You're watching the Outlook 2016 show.

4
00:00:12.680 --> 00:00:15.820
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and today,
we're gonna be learning about

5
00:00:15.820 --> 00:00:19.500
the email interface and Vonne Smith's
going to help guide us through that.

6
00:00:19.500 --> 00:00:20.660
Vonne, welcome back to our studios.

7
00:00:20.660 --> 00:00:21.867
>> Thank you for having me Ronnie.

8
00:00:21.867 --> 00:00:26.447
I'm excited to be here, cuz we've left
off in our previous episode we were

9
00:00:26.447 --> 00:00:31.411
talking about the Outlook interface,
about the whole program in its entirety.

10
00:00:31.411 --> 00:00:36.300
And now we're gonna be focusing
directly in the email area of Outlook.

11
00:00:36.300 --> 00:00:39.075
So we're gonna get familiar
with the different folders,

12
00:00:39.075 --> 00:00:42.018
talk about what they are,
identify the different views, and

13
00:00:42.018 --> 00:00:45.630
all the different options you can have for
looking at what you're seeing.

14
00:00:45.630 --> 00:00:47.160
[LAUGH] For lack of a better term.

15
00:00:47.160 --> 00:00:51.162
And then that way you get a better
idea of where we're going,

16
00:00:51.162 --> 00:00:55.889
so in our future episodes we'll be
able to just identify those in a bit.

17
00:00:55.889 --> 00:00:58.560
I know what that is because I
watched the email interface episode.

18
00:00:59.582 --> 00:01:04.290
>> Yeah, Vonne that really does make sense
for us to have a solid foundation here.

19
00:01:04.290 --> 00:01:07.940
Email is probably what we spend
the majority of the time on anyways.

20
00:01:07.940 --> 00:01:10.580
So it's good for
us to get a good solid grounding on

21
00:01:10.580 --> 00:01:13.020
all the different things that
we'll end up seeing here.

22
00:01:13.020 --> 00:01:15.486
Because it's more than just sending and
receiving emails,

23
00:01:15.486 --> 00:01:16.897
there's a lot more that we can do.

24
00:01:16.897 --> 00:01:18.347
So Vonne where are we gonna begin?

25
00:01:18.347 --> 00:01:21.897
>> Alright, well why don't we go ahead and
jump down to my computer and

26
00:01:21.897 --> 00:01:24.591
I have Outlook already
opened up on this computer.

27
00:01:24.591 --> 00:01:29.015
And I set some things up before this
episode to be able to show you all

28
00:01:29.015 --> 00:01:32.180
the different pieces and
areas within email.

29
00:01:32.180 --> 00:01:35.530
So let's start over on
the left hand side and

30
00:01:35.530 --> 00:01:38.935
this area right over here,
we identified as the folder pane,

31
00:01:38.935 --> 00:01:43.075
because everything that we're working
with in Outlook it it really is a folder.

32
00:01:43.075 --> 00:01:47.169
Like we have our inbox is a folder,
our outbox is a folder.

33
00:01:47.169 --> 00:01:51.809
The calendar really is a folder as well,
even though we're calling it an area or

34
00:01:51.809 --> 00:01:53.553
different piece of Outlook.

35
00:01:53.553 --> 00:01:58.376
But the way Outlook sees it, they're all
folders within the Outlook filing cabinet,

36
00:01:58.376 --> 00:01:59.374
if you would say.

37
00:01:59.374 --> 00:02:02.790
So in this main section of the email
interface over on the right,

38
00:02:02.790 --> 00:02:07.093
that would be the other right, that would
be the left, [LAUGH] the left hand side,

39
00:02:07.093 --> 00:02:08.127
we have our inbox.

40
00:02:08.127 --> 00:02:10.410
So what is the inbox?

41
00:02:10.410 --> 00:02:12.100
Kind of says it itself.

42
00:02:12.100 --> 00:02:15.080
It's the place where all
your mail comes into.

43
00:02:15.080 --> 00:02:16.650
So that's what we've got right over here.

44
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:18.510
And if I click on it
on the left hand side,

45
00:02:18.510 --> 00:02:20.470
nothing's really gonna change right now.

46
00:02:20.470 --> 00:02:24.536
Because I'm already in
the inbox by default.

47
00:02:24.536 --> 00:02:26.402
So what is the drafts folder?

48
00:02:26.402 --> 00:02:30.713
The drafts is kind of, if you think
about if I'm drafting a letter or

49
00:02:30.713 --> 00:02:33.890
I'm creating a draft
before my final paper.

50
00:02:33.890 --> 00:02:37.490
It's a place where you kind of won't
let things hang out for a little bit.

51
00:02:37.490 --> 00:02:40.270
And kind of let it breed if you wanna say.

52
00:02:40.270 --> 00:02:44.930
So place where if you saved any mail,
like if you are starting a new message.

53
00:02:44.930 --> 00:02:46.190
And you click the save button,

54
00:02:46.190 --> 00:02:48.450
it's automatically gonna
go into your drafts folder.

55
00:02:48.450 --> 00:02:52.060
And so that's where your
saved messages will hang out.

56
00:02:52.060 --> 00:02:55.803
And I'm gonna go ahead and click on it,
and you can see once I single click on

57
00:02:55.803 --> 00:02:59.668
the left-hand side on the drafts folder,
it takes me in to the drafts area and

58
00:02:59.668 --> 00:03:02.724
shows me all the different things
that are in that right now.

59
00:03:02.724 --> 00:03:06.422
So this area right here in
the main middle section is

60
00:03:06.422 --> 00:03:11.324
going to be viewing whatever folder
that you are in at that time, and

61
00:03:11.324 --> 00:03:15.288
I had put one in here that I
started in an email to Lance.

62
00:03:15.288 --> 00:03:19.554
And I was going to save it for later, and
you can see I actually gave it a subject

63
00:03:19.554 --> 00:03:23.770
line, and it says, saving for later,
cuz I'm not ready to send it.

64
00:03:23.770 --> 00:03:25.660
So I'm letting it hangout in the drafts.

65
00:03:25.660 --> 00:03:29.771
You can also see over on the left-hand
side the little numbers to the right

66
00:03:29.771 --> 00:03:31.372
of each of the folder names.

67
00:03:31.372 --> 00:03:34.668
And the inbox I have
a bold number 2 in there.

68
00:03:34.668 --> 00:03:38.971
In the drafts folder I have a 1 in
those little square brackets, and

69
00:03:38.971 --> 00:03:42.143
that's just indicating
the amount of drafts, or

70
00:03:42.143 --> 00:03:46.730
amount of emails that I have in
the drafts folder waiting for me.

71
00:03:46.730 --> 00:03:51.430
And the two means that I have
two unread messages in my inbox.

72
00:03:51.430 --> 00:03:53.610
Now once I go ahead and
read those messages,

73
00:03:53.610 --> 00:03:55.870
that number two is gonna go to zero.

74
00:03:55.870 --> 00:03:57.916
But that's always the number
that you look at is like,

75
00:03:57.916 --> 00:03:59.125
how many new e-mails do I have.

76
00:03:59.125 --> 00:04:04.317
And I can remember coming back from
a vacation, or a weekend, and that's just

77
00:04:04.317 --> 00:04:09.444
a really large number, and you just
kind of go, okay, let's jump right in.

78
00:04:09.444 --> 00:04:11.460
[LAUGH] And get cracking on that.

79
00:04:11.460 --> 00:04:13.930
So that's what the numbers
mean over there.

80
00:04:13.930 --> 00:04:16.870
So let's go ahead and keep navigating
through our different folders.

81
00:04:16.870 --> 00:04:18.140
The sent Items.

82
00:04:18.140 --> 00:04:20.920
What do you think that means, Ronnie?

83
00:04:20.920 --> 00:04:24.970
>> I'm assuming that it means that it's
emails that we actually have sent.

84
00:04:24.970 --> 00:04:25.750
>> Correct, yes.

85
00:04:25.750 --> 00:04:27.450
It's items that we have sent.

86
00:04:27.450 --> 00:04:28.100
>> Right.
>> So

87
00:04:28.100 --> 00:04:31.120
those are the different ones that
I have sent to somebody else.

88
00:04:31.120 --> 00:04:34.490
I don't really know how many other
ways I can really explain that,

89
00:04:34.490 --> 00:04:36.430
except it's the sent items.

90
00:04:36.430 --> 00:04:37.710
Let's keep on moving down.

91
00:04:37.710 --> 00:04:40.560
Deleted, well,
that's pretty self-explanatory as well.

92
00:04:40.560 --> 00:04:41.872
This is your trashcan.

93
00:04:41.872 --> 00:04:44.316
It's the Items that you have said,
I don't want that email.

94
00:04:44.316 --> 00:04:46.549
Cuz maybe coming back
after that vacation and

95
00:04:46.549 --> 00:04:50.483
you've got a bunch of emails from
somebody that's just talking about, well,

96
00:04:50.483 --> 00:04:52.671
the pizza that they had for
lunch on Friday.

97
00:04:52.671 --> 00:04:55.075
It's like, well I wasn't here on Friday so
I don't really mind.

98
00:04:55.075 --> 00:04:56.850
But I don't really want
to hear about this.

99
00:04:56.850 --> 00:04:58.940
So you just hit the delete key and
it just goes away and

100
00:04:58.940 --> 00:05:01.340
it goes into your deleted items.

101
00:05:01.340 --> 00:05:02.470
Now just because you go ahead and

102
00:05:02.470 --> 00:05:06.530
delete a message doesn't mean
that they permanently go away.

103
00:05:06.530 --> 00:05:11.240
It is like our recycle bin on our desktop
or in our operating system is that

104
00:05:11.240 --> 00:05:14.830
you put something in the trash, but that
doesn't mean that you cannot fish that

105
00:05:14.830 --> 00:05:19.350
thing out of the trash, I know we've all
done that before, so the same thing here.

106
00:05:19.350 --> 00:05:22.710
If you now delete your trash, or

107
00:05:22.710 --> 00:05:26.950
you go ahead and empty your deleted items,
well then it's permanently gone.

108
00:05:26.950 --> 00:05:29.090
So they just go ahead and
hang out in the trash bin, or

the last week.

543
00:28:47.490 --> 00:28:48.570
I like this.

544
00:28:48.570 --> 00:28:50.120
I never really saw a problem with it.

545
00:28:50.120 --> 00:28:52.363
But what if you didn't
want it to show that way?

546
00:28:52.363 --> 00:28:56.890
I don't want it to organize and
group by the dates.

547
00:28:56.890 --> 00:28:58.430
If you go into your view settings, and

548
00:28:58.430 --> 00:29:01.940
this is where it can go really crazy on
all the different things that you can do.

549
00:29:01.940 --> 00:29:09.950
But you can see that it's going into
the group by, notice that it says none.

550
00:29:09.950 --> 00:29:11.240
So it's a little confusing.

551
00:29:11.240 --> 00:29:14.120
You're like, well,
it's not grouped by anything, but it is.

552
00:29:14.120 --> 00:29:15.000
You go to Grouped By,

553
00:29:15.000 --> 00:29:19.320
do you see where it says automatically
group according to arrangement?

554
00:29:19.320 --> 00:29:21.070
It's arranged by dates.

555
00:29:21.070 --> 00:29:24.400
So if I unchecked that and click OK,

556
00:29:24.400 --> 00:29:30.210
and click OK again,
all of those groups are going to go away.

557
00:29:30.210 --> 00:29:31.840
Just in case you didn't like it and

558
00:29:31.840 --> 00:29:37.180
you wanted to turn it off, I am gonna turn
it back on cuz I tend to think it's nice.

559
00:29:37.180 --> 00:29:37.783
And again,

560
00:29:37.783 --> 00:29:42.304
we're sorting it by date right now, really
quickly, we're gonna have another episode

561
00:29:42.304 --> 00:29:45.819
where we do a lot more about searching
how to kinda organize ourself.

562
00:29:45.819 --> 00:29:49.367
But if you don't wanna sort it by
date at the tops of column you can

563
00:29:49.367 --> 00:29:53.300
always come down here cuz maybe
you are trying to find something.

564
00:29:53.300 --> 00:29:56.250
You can always sort it
by different things.

565
00:29:56.250 --> 00:30:00.160
Since we are talking about email,
I think date makes the most sense,

566
00:30:00.160 --> 00:30:05.370
but if you ever needed to change it here
you could do it and then change it back.

567
00:30:05.370 --> 00:30:08.460
Change it from, do you want the oldest or
newest on top and

568
00:30:08.460 --> 00:30:11.380
so, it's different ways of sorting and
filtering, if you want to say.

569
00:30:11.380 --> 00:30:13.510
It's really sorting,
we're not really filtering.

570
00:30:13.510 --> 00:30:15.850
So, we're sorting our emails.

571
00:30:15.850 --> 00:30:20.050
And, I think that covers everything
about the email interface

572
00:30:20.050 --> 00:30:21.330
that I have listed in my notes.

573
00:30:21.330 --> 00:30:23.198
So, I think we're done, Ronnie.

574
00:30:23.198 --> 00:30:24.346
>> All right, Vonne,

575
00:30:24.346 --> 00:30:28.202
well, thank you for introducing
us to the email interface itself.

576
00:30:28.202 --> 00:30:32.450
Remember that there's a lot more to
what you're actually seeing before you.

577
00:30:32.450 --> 00:30:34.880
Most of us might just jump in there,
and send emails and

578
00:30:34.880 --> 00:30:37.440
never explore all of
the options that you'll see.

579
00:30:37.440 --> 00:30:41.020
But realize, it is a powerful
interface that we can do more

580
00:30:41.020 --> 00:30:44.870
in the display that we have, as well as
change the way that we interact with it.

581
00:30:44.870 --> 00:30:49.360
It takes a little more time but
at least now you'll have the ability to

582
00:30:49.360 --> 00:30:52.730
continue forward with the show and
know exactly what we're talking about.

583
00:30:52.730 --> 00:30:55.510
Well, that's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

584
00:30:55.510 --> 00:30:58.580
For Office Pro TV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

585
00:30:58.580 --> 00:30:59.600
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

586
00:30:59.600 --> 00:31:02.379
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Outlook 2016 shows.

587
00:31:02.379 --> 00:31:06.452
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore working with the Focused inbox option in Outlook 2016. Here you will learn what Focused inbox is and how to enable or disable it. They also discuss how the Focused inbox relates to the Clutter option in previous versions.
episodes.title: Focused Inbox
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.114 --> 00:00:05.863
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.863 --> 00:00:08.760
All right, greetings everyone,
welcome to OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:08.760 --> 00:00:12.240
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:12.240 --> 00:00:15.880
we are continuing on with more
on our Outlook 2016 series.

5
00:00:15.880 --> 00:00:17.210
Joining us in the studio yet

6
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:19.880
again, you know her, you love her,
she's Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:19.880 --> 00:00:21.900
Vonne, welcome back, we're so
glad to have you again today.

8
00:00:21.900 --> 00:00:25.390
>> Thank you Daniel,
glad to be here with you, yes.

9
00:00:25.390 --> 00:00:27.260
And we're talking today-
>> Stop.

10
00:00:27.260 --> 00:00:27.802
>> I know.

11
00:00:27.802 --> 00:00:29.100
>> [LAUGH]
>> And today,

12
00:00:29.100 --> 00:00:32.330
we're going to be talking
about Focused Inbox.

13
00:00:32.330 --> 00:00:36.590
And if you're watching these episodes
in order, you're like, well,

14
00:00:36.590 --> 00:00:38.050
one, Vonne's wearing a different shirt.

15
00:00:38.050 --> 00:00:39.583
And, two, we have a different host.

16
00:00:39.583 --> 00:00:41.188
It's not Ronnie anymore,

17
00:00:41.188 --> 00:00:45.950
because I'm putting this episode in
the order right after the Email interface.

18
00:00:45.950 --> 00:00:49.400
So this is almost like a part two,
but it's not a part two.

19
00:00:49.400 --> 00:00:55.658
It's a continuation of the interface, so
it's not really a part two at all, is it?

20
00:00:55.658 --> 00:00:57.925
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's its own episode, but

21
00:00:57.925 --> 00:01:01.711
it's something that actually
happen to me just last week.

22
00:01:01.711 --> 00:01:05.857
Filming, we were right in the middle
of filming the Outlook 2016,

23
00:01:05.857 --> 00:01:07.870
we've done quite a few episodes.

24
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:10.195
And now I'm just like,
I come back to my desk and I'm like,

25
00:01:11.582 --> 00:01:15.445
It doesn't look the same as when I was
just in the studio, what just happened?

26
00:01:15.445 --> 00:01:19.078
>> No, our sweet little lamb here got
angry and frustrated at the same time.

27
00:01:19.078 --> 00:01:23.214
I thought the world was gonna implode on
itself with the fire and the snorting,

28
00:01:23.214 --> 00:01:23.975
it was crazy.

29
00:01:23.975 --> 00:01:25.950
>> Yeah,
I did have a little mini-meltdown.

30
00:01:25.950 --> 00:01:29.674
Because I originally just thought,
okay, all right, well,

31
00:01:29.674 --> 00:01:31.934
something changed in the interface.

32
00:01:31.934 --> 00:01:34.750
Let me just switch it back,
I couldn't switch back.

33
00:01:34.750 --> 00:01:38.300
And I'm thinking well,
I'm filming this entire show based

34
00:01:38.300 --> 00:01:42.280
on the interface that
I am presenting here.

35
00:01:42.280 --> 00:01:45.650
And now, my interface has changed.

36
00:01:45.650 --> 00:01:47.642
And while it really is,
it's a small thing,

37
00:01:47.642 --> 00:01:49.850
it really is a very small
change in the interface.

38
00:01:49.850 --> 00:01:53.528
But it's one of those, that it's small
enough to be really, really big.

39
00:01:53.528 --> 00:01:58.290
Anytime that your environment changes, and
Microsoft decides to put a button that

40
00:01:58.290 --> 00:02:00.884
once was on the right,
but it's on the left.

41
00:02:00.884 --> 00:02:02.386
It throws your whole world off for
a while.

42
00:02:02.386 --> 00:02:05.715
>> It's a paradigm shift,
and people get really crazy.

43
00:02:05.715 --> 00:02:08.014
Because they're so
used to being able to, I mean,

44
00:02:08.014 --> 00:02:11.298
you almost get muscle memory to
going to things that you're used to.

45
00:02:11.298 --> 00:02:13.838
There's where my Start button is,
there's where this button is,

46
00:02:13.838 --> 00:02:15.360
there's where that button is.

47
00:02:15.360 --> 00:02:19.770
And when you change that on someone,
they feel lost in the woods.

48
00:02:19.770 --> 00:02:22.809
And we've all be there, we've all
done that, we all understand that.

49
00:02:22.809 --> 00:02:27.030
So today, I guess we're gonna talk about
finding our ways through those woods.

50
00:02:27.030 --> 00:02:29.531
Understanding where has
Microsoft put things and, so

51
00:02:29.531 --> 00:02:31.840
that we can become more
familiarized with it.

52
00:02:31.840 --> 00:02:35.140
That being said, what do they mean
when they say Focused Inbox, Vonne?

53
00:02:35.140 --> 00:02:36.160
>> Exactly, so

54
00:02:36.160 --> 00:02:40.280
if you're looking at the interface in the
episode that you just finished watching.

55
00:02:40.280 --> 00:02:43.960
If you're, again, in order,
mine doesn't look anything like that.

56
00:02:43.960 --> 00:02:46.027
So let's jump down into my computer, and

57
00:02:46.027 --> 00:02:49.287
let me give you some demonstrations
as to what I am talking about.

58
00:02:49.287 --> 00:02:51.589
So right here,
I'm in Joey's inbox right now.

59
00:02:51.589 --> 00:02:55.139
Because as you know,
I'm multiple people in this episode, and

60
00:02:55.139 --> 00:02:56.360
sometimes-
>> True schizophrenic.

61
00:02:56.360 --> 00:02:57.901
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yes, and sometimes you take on some

62
00:02:57.901 --> 00:02:59.201
other personalities as well.

63
00:02:59.201 --> 00:02:59.718
>> I do.

64
00:02:59.718 --> 00:03:02.891
>> So
it's all a big fun game of who's who.

65
00:03:02.891 --> 00:03:03.611
>> Who's who.

66
00:03:03.611 --> 00:03:05.980
>> Yeah, right now, so
this is Joey's inbox.

67
00:03:05.980 --> 00:03:09.944
And you can see in the interface, the way
that we had filmed the previous episode.

68
00:03:09.944 --> 00:03:14.102
Where we had the buttons on the top,
where we had All, Unread, Mentions, and

69
00:03:14.102 --> 00:03:15.301
sorted them by dates.

70
00:03:15.301 --> 00:03:19.806
And I just touched upon it, we didn't
really go into depth as to using those and

71
00:03:19.806 --> 00:03:24.127
the functionalities of that top row,
I'm calling it, with the buttons.

72
00:03:24.127 --> 00:03:27.960
But I did show it, well, this is Joey.

73
00:03:27.960 --> 00:03:33.456
And let me show you JT, because JT was
the account that I was teaching from,

74
00:03:33.456 --> 00:03:35.210
and now look at the top.

75
00:03:35.210 --> 00:03:36.940
There's no Mentions, there's no Unread,

76
00:03:36.940 --> 00:03:40.260
and there's no buttons of the Sort By,
the dates and how to arrange it.

77
00:03:40.260 --> 00:03:42.864
And so I was like, what just happened?

78
00:03:42.864 --> 00:03:47.510
>> [LAUGH]
>> This is the new interface that all of

79
00:03:47.510 --> 00:03:50.200
your Outlook 2016s are going to.

80
00:03:50.200 --> 00:03:53.040
Now this is something
that's not new to me.

81
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:57.680
I've seen this because, I think,
I know you use Outlook.com, you go online.

82
00:03:57.680 --> 00:03:59.740
You don't have Outlook installed
on your computer, correct?

83
00:03:59.740 --> 00:04:00.850
>> That's correct.

84
00:04:00.850 --> 00:04:02.820
>> Yeah, so this doesn't look
anything new to you, correct?

85
00:04:02.820 --> 00:04:05.423
>> No.
>> Yeah, because Outlook.com has been

86
00:04:05.423 --> 00:04:09.802
using this interface for a while,
so I wasn't completely thrown off.

87
00:04:09.802 --> 00:04:11.936
But enough to where I thought,

88
00:04:11.936 --> 00:04:17.270
locally installed versions of
Outlook don't have this just yet.

89
00:04:17.270 --> 00:04:21.730
So, what happened, why did it happen,
and how can I use it?

90
00:04:21.730 --> 00:04:24.841
So it changed over to the Focused and
the Other.

91
00:04:24.841 --> 00:04:27.685
And then if I come over
here to the View tab,

92
00:04:27.685 --> 00:04:32.508
I have a new button on the View tab
that says, Show Focused inbox, okay.

93
00:04:32.508 --> 00:04:35.905
So what does this all mean?

94
00:04:35.905 --> 00:04:41.142
What a Focused Inbox,
it's Outlook being smart for us.

95
00:04:41.142 --> 00:04:46.080
It is where Outlook is determining
what email comes to you,

96
00:04:46.080 --> 00:04:49.061
that it thinks is important to you.

97
00:04:49.061 --> 00:04:52.550
And then the Other,
that's kind of secondary.

98
00:04:52.550 --> 00:04:57.350
Because we get e-mails all day long,
and we usually get a lot of junk mail,

99
00:04:57.350 --> 00:05:00.150
and we do have an entire
episode about junk mail.

100
00:05:00.150 --> 00:05:03.270
And what gets treated as junk,
what gets treated as Other,

101
00:05:03.270 --> 00:05:04.630
what gets treated as Focused.

102
00:05:04.630 --> 00:05:07.780
It's kind of right now,
I feel that, Outlook and Microsoft,

103
00:05:07.780 --> 00:05:10.566
they're kind of in a shifting phase,
right?

104
00:05:10.566 --> 00:05:14.800
They're in a transition right now,
of all of these different services.

105
00:05:14.800 --> 00:05:19.394
For Outlook to really help you, to be able
to just get to what you need to get, and

106
00:05:19.394 --> 00:05:21.395
not get you all the other clutter.

107
00:05:21.395 --> 00:05:24.169
I'm mentioning clutter,
specifically, as a word.

108
00:05:24.169 --> 00:05:28.873
Because there are some previous
versions of Outlook that was using

109
00:05:28.873 --> 00:05:31.396
a Clutter folder, your junk mail.

110
00:05:31.396 --> 00:05:34.661
So if you're coming from Outlook 2013, or

111
00:05:34.661 --> 00:05:38.588
any type of Office 365 where
you had a Clutter folder?

112
00:05:38.588 --> 00:05:43.960
Well, this is the new Clutter,
this is the new Junk.

113
00:05:43.960 --> 00:05:49.960
Even though we still have Junk Mail, it's
just trying to sort out your mail for you.

114
00:05:51.100 --> 00:05:54.730
I think this can be a good feature, but
of course it's like, well, Microsoft,

115
00:05:54.730 --> 00:05:56.920
how do you know it's important to me?

116
00:05:56.920 --> 00:05:58.887
I know it's important to me,
so can you please stop?

117
00:05:58.887 --> 00:06:01.889
So it's funny, if you go online,
you start looking at message boards?

118
00:06:01.889 --> 00:06:04.276
There are people just
up in arms about this.

119
00:06:04.276 --> 00:06:06.765
How are you supposed to tell
me what I'm supposed to do?

120
00:06:06.765 --> 00:06:09.406
>> [LAUGH]
>> They're not happy.

121
00:06:09.406 --> 00:06:12.280
But that's something-
>> And they say it exactly like that, too.

122
00:06:12.280 --> 00:06:15.076
>> Yes, all caps, I'm very mad!

123
00:06:15.076 --> 00:06:17.202
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, it's one of those,

124
00:06:17.202 --> 00:06:21.626
we're in transition, and
anything that starts being different,

125
00:06:21.626 --> 00:06:24.041
it gets us a little worked up, okay.

126
00:06:24.041 --> 00:06:28.360
So, it's a good thing,
if you want it to be-

127
00:06:28.360 --> 00:06:29.400
>> [LAUGH]

128
00:06:29.400 --> 00:06:31.074
>> And if you allow it to be.

129
00:06:31.074 --> 00:06:34.070
Now, how did I get this to change?

130
00:06:34.070 --> 00:06:37.600
We have talked in our
episodes about updates, and

131
00:06:37.600 --> 00:06:40.220
what version of Outlook that you are in.

132
00:06:40.220 --> 00:06:42.020
Now that's gonna be another big thing.

133
00:06:42.020 --> 00:06:44.865
So let's jump over here to Joey,
so Joey's account.

134
00:06:44.865 --> 00:06:48.277
I'm gonna come over here to my file, and
I'm gonna go over to my Office account.

135
00:06:48.277 --> 00:06:50.309
And over here in the Product Information,

136
00:06:50.309 --> 00:06:53.025
there's always somewhere where
you need to be aware of.

137
00:06:53.025 --> 00:06:57.720
Cuz right here, you can see that this is
Version 1703, and there's a build number.

138
00:06:57.720 --> 00:07:02.270
And then I also have,
what type of update schedule I'm on.

139
00:07:02.270 --> 00:07:06.390
Right now, Current Channel means that it's
going to be updating itself every month,

140
00:07:06.390 --> 00:07:08.060
automatically.

141
00:07:08.060 --> 00:07:12.244
There is another channel, which I honestly
can't remember the name of it, but

142
00:07:12.244 --> 00:07:13.877
it updates every four months.

143
00:07:13.877 --> 00:07:17.958
And these are the settings that you
can control in your Admin section.

144
00:07:17.958 --> 00:07:23.115
And you can say, that I want to be on the
Current Channel, or the Deferred Channel?

145
00:07:23.115 --> 00:07:26.632
I don't think that's the right name,
but I can go and look up which it is.

146
00:07:26.632 --> 00:07:29.206
It's basically one choice or
the other choice, okay,

147
00:07:29.206 --> 00:07:30.590
whichever one you want to do.

148
00:07:30.590 --> 00:07:32.955
Now these are settings that you
might not be able to control.

149
00:07:32.955 --> 00:07:37.961
If you're in an environment, that your
IT department controls when you update.

150
00:07:37.961 --> 00:07:41.977
But if you're more of a personal user,
or in a small organization,

151
00:07:41.977 --> 00:07:43.460
you have access to that?

152
00:07:43.460 --> 00:07:45.650
Then that's something
that you can control.

153
00:07:45.650 --> 00:07:48.900
So something you might not be able to.

154
00:07:50.080 --> 00:07:54.260
Let's jump over to JT's account,
and let's go over here to File, and

155
00:07:54.260 --> 00:07:56.500
go into the Office account here.

156
00:07:56.500 --> 00:08:01.696
Notice his version is 1704, and
it's a build that's 8,000-something,

157
00:08:01.696 --> 00:08:04.590
the other build was 7,000-something.

158
00:08:04.590 --> 00:08:08.110
So right here,
that's a big indication, to me,

159
00:08:08.110 --> 00:08:13.920
that JT is on the next version or
the next update of that Office product.

160
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:19.385
And in that update, that's probably where
the Focused and the Other came about.

161
00:08:19.385 --> 00:08:25.091
And so that's, I think, the reason
of why JT's account went ahead and

162
00:08:25.091 --> 00:08:27.861
changed, versus Joey and Lance.

163
00:08:27.861 --> 00:08:30.524
That I also have other virtual
machines that have those.

164
00:08:30.524 --> 00:08:32.758
They're not updated, and so
they don't have the Focused.

165
00:08:32.758 --> 00:08:36.185
They have the same, well I guess
you can call it old school way,

166
00:08:36.185 --> 00:08:38.330
even though it's not really that old.

167
00:08:38.330 --> 00:08:40.070
>> Justin's through the looking glass,
as it were.

168
00:08:40.070 --> 00:08:44.390
He's on the other side of, welcome to
the new ways in which we do things, and

169
00:08:44.390 --> 00:08:46.090
you're not going back.

170
00:08:46.090 --> 00:08:47.850
And the other guys aren't there now.

171
00:08:47.850 --> 00:08:50.854
>> Exactly, and that was where, well
I'll just set it, I can't set it back.

172
00:08:50.854 --> 00:08:56.407
Over in JT, the only thing I have control
over in my View tab Iis whether I want,

173
00:08:56.407 --> 00:08:59.619
whether or not I want it to Focus or
not Focus.

174
00:08:59.619 --> 00:09:02.805
And that's kind of a nice thing, if
everyone's, I don't want focus to happen,

175
00:09:02.805 --> 00:09:04.440
just turn it off.

176
00:09:04.440 --> 00:09:08.110
And if I click this,
now you can see that it just says, Inbox.

177
00:09:08.110 --> 00:09:13.011
There's no automatic sorting, based upon
Microsoft's looking at your mail and

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne introduce emailing basics a single recipient.  They demonstrate the use of the email addresses and subject line.  They also show how to attach files to an email as well as receive them to view or save.  They also show how to change to conversation view to see the messages and replies in the chronology they were sent.
episodes.title: Email Basics

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne continue with some emailing basics with multiple recipients.  They establish the use of CC and the BCC when sending emails.   Vonne emphasizes the use of BBC should be a conscious choice.  She also shows and explains the use of forwarding emails along with the use of email drafts too.

So, where we gonna go to next?

245
00:14:18.070 --> 00:14:18.940
Goodness.

246
00:14:18.940 --> 00:14:20.210
>> The BCC.

247
00:14:20.210 --> 00:14:24.160
>> The BCC field in your e-mail,
blind carbon copy.

248
00:14:25.910 --> 00:14:28.030
This is where you start hiding things.

249
00:14:28.030 --> 00:14:32.312
Maybe you're having a conversation
between you and a co-worker, and

250
00:14:32.312 --> 00:14:35.804
you want to include your boss on this or
somebody else, but

251
00:14:35.804 --> 00:14:38.388
you don't want the other person to see it.

252
00:14:38.388 --> 00:14:41.860
And this is where it starts sounding
a little devious [LAUGH] and

253
00:14:41.860 --> 00:14:43.820
a little covert.

254
00:14:43.820 --> 00:14:46.762
So I guess that's also, always be aware,

255
00:14:46.762 --> 00:14:52.320
at any time in any of your e-mail
exchanges, anyone could be bcc'd on that.

256
00:14:52.320 --> 00:14:53.010
>> True.

257
00:14:53.010 --> 00:14:55.140
>> So
be cautious about what you say sometimes.

258
00:14:56.830 --> 00:14:57.851
Just throwing it out there.

259
00:14:57.851 --> 00:15:02.880
[LAUGH] So what is the, like I said it's
the bcc, it's the blind carbon copy.

260
00:15:02.880 --> 00:15:04.340
And who's seeing what?

261
00:15:04.340 --> 00:15:08.322
And this is where,
is everybody in the BCC field, or

262
00:15:08.322 --> 00:15:09.960
are there people in the To field?

263
00:15:09.960 --> 00:15:12.160
Let me explain.

00:15:12.160 --> 00:15:13.590
I'm gonna come into here.

00:15:13.590 --> 00:15:17.570
If I address this to Lance,
and I see, I go ahead and,

00:15:17.570 --> 00:15:20.330

00:15:20.330 --> 00:15:21.680
I forgot where I was at.

00:15:21.680 --> 00:15:23.708
We'll go ahead and do Lance.

00:15:23.708 --> 00:15:31.626
And I BCC Joey,
Joey needs to go down here, okay?

00:15:31.626 --> 00:15:37.940
Joey is going to receive the e-mail and
see that it went to Lance.

271
00:15:37.940 --> 00:15:41.190
Lance will also see that it went to him,
but he won't see Joey.

272
00:15:41.190 --> 00:15:44.530
So if there's somebody in the To or
the BCC field,

273
00:15:44.530 --> 00:15:50.130
that person that gets blind carbon copied
on it, it sees those recipients, okay?

274
00:15:50.130 --> 00:15:52.950
I actually have an example over here.

00:15:52.950 --> 00:15:58.550
This is Chris' e-mail in Gmail

00:15:58.550 --> 00:16:05.030

00:16:10.640 --> 00:16:14.760
but Lance and
Joey didn't see me on their email.

279
00:16:14.760 --> 00:16:17.840
Okay, so just kind of clarifying.

280
00:16:17.840 --> 00:16:23.330
To and
Ccs always get shown to everybody, okay?

281
00:16:23.330 --> 00:16:25.180
Let's come back over to here.

00:16:25.180 --> 00:16:30.770
So that's kind of the composition

00:16:30.770 --> 00:16:34.410

00:16:34.410 --> 00:16:37.550
I gotta make sure I got that
semicolon in between them.

285
00:16:37.550 --> 00:16:41.330
Always separate your multiple
recipients by semicolons.

286
00:16:41.330 --> 00:16:44.550
When I was using this, it automatically
did this and sometimes when you delete it,

287
00:16:44.550 --> 00:16:46.330
you get multiple semicolons.

00:16:46.330 --> 00:16:50.520
So just kinda go back and proof it out and
make sure that there is a semicolon

00:16:50.520 --> 00:16:54.800
between each recipient in
whatever field you're working in.

00:16:54.800 --> 00:17:01.320
Now if I sent this to Joey and
Lance, that were both gonna be Bcc,

00:17:01.320 --> 00:17:06.965

what this is gonna look like is that Joey

00:17:06.965 --> 00:17:12.140

00:17:12.140 --> 00:17:17.540

00:17:17.540 --> 00:17:21.630
think that he is the only
person on that email as well.

00:17:21.630 --> 00:17:23.810
It's like you're basically
protecting people,

296
00:17:23.810 --> 00:17:25.670
if you wanna say,
from their email addresses.

297
00:17:25.670 --> 00:17:29.470
Like if I was emailing this out to a list
of students or all of my instructors and

298
00:17:29.470 --> 00:17:34.530
I wanted them to see like this
global message from me, but if

299
00:17:34.530 --> 00:17:39.040
I put them all in the to field, everybody
sees each other's email addresses.

300
00:17:39.040 --> 00:17:40.000
And of course, what does that mean?

301
00:17:40.000 --> 00:17:43.317
You can take them and
you can email that person individually.

302
00:17:43.317 --> 00:17:45.997
So I'm trying to kind of
hide their identity but

303
00:17:45.997 --> 00:17:48.147
just hide their privacy a little bit.

304
00:17:48.147 --> 00:17:52.334
Like I don't want to send every single
student everybody's email address because

305
00:17:52.334 --> 00:17:54.520
they don't need to see that.

306
00:17:54.520 --> 00:17:59.690
So putting everybody in the Bcc,
message to everybody but

00:17:59.690 --> 00:18:03.580
it's only to a single
recipient on their end.

308
00:18:04.620 --> 00:18:08.830
So understanding when
to use the Bcc versus

309
00:18:08.830 --> 00:18:11.230
putting everybody into the To field.

310
00:18:11.230 --> 00:18:13.780
Do you want everybody to see everything or

311
00:18:13.780 --> 00:18:16.590
you want people to not see everything,
okay?

312
00:18:16.590 --> 00:18:20.393
So that's always a good
thing to notice about.

00:18:20.393 --> 00:18:23.447
So if I go ahead and say okay,

In our previous episode,

To fields and then this is the one that

Bcc and

So Bcc's, good thing to know about and

00:27:27.805 --> 00:27:29.095
we do have a part three.

475
00:27:29.095 --> 00:27:32.085
We have a couple more things that
I want to address, maybe a little,

476
00:27:32.085 --> 00:27:34.495
kind of tips and tricks here and there.

477
00:27:34.495 --> 00:27:37.465
So definitely come back and
check it out one more time.

478
00:27:37.465 --> 00:27:41.400
>> All right Vonne, well that's a great
place for us to also sign off then.

479
00:27:41.400 --> 00:27:44.380
For OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

480
00:27:44.380 --> 00:27:45.340
>> And I'm Von Smith.

481
00:27:45.340 --> 00:27:49.232
>> Stayed tuned right here for
more Outlook 2016 shows.

482
00:27:49.232 --> 00:27:55.520
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look a few additional emailing features users can take advantage of to help them.  They examine two undeliverable message to show the information they provide for troubleshooting.  They also show how to add multiple attachments using a couple of different methods.  Vonne discusses the use of the deleted items folder and lastly some of the common messages that we when the email messages are missing elements.
episodes.title: Email Basics Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.912
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.912 --> 00:00:09.320
Welcome to another great episode
right here on Office Pro.Tv.

3
00:00:09.320 --> 00:00:13.653
You're watching the Office 2016 show,
I'm your host Ronnie Wong and

4
00:00:13.653 --> 00:00:17.871
today we're going into what some more
details on email and basics here.

5
00:00:17.871 --> 00:00:20.292
This is a part three,
helping us to finish up and

6
00:00:20.292 --> 00:00:23.335
wrap up all the content of this
is gonna be Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:23.335 --> 00:00:24.271
Vonne, welcome back to the studios.

8
00:00:24.271 --> 00:00:25.609
>> Hello, yes.

9
00:00:25.609 --> 00:00:27.991
>> Hello.
>> [LAUGH] Hello.

10
00:00:27.991 --> 00:00:30.578
Yes, we are on to part three
of our basic emails and

11
00:00:30.578 --> 00:00:33.365
when you think basic emails
maybe should just be one.

12
00:00:33.365 --> 00:00:37.107
But again, we're just getting a nice
foundation to establish for sending and

13
00:00:37.107 --> 00:00:38.105
