14
00:00:38.105 --> 00:00:43.986
We've gone through single recipients,
multiple recipients, the BCC.

15
00:00:43.986 --> 00:00:44.516
>> Right.

16
00:00:44.516 --> 00:00:45.450
>> Yeah, I got it right.

17
00:00:45.450 --> 00:00:46.106
[LAUGH] And

18
00:00:46.106 --> 00:00:51.530
now we're just on to just a few little
kind of tidbits I would like to call them.

19
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:54.070
So I wanna go over some attachments again.

20
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:57.110
There gonna be some things
with dragging and dropping.

21
00:00:57.110 --> 00:00:59.405
We're gonna be dragging and
dropping a lot actually.

22
00:00:59.405 --> 00:01:02.664
We're gonna talk about deleted emails and
what we need to do with that.

23
00:01:02.664 --> 00:01:06.427
And then, we're also going to
talk about undeliverables,

24
00:01:06.427 --> 00:01:11.369
which we actually had happen in the first
part which I didn't actually plan on,

25
00:01:11.369 --> 00:01:14.420
but hey,
we turned it into a teachable moment.

26
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:17.244
And so why don't we have another
teachable moment as well.

27
00:01:17.244 --> 00:01:22.530
So let's jump back down into my
inbox that I already have opened.

28
00:01:22.530 --> 00:01:27.401
And then, in the first episode, the reason
we had that undeliverable message pop

29
00:01:27.401 --> 00:01:30.588
back up was because I had
misspelled the domain name.

30
00:01:30.588 --> 00:01:33.840
We talked about the different
pieces of an email address.

31
00:01:33.840 --> 00:01:38.780
And just let's go back to that message
that we got earlier in part one.

32
00:01:38.780 --> 00:01:43.565
It was saying that Lance could not
receive my email, because the DNS,

33
00:01:43.565 --> 00:01:48.283
the Domain Naming System,
couldn't understand what was going on.

34
00:01:48.283 --> 00:01:51.090
And that's because I
misspelled was it Microsoft?

35
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:53.670
Yes I always misspell Microsoft.

36
00:01:53.670 --> 00:01:57.050
I forgot that S in there and so,
that's what the problem was.

37
00:01:57.050 --> 00:02:01.150
Well, I have another mistake,
I guess I would call it or

38
00:02:01.150 --> 00:02:05.780
a undeliverable message that came back,
and here's this one, so

39
00:02:05.780 --> 00:02:10.740
you can see that this is coming from
Office 365, so a little bit different of

40
00:02:10.740 --> 00:02:15.520
an error message than the one that I
had when I misspelled Lance's email.

41
00:02:15.520 --> 00:02:22.480
On this one it says that Vaughn,
Vaughn wasn't found on ITProTV.

42
00:02:22.480 --> 00:02:28.005
So it recognized that
the address after the at sign.

43
00:02:28.005 --> 00:02:32.860
Itpro.tv is a valid domain name,
like that's not the problem.

44
00:02:32.860 --> 00:02:35.930
The thing is that there is not a user in

45
00:02:35.930 --> 00:02:40.500
the itpro.tv domain of
Vaughn with three v's.

46
00:02:40.500 --> 00:02:44.432
So I misspelled the user name and you
can see that the error is different and

47
00:02:44.432 --> 00:02:48.501
it's also nice that it gave us little
like hey, this is how you might fix it.

48
00:02:48.501 --> 00:02:52.298
Thank you very much,
gives me some little links and

49
00:02:52.298 --> 00:02:56.373
some some feed back on what I
may be able to do with this.

50
00:02:56.373 --> 00:02:58.828
And also more info for email domains.

51
00:02:58.828 --> 00:03:01.778
That's nice it kinda gives us
a little tutorial on what it

52
00:03:01.778 --> 00:03:03.875
means to actually have an email domain.

53
00:03:03.875 --> 00:03:08.300
Now, if I scroll on down through a little
bit further, it actually gives me some

54
00:03:08.300 --> 00:03:13.054
other, if you're not really familiar with
some techie jargon, as I like to call it,

55
00:03:13.054 --> 00:03:17.170
because when you have emails,
you have things known as headers, right?

56
00:03:17.170 --> 00:03:19.690
Like, if you think about like a head,
and a body, and

57
00:03:19.690 --> 00:03:23.570
a foot, then the head is like
the beginning part of it.

58
00:03:23.570 --> 00:03:27.531
It's the header packets that get
sent through all the TCP/IP,

59
00:03:27.531 --> 00:03:32.535
all that kind of, see, I start talking
techie and I start tripping over myself.

60
00:03:32.535 --> 00:03:37.800
[LAUGH] But it's the part that comes first
and it has that basic information like

61
00:03:37.800 --> 00:03:43.004
who it's from, where it's going to,
and the stuff to kinda get it started.

62
00:03:43.004 --> 00:03:46.977
Then the meat, the middle part
comes in and then, I don't know if,

63
00:03:46.977 --> 00:03:47.963
is there a foot?

64
00:03:47.963 --> 00:03:50.692
They're not really a footer in the packet,
is there?

65
00:03:50.692 --> 00:03:52.270
>> Well, there can be.

66
00:03:52.270 --> 00:03:53.040
>> Okay, okay.

67
00:03:53.040 --> 00:03:54.499
In an e-mail, not?

68
00:03:54.499 --> 00:03:56.300
>> There can be.

69
00:03:56.300 --> 00:03:58.450
So it just depends on the message itself.

70
00:03:58.450 --> 00:04:00.930
So all we're doing is we're seeing
different parts of the email.

71
00:04:00.930 --> 00:04:04.150
This information is useful for
troubleshooting, especially in message

72
00:04:04.150 --> 00:04:08.730
like this, and these details might not be
any use to you and me as an end user, but

73
00:04:08.730 --> 00:04:12.920
to your email administrator, it's gonna
be useful information they can use to

74
00:04:12.920 --> 00:04:16.240
just really pinpoint in what
others use might be there.

75
00:04:16.240 --> 00:04:20.040
>> Yeah, so that might be where if
you keep getting undeliverables, and

76
00:04:20.040 --> 00:04:24.270
like I know this exist, this person
is here and hey I need some help.

77
00:04:24.270 --> 00:04:28.492
You could forward this message on to your
IT personnel that might be able to look at

78
00:04:28.492 --> 00:04:32.216
some of these gully goop that might
look to you they're like, no,

79
00:04:32.216 --> 00:04:34.041
I know exactly what the reason is.

80
00:04:34.041 --> 00:04:40.540
And I know a little bit of this stuff but
enough to know I don't know anything.

81
00:04:40.540 --> 00:04:45.543
But I actually have had undeliverable
messages to me before where I've looked

82
00:04:45.543 --> 00:04:50.948
through stuff and I've found something
in there, but is there a mailbox size?

83
00:04:50.948 --> 00:04:54.642
So it wasn't that it didn't exist, it's
that they had reached their capacity and

84
00:04:54.642 --> 00:04:58.095
I wasn't able to send it, or there was
something about maybe an attachment.

85
00:04:58.095 --> 00:05:00.925
So I was able to do
a little detective work

86
00:05:00.925 --> 00:05:04.945
by reading through some
of this stuff in here.

87
00:05:04.945 --> 00:05:08.783
While I don't understand all of it,
I got a little bit out of it.

88
00:05:08.783 --> 00:05:13.371
So just try it, see what you can look for
and see if there is

89
00:05:13.371 --> 00:05:18.451
an answer in this code to why you
are getting an undeliverable.

90
00:05:18.451 --> 00:05:22.649
And if it keeps on bouncing out, talk
to the person, like, call the person on

91
00:05:22.649 --> 00:05:26.680
the phone or text them if you have
some other way of contacting them.

92
00:05:26.680 --> 00:05:30.566
But try to say like, hey,
I'm not being able to get into your inbox,

93
00:05:30.566 --> 00:05:34.658
like it's just, do I have the right
address, what's wrong with this?

94
00:05:34.658 --> 00:05:39.447
I mean, there is many different feature of
steps, I would say, along the way of where

95
00:05:39.447 --> 00:05:44.120
you can have something break, might not
always be you, might not always be them.

96
00:05:44.120 --> 00:05:46.994
It could just be, as I call it,
a fauna matrix, right,

97
00:05:46.994 --> 00:05:50.683
the hamsters running in the wheels
are taking a little break right now.

98
00:05:50.683 --> 00:05:55.290
So, it happens, you can't always
figure out exactly what's wrong.

99
00:05:55.290 --> 00:05:57.960
But, isn't that just the world
of computers we live in anyways.

100
00:05:57.960 --> 00:06:02.250
So, but at least, we can at least
get some of our information

101
00:06:02.250 --> 00:06:04.510
from our undeliverable messages.

102
00:06:04.510 --> 00:06:06.270
Okay, perfect.

103
00:06:06.270 --> 00:06:08.130
So let's move on to another topic.

104
00:06:08.130 --> 00:06:13.489
So we're gonna take a turn, and
we're gonna go back to attachments

105
00:06:13.489 --> 00:06:19.611
that we had done, I believe, in part
one of our basic emailing shows, here.

106
00:06:19.611 --> 00:06:22.851
When I start a new message and
I'm ready to go ahead and

107
00:06:22.851 --> 00:06:25.800
send something, and I have an attachment.

108
00:06:25.800 --> 00:06:27.755
I don't know if you do this Ronnie, but

109
00:06:27.755 --> 00:06:30.434
I sometimes wait to the end
to put an attachment on it.

110
00:06:30.434 --> 00:06:34.595
And then guess what I do,
I send it and there's no attachment.

111
00:06:34.595 --> 00:06:38.397
And the person says, hey,
did you mean to attach that file like,

112
00:06:38.397 --> 00:06:40.346
yes, I did, let me try it again.

113
00:06:40.346 --> 00:06:44.398
It's really great when you send it out
to a really big list of people and

114
00:06:44.398 --> 00:06:49.095
you get to have everybody say that,
hmm yeah, I forgot my attachment.

115
00:06:49.095 --> 00:06:54.240
Well, the nice thing is that if
you word your email correctly,

116
00:06:54.240 --> 00:06:59.483
and what I mean by correctly,
in the eyes of Microsoft Outlook,

117
00:06:59.483 --> 00:07:05.042
Outlook will help detect, hey,
did you mean to attach a file here?

118
00:07:05.042 --> 00:07:06.342
It'll give me a warning, and

119
00:07:06.342 --> 00:07:09.130
I will tell you, that's actually
saved me quite a few times.

120
00:07:09.130 --> 00:07:12.900
So let's go ahead and
address this to Lance,

121
00:07:12.900 --> 00:07:18.061
just to kinda get something started and
I'll be like a file for

122
00:07:18.061 --> 00:07:24.731
you, and I will write in the message body,
hello, I have the report attached.

123
00:07:24.731 --> 00:07:30.250
Please check and respond or
something to that effect.

124
00:07:30.250 --> 00:07:30.870
So here we go.

125
00:07:30.870 --> 00:07:36.195
So I have written something in
the message that is kinda saying, hey,

126
00:07:36.195 --> 00:07:42.171
I've got an attachment attached,
file, I mean, there's different ways.

127
00:07:42.171 --> 00:07:44.250
And I haven't found the exact algorithm.

128
00:07:44.250 --> 00:07:47.310
But I'm pretty sure the keyword
right there is attached, or

129
00:07:47.310 --> 00:07:49.142
file is attached for you.

130
00:07:49.142 --> 00:07:51.532
There is something in there that
Microsoft won't understand.

131
00:07:51.532 --> 00:07:54.901
Now if I send this, see right there.

132
00:07:54.901 --> 00:07:59.950
There's the warning,
you may have forgotten to attach a file.

133
00:07:59.950 --> 00:08:01.934
Do you wanna send this anyways?

134
00:08:01.934 --> 00:08:04.234
Or, good, thanks Microsoft.

135
00:08:04.234 --> 00:08:05.817
Thank you for catching me.

136
00:08:05.817 --> 00:08:08.360
Let me go ahead and
get that attachment for you.

137
00:08:08.360 --> 00:08:10.900
So, this could be really, really helpful.

138
00:08:10.900 --> 00:08:15.440
Now, there is situations where maybe
you're saying the report is attached

139
00:08:15.440 --> 00:08:20.460
to your desk or attached to your door.

140
00:08:20.460 --> 00:08:21.660
So make sure you check it.

141
00:08:21.660 --> 00:08:26.647
So, we're wording it in a way that
is like it's physically somewhere,

142
00:08:26.647 --> 00:08:28.624
not attached in this email.

143
00:08:28.624 --> 00:08:33.422
So there might be times where it's like,
no, no, I'm gonna go ahead and send it

144
00:08:33.422 --> 00:08:38.434
anyway, but it's nice that it gives enough
of an intelligence, right, to get it to

145
00:08:38.434 --> 00:08:43.670
where we might have forgotten something,
so thanks for the warning there Microsoft.

146
00:08:43.670 --> 00:08:48.030
I'm gonna go ahead and send it anyways,
and then go ahead and send on.

147
00:08:48.030 --> 00:08:49.940
So, warning with your attachments.

148
00:08:51.150 --> 00:08:54.080
Other things with attachments,
we went ahead and

149
00:08:54.080 --> 00:08:58.810
showed you how you can attach
a file by creating a new message.

150
00:08:58.810 --> 00:09:02.890
Coming in to the attached file and it's
nice that it gives like the most recently

151
00:09:02.890 --> 00:09:07.200
used or the most frequently
used files in your system.

152
00:09:07.200 --> 00:09:07.810
That's great.
But

153
00:09:07.810 --> 00:09:11.730
what if I have a bunch of files
that I wanna send and they're from

154
00:09:11.730 --> 00:09:15.790
all different places and some are from
my My Documents and some are from here.

155
00:09:16.810 --> 00:09:20.310
There's other ways that you can
get attachments into your email.

156
00:09:20.310 --> 00:09:22.510
And I actually use this a lot.

157
00:09:22.510 --> 00:09:23.420
I like this method.

158
00:09:23.420 --> 00:09:28.020
So what I just did is I went back and
clicked on my main Microsoft window.

159
00:09:28.020 --> 00:09:30.470
My message window is still there.

160
00:09:30.470 --> 00:09:34.280
You can see down here in my
task bar that I've got two

161
00:09:34.280 --> 00:09:37.410
windows were opened up
in this application.

162
00:09:37.410 --> 00:09:41.120
I'm going to minimize Outlook,
and just have the message.

163
00:09:41.120 --> 00:09:44.513
Cuz I work on multiple monitors and
so I would have one over here and

164
00:09:44.513 --> 00:09:47.240
one over there and
I could kinda move things around.

165
00:09:47.240 --> 00:09:51.990
And so I have my File Explorer,
or well it is the File Explorer.

166
00:09:51.990 --> 00:09:55.407
That's what it's technically called,
Windows Explorer, whoops, sorry.

167
00:09:55.407 --> 00:09:59.172
I forgot this computer's a little slower
than my other computer that's in the shop

168
00:09:59.172 --> 00:10:03.750
right now, so I have to remember to let it
breathe a little bit like it's working.

169
00:10:03.750 --> 00:10:05.800
It's seven years old but
it's still kicking pretty good.

170
00:10:05.800 --> 00:10:10.202
So we have here my
File Explorer in this email.

171
00:10:10.202 --> 00:10:13.230
I have files in a folder called files and

172
00:10:13.230 --> 00:10:18.460
I would like to send this Word
document and this Excel file.

173
00:10:18.460 --> 00:10:21.560
Now they're right next to each other,
so I can use my Shift key or

174
00:10:21.560 --> 00:10:24.810
my Ctrl key to go ahead and
select multiple files.

175
00:10:24.810 --> 00:10:26.460
Shift would go ahead and
give you the range.

176
00:10:26.460 --> 00:10:30.290
Ctrl will be able to select files
that aren't next to each other.

177
00:10:30.290 --> 00:10:31.780
So, select all the files that I want.

178
00:10:31.780 --> 00:10:34.860
If I want those to be
attachments into this message,

179
00:10:34.860 --> 00:10:36.080
all I gotta do is drag and drop.

180
00:10:36.080 --> 00:10:39.250
Now the thing is, you gotta be
careful where you drop it into.

181
00:10:39.250 --> 00:10:44.080
So if you drag it, I actually see,
if I come down here, my mouse turns to

182
00:10:44.080 --> 00:10:47.850
a white arrow with a box over it,
as opposed to here, with a no sign.

183
00:10:47.850 --> 00:10:51.570
So you do need to drop it
into the message body, but

184
00:10:51.570 --> 00:10:53.660
you're not actually putting
it into the message body,

185
00:10:53.660 --> 00:10:58.640
watch what happens when I let go,
it just adds itself as an attachment, fun!

186
00:10:58.640 --> 00:11:00.580
>> Nice.
>> Yeah, I love the drag and drop method,

187
00:11:00.580 --> 00:11:01.730
because there's a lot of times,

188
00:11:01.730 --> 00:11:04.710
if I'm sending multiple files
>> Why don't I do it this way?

189
00:11:04.710 --> 00:11:08.030
Because then I can come back out
into here, take my pictures.

190
00:11:08.030 --> 00:11:10.300
Let's say I wanna send all of these files.

191
00:11:10.300 --> 00:11:14.420
I'm gonna click on one,
do a Ctrl+A for select all.

192
00:11:14.420 --> 00:11:17.420
And I can then just drag and
drop those right into there.

193
00:11:17.420 --> 00:11:19.320
Make sure I get it into it.

194
00:11:19.320 --> 00:11:20.580
>> And then there we go.

195
00:11:20.580 --> 00:11:21.970
Perfect.
I can just drag and

196
00:11:21.970 --> 00:11:25.930
drop my attachments right into my composed
message, or if it's a reply message, so

197
00:11:25.930 --> 00:11:27.480
it doesn't always have
to be a new message.

198
00:11:27.480 --> 00:11:29.690
It's just anytime you are writing or

199
00:11:29.690 --> 00:11:34.130
composing a message that you want files
attached, just drag those guys in there,

200
00:11:34.130 --> 00:11:36.800
and then you could go ahead and
send it on your merry way.

201
00:11:37.940 --> 00:11:42.810
I'm gonna go ahead and
just name this files, For you.

202
00:11:42.810 --> 00:11:48.790
I think I already said that a couple of
times but we'll just say files, that's it.

203
00:11:48.790 --> 00:11:52.023
I'm not gonna do anything else with
this just so I can see if I can

204
00:11:52.023 --> 00:11:55.870
show you those auto save features,
this is gonna go in your drafts folder.

205
00:11:55.870 --> 00:11:59.900
Well you have to wait a little bit, so
I'm just gonna go ahead and minimize this.

206
00:11:59.900 --> 00:12:05.700
And then we are going to bring back up
our Outlook and then move on from there.

207
00:12:05.700 --> 00:12:09.286
Multiple attachments,
now that was a way I could go ahead and

208
00:12:09.286 --> 00:12:12.462
add multiple attachments by dragging and
dropping.

phishing tactics that the bad guys,

432
00:24:35.480 --> 00:24:38.840
excuse me, are out there to try to
phish out information from you.

433
00:24:38.840 --> 00:24:41.700
And try to get you to connect,
in a sense, for

434
00:24:41.700 --> 00:24:43.490
them to be able to take their information.

435
00:24:43.490 --> 00:24:45.520
Won't go into major details on that.

436
00:24:45.520 --> 00:24:47.457
We actually do have some security shows,

437
00:24:47.457 --> 00:24:49.290
too, that you might want
to be able to watch on.

438
00:24:49.290 --> 00:24:53.440
And user security, of how to keep yourself
safe in here, and this is one of them.

439
00:24:53.440 --> 00:24:57.510
But what is happening in this
particular email is that this company,

440
00:24:57.510 --> 00:24:59.030
which is Microsoft.

441
00:24:59.030 --> 00:25:03.590
There's pictures that is
in the body of this email,

442
00:25:03.590 --> 00:25:06.780
which is in an HTML format,
which is HyperText Markup Language.

443
00:25:06.780 --> 00:25:11.100
We'll talk a little bit more about email
formats in our next episodes coming up.

444
00:25:11.100 --> 00:25:16.080
But this is written to where there's
information in here that has pictures,

445
00:25:16.080 --> 00:25:18.920
that they're not embedded in the email.

446
00:25:18.920 --> 00:25:21.870
We're going to talk about inserting
images into an email, and

447
00:25:21.870 --> 00:25:25.000
then sending it off to
somebody by Insert Picture.

448
00:25:25.000 --> 00:25:29.123
That's different, the picture
lives in the body of the email.

449
00:25:29.123 --> 00:25:33.747
In this sense, the pictures live outside,
if you want to say.

450
00:25:33.747 --> 00:25:36.360
They live on a website,
they live on a web address.

451
00:25:36.360 --> 00:25:41.490
And there's a link, they're linked images,
they're not embedded images.

452
00:25:41.490 --> 00:25:44.448
Well the thing is here, the reason why
it's giving me this warning is because

453
00:25:44.448 --> 00:25:46.560
they are outsider-linked to a website.

454
00:25:46.560 --> 00:25:49.350
That means that you need
to make a connection,

455
00:25:49.350 --> 00:25:51.660
to be able to retrieve those messages.

456
00:25:51.660 --> 00:25:54.690
Or sorry, not message,
the images within this message.

457
00:25:54.690 --> 00:25:56.230
So you're establishing a connection,

458
00:25:56.230 --> 00:25:59.350
you can see right there with
that whole phishing scheme.

459
00:25:59.350 --> 00:26:02.750
You've established a connection, it could
be to a website that is there to collect

460
00:26:02.750 --> 00:26:04.660
information without you even knowing it.

461
00:26:04.660 --> 00:26:07.320
So that's where you need to be
a little careful about that.

462
00:26:07.320 --> 00:26:10.830
But I wanted to give you
a little background as to how

463
00:26:10.830 --> 00:26:15.250
a message like this is built, and
why it's giving me this warning.

464
00:26:15.250 --> 00:26:18.220
It's saying,
you want to download the pictures

465
00:26:18.220 --> 00:26:22.760
from a site to this particular
message onto your computer.

466
00:26:22.760 --> 00:26:24.930
Do you want me to do this?

467
00:26:24.930 --> 00:26:28.360
Now, this is from Microsoft,
and I know it's from Microsoft.

468
00:26:28.360 --> 00:26:31.316
So if I click on it, yes,
I would like to go ahead and do this.

469
00:26:31.316 --> 00:26:35.918
And this is also where we start getting
into our Safe Senders list, and

470
00:26:35.918 --> 00:26:38.882
this will be tied into our junk mail and
spam.

471
00:26:38.882 --> 00:26:43.849
About, do you always want to accept
pictures from this particular domain, or

472
00:26:43.849 --> 00:26:45.215
add to Safe Senders?

473
00:26:45.215 --> 00:26:47.771
But again,
more on that in another episode.

474
00:26:47.771 --> 00:26:49.943
But right here,
let's just go ahead and say, yep.

475
00:26:49.943 --> 00:26:53.450
Let's go ahead and download these
pictures for this particular email.

476
00:26:53.450 --> 00:26:59.120
I wouldn't start changing the settings to
download from any email that comes in.

477
00:26:59.120 --> 00:27:01.780
Because that's where you wanna
kinda keep yourself safe.

478
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:04.950
Tell me as I need, and
then I can say, there it is.

479
00:27:04.950 --> 00:27:08.430
Download the logo from
this particular web site.

480
00:27:08.430 --> 00:27:11.550
And I think the other one's another logo,
yep, there's the Microsoft logo.

481
00:27:11.550 --> 00:27:15.740
So just wanted to point that out, and
to give you a little background on it.

482
00:27:15.740 --> 00:27:19.877
And now I think I have covered
everything that I wanted to,

483
00:27:19.877 --> 00:27:22.421
in this part three of email basics.

484
00:27:22.421 --> 00:27:23.719
All right, Vonne, well,

485
00:27:23.719 --> 00:27:26.717
thank you again for helping us
to round out our knowledge here.

486
00:27:26.717 --> 00:27:31.580
On some of the basic emailing features
that are gonna be available in Outlook.

487
00:27:31.580 --> 00:27:35.740
Remember that in this episode, we did talk
about some of the undeliverable messages,

488
00:27:35.740 --> 00:27:37.690
and the information
that it shows us there.

489
00:27:37.690 --> 00:27:40.469
We also, of course,
took a look at attachments.

490
00:27:40.469 --> 00:27:44.024
When you have multiple attachments, and
what we do with multiple attachments.

491
00:27:44.024 --> 00:27:47.850
Not only sending them, how to send them,
we can click and drop and drag.

492
00:27:47.850 --> 00:27:49.550
And of course, even receiving them,

493
00:27:49.550 --> 00:27:53.150
how do we get all of those different
images back on to our computer?

494
00:27:53.150 --> 00:27:55.521
And lastly here, different deleted emails.

495
00:27:55.521 --> 00:28:00.266
And then Vonne also showed us some of the
differences with the images that also come

496
00:28:00.266 --> 00:28:01.453
in on emails, too.

497
00:28:01.453 --> 00:28:04.861
Something we have pay attention to and
be aware of.

498
00:28:04.861 --> 00:28:07.997
But that is a great place for
us to also end this show, then.

499
00:28:07.997 --> 00:28:12.615
Signing off for OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Long.

500
00:28:12.615 --> 00:28:13.326
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

501
00:28:13.326 --> 00:28:18.564
>> Stay tuned right here, for

502
00:28:18.564 --> 00:28:24.492
more Outlook 2016 shows.

503
00:28:24.492 --> 00:28:25.950
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne show some different ways to format the messages that we send out from Outlook 2016.  Vonne takes the time to differentiate character and paragraph level formatting.  She continues by showing some of the built in “auto” features that Outlook automatically does to help your email composition remains professional (AutoCorrect, AutoFormat, Spelling and Grammar Checking).
episodes.title: Format Message Body
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:06.180 --> 00:00:08.750
Welcome to another great episode
right here on OfficeProTV.

2
00:00:08.750 --> 00:00:12.150
You're watching the Outlook 2016 show.

3
00:00:12.150 --> 00:00:13.540
I'm your host, Ronnie Wong.

4
00:00:13.540 --> 00:00:18.460
And today, we're gonna be taking a look
at formatting our email messages and

5
00:00:18.460 --> 00:00:19.660
what we can do with that.

6
00:00:19.660 --> 00:00:23.030
And here to help us to see some of
those details is Miss Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:23.030 --> 00:00:24.360
Vonne, welcome back to the studios.

8
00:00:24.360 --> 00:00:25.530
>> Hello Ronnie, good to see you.

9
00:00:25.530 --> 00:00:26.670
>> Goo to see you, too.

10
00:00:26.670 --> 00:00:27.370
>> Thank you.

11
00:00:27.370 --> 00:00:31.490
So yes, we're gonna be formatting
the message body of our email.

12
00:00:31.490 --> 00:00:35.330
Now, a lot of the things that we're
gonna be going over in this episode, and

13
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:36.940
I'm assuming we're gonna go to a part two.

14
00:00:36.940 --> 00:00:39.870
Because I do have a lot to
talk about here, of it.

15
00:00:39.870 --> 00:00:43.860
These are going to be things
that I'm gonna go kind of fast.

16
00:00:43.860 --> 00:00:45.910
I'm just going to identify where they are,

17
00:00:45.910 --> 00:00:49.440
give you a quick example of what
that particular formatting does.

18
00:00:49.440 --> 00:00:53.449
And then we're gonna move on
because everything that we're doing

19
00:00:53.449 --> 00:00:56.320
here in the message body
is really part of Word.

20
00:00:56.320 --> 00:01:00.140
Cuz we talked about in some
previous episodes are referring to

21
00:01:00.140 --> 00:01:04.275
Word being like the default
editor of your Outlook messages.

22
00:01:04.275 --> 00:01:07.755
And well its not really
Word inside of Outlook,

23
00:01:07.755 --> 00:01:10.450
its It's really all the same features.

24
00:01:10.450 --> 00:01:13.160
And there's an extensive
amount of features and

25
00:01:13.160 --> 00:01:16.830
options within the composing
part of your message.

26
00:01:16.830 --> 00:01:18.420
So I'm going to point some of those out.

27
00:01:18.420 --> 00:01:22.340
But you can really dive deep into some of
these things, and really customize it.

28
00:01:22.340 --> 00:01:25.050
Just like we've come to find out
in all of our other episodes of

29
00:01:25.050 --> 00:01:28.290
we have a lot of customizations
we can be doing in Outlook.

30
00:01:28.290 --> 00:01:33.010
So if you want a little bit more in depth
on things like paragraph formatting and

31
00:01:33.010 --> 00:01:36.920
the space after paragraph and the styles
and how we can use styles and themes.

32
00:01:36.920 --> 00:01:42.400
Are we using some terminology that we're
going to be going into this episode?

33
00:01:42.400 --> 00:01:45.880
We do have an entire series on Word so
you can go ahead and

34
00:01:45.880 --> 00:01:51.141
take a little bit of more time to
get through some of these concepts.

35
00:01:51.141 --> 00:01:55.100
>> All right Vonne, I remember
when I first started using email.

36
00:01:55.100 --> 00:01:59.070
There was really none of this
formatting in terms of email messages.

37
00:01:59.070 --> 00:02:01.560
It was simply typing on the screen and
just pressing send.

38
00:02:01.560 --> 00:02:03.480
And that was pretty much it.

39
00:02:03.480 --> 00:02:06.295
So where are we going to begin when
we start taking a look at formatting

40
00:02:06.295 --> 00:02:06.932
our messages?

41
00:02:06.932 --> 00:02:10.195
>> That is the most perfect
place to start, I think.

42
00:02:10.195 --> 00:02:14.280
Because we really need to talk about not
just the things that we can do in Outlook.

43
00:02:14.280 --> 00:02:19.090
To begin with, we need to talk about
the difference between HTML formatting,

44
00:02:19.090 --> 00:02:22.130
rich text formatting, and
plain text formatting.

45
00:02:22.130 --> 00:02:24.180
So, while we gonna go and
get in to the computer so

46
00:02:24.180 --> 00:02:26.610
we have just some type of video reference

47
00:02:26.610 --> 00:02:29.850
to guide us along as we start talking
about some of these concepts.

48
00:02:29.850 --> 00:02:32.420
Just to let you know where I am at,
I'm in my drafts folder.

49
00:02:32.420 --> 00:02:36.630
Because I went ahead and got a message
already created with a bunch of text so

50
00:02:36.630 --> 00:02:38.690
I have something in here
to start formatting.

51
00:02:38.690 --> 00:02:42.610
Because you don't really want to see me
try to type out a really long passage

52
00:02:42.610 --> 00:02:43.510
of text in here.

53
00:02:43.510 --> 00:02:47.840
So I took some placeholder texts, there
are a lot of texts I've been using in my

54
00:02:47.840 --> 00:02:50.100
episodes to go ahead and get us started.

55
00:02:50.100 --> 00:02:52.080
So let me go ahead and
open up that message and

56
00:02:52.080 --> 00:02:54.950
now I'm in the actual message window.

57
00:02:54.950 --> 00:02:58.100
And into the tabs along our ribbon
that we are going to be able to

58
00:02:58.100 --> 00:02:59.870
use to format everything.

59
00:02:59.870 --> 00:03:00.630
So where is that,

60
00:03:00.630 --> 00:03:06.860
at the very beginning what format am I
actually using to create my message?

61
00:03:06.860 --> 00:03:09.891
I'm gonna jump over here
to the Options tab.

62
00:03:09.891 --> 00:03:13.980
Now, that's actually not the right one,
that's the Format text [LAUGH].

63
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:17.236
The next tab over the Format text tab.

64
00:03:17.236 --> 00:03:20.845
And a lot of the same things you see on
the Format text you will see a little bit

65
00:03:20.845 --> 00:03:21.666
on the message.

66
00:03:21.666 --> 00:03:25.320
So just you know, there's two different
places where I can choose like fonts, and

67
00:03:25.320 --> 00:03:27.570
bold, and italic, and things like that.

68
00:03:27.570 --> 00:03:29.370
Right now, everything's grayed out.

69
00:03:29.370 --> 00:03:32.440
The reason is, is cuz I'm not actually
clicked into the Message body.

70
00:03:32.440 --> 00:03:33.710
I'm in the To field.

71
00:03:33.710 --> 00:03:35.650
You can't really format the To field.

72
00:03:35.650 --> 00:03:37.300
It's just, that's straight text.

73
00:03:37.300 --> 00:03:39.220
So let me click on down
here to go ahead and

74
00:03:39.220 --> 00:03:42.300
activate the different options
we have on our Ribbon.

75
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:47.340
So right over here on the left hand
side we can see that we have HTML,

76
00:03:47.340 --> 00:03:51.800
Plain Text, and Rich Text, so
what's the difference between these?

77
00:03:51.800 --> 00:03:52.617
We'll start with plain text.

78
00:03:52.617 --> 00:03:57.427
Even if it's in the middle as your choice,
I feel actually the bottom that's just in

79
00:03:57.427 --> 00:04:00.580
me like a hierarchy,
like what the formatting can do.

80
00:04:00.580 --> 00:04:04.940
Well, plain text is almost exactly
like what it says, it's plain text.

81
00:04:04.940 --> 00:04:09.290
It can only support things
like your characters, numbers,

82
00:04:09.290 --> 00:04:12.750
alphanumerical characters and that's it.

83
00:04:12.750 --> 00:04:16.490
You can't make it a different font,
you can't make it a different size,

84
00:04:16.490 --> 00:04:20.810
it's just text,
no extra formatting on there.

85
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:25.024
Rich text formatting is just
taking plain text one step up.

86
00:04:25.024 --> 00:04:29.860
Where you can do some of your formattings,
like some fonts, and some colors.

87
00:04:29.860 --> 00:04:33.880
I believe you can do some spacing,
not spacing but a bold.

88
00:04:33.880 --> 00:04:37.350
I know bold and italic, and
those are all character level formattings.

89
00:04:37.350 --> 00:04:39.040
I think you can do centered.

90
00:04:39.040 --> 00:04:40.214
And bullets possibly?

91
00:04:40.214 --> 00:04:41.213
You know what?

92
00:04:41.213 --> 00:04:41.945
We could check that out.

93
00:04:41.945 --> 00:04:43.036
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

94
00:04:43.036 --> 00:04:45.747
>> But what I'm trying to say is it's this

95
00:04:45.747 --> 00:04:47.810
one level up from plain text.

96
00:04:47.810 --> 00:04:51.870
So, there will be some formatting
that you will be able to

97
00:04:51.870 --> 00:04:55.390
do in your formatting because
Rich text will allow you.

98
00:04:55.390 --> 00:04:58.430
Then the highest level is HTML formatting.

99
00:04:58.430 --> 00:05:01.460
And HTML stands for
HyperText Markup Language.

100
00:05:01.460 --> 00:05:04.960
And it's using a series of tags and
codes to be able to format your message.

101
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:06.810
You don't have to know
anything about HTML.

102
00:05:06.810 --> 00:05:08.680
You don't even have to know what's a tag.

103
00:05:08.680 --> 00:05:10.590
What?
Don't worry about that.

104
00:05:10.590 --> 00:05:15.100
It's really just the most
extensive type of formatting

105
00:05:15.100 --> 00:05:19.190
that you are allowed to do
when composing a message.

106
00:05:19.190 --> 00:05:24.950
And that's the default mode
that your email editor or

107
00:05:24.950 --> 00:05:28.310
composing your messages
are going to be in.

108
00:05:28.310 --> 00:05:29.780
And so
that's the one that we're going to do.

109
00:05:29.780 --> 00:05:31.010
Now, why does this make a difference?

110
00:05:31.010 --> 00:05:31.630
You're like, well,

111
00:05:31.630 --> 00:05:35.230
I should always use HTML, because that
gives me everything that I want to do.

112
00:05:35.230 --> 00:05:39.150
Well, you have to remember that we're
not the only people using Outlook.

113
00:05:39.150 --> 00:05:41.220
And there's other people that use Outlook,
but

114
00:05:41.220 --> 00:05:45.620
there are a bunch of other type
of mail servers that you can use.

115
00:05:45.620 --> 00:05:49.888
I mean, there's Gmail, there's Yahoo,
there's old versions of thing,

116
00:05:49.888 --> 00:05:53.440
I mean there's all sorts of
different levels of mail servers.

117
00:05:53.440 --> 00:05:59.130
And what those servers are configured
to allow your messages to be.

118
00:05:59.130 --> 00:06:00.430
And I say, it's a big difference.

119
00:06:00.430 --> 00:06:02.068
So I can go ahead,
I have always capabilities.

120
00:06:02.068 --> 00:06:06.746
But I might be sending somebody with an
email that they've actually configured it

121
00:06:06.746 --> 00:06:09.810
to where they won't allow
any HTML to come into them.

122
00:06:09.810 --> 00:06:14.270
They only want plain text because of
maybe they have slow connections.

123
00:06:14.270 --> 00:06:18.730
I mean, there's a whole myriad of reasons
why people want to use plain text.

124
00:06:18.730 --> 00:06:20.920
Also security reasons, right?

125
00:06:20.920 --> 00:06:24.420
Because if it was plain text,
there's not any links of the emails.

126
00:06:24.420 --> 00:06:28.440
We talked about downloading the pictures
that could be some issues with

127
00:06:28.440 --> 00:06:30.260
the security.

128
00:06:30.260 --> 00:06:32.354
So, it's not just you
you have to think about.

129
00:06:32.354 --> 00:06:36.361
You have to think of the recipient,
the person on the other end, and

130
00:06:36.361 --> 00:06:38.345
what they could or could not see.

131
00:06:38.345 --> 00:06:43.610
And you kind of have to make that
decision as to which one you want to do.

132
00:06:43.610 --> 00:06:46.340
>> Vonne,
I think that that makes a very good point.

133
00:06:46.340 --> 00:06:49.920
Normally, I won't say best practice,
but the protocol or

134
00:06:49.920 --> 00:06:51.920
the etiquette behind this is simple.

135
00:06:51.920 --> 00:06:56.440
If you get an email message and
it's in plain text, usually what you

136
00:06:56.440 --> 00:06:59.750
want to respond with is a plain text
email, is what it comes down to.

137
00:06:59.750 --> 00:07:03.870
If you get one in rich text,
usually it's trying to do the same thing.

138
00:07:03.870 --> 00:07:08.640
So that way, on their end, if there is
a limitation like Vonne was explaining,

139
00:07:08.640 --> 00:07:09.470
that you're not trapped.

140
00:07:09.470 --> 00:07:13.250
Because you sent something in a higher
format than what their email server

141
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:14.640
is going to handle.

142
00:07:14.640 --> 00:07:18.180
So that's at least what we would call that
protocol or that etiquette to be able

143
00:07:18.180 --> 00:07:20.920
to do that is that you want to
send it in the same manner.

144
00:07:20.920 --> 00:07:24.739
You may even get unusual messages
that return back to you that says,

145
00:07:24.739 --> 00:07:29.568
your email was rejected because we don't
take anything but plain text, sometimes.

146
00:07:29.568 --> 00:07:32.478
And I've seen a couple of
companies like that before.

147
00:07:32.478 --> 00:07:36.089
But that's just kind of a nice
little basic way if you're going,

148
00:07:36.089 --> 00:07:38.133
when should I choose which one to do.

149
00:07:38.133 --> 00:07:41.779
Well, if you get it that way,
send it back in that particular format.

150
00:07:41.779 --> 00:07:43.659
And that probably helps
them out at the same time.

151
00:07:43.659 --> 00:07:45.720
>> Yeah, that's a really great point.

152
00:07:45.720 --> 00:07:48.790
It's, don't do something that they can't.

sometimes when you keep the local formats,

I know, since I know styles,

When I start doing style overrides

it stays within that formatting.

So maybe you've encountered and

[LAUGH] When you hit enter,

[COUGH] it goes ahead and

So, style a name group of formatting that

00:31:46.928 --> 00:31:51.783

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne continue with some additional formatting options available in Outlook 2016.  Vonne shows additional elements likes tables, smarter, shapes, picture and even screenshots.  She continues to demonstrate some of the additional copy and paste options.  The team also shows some additional legacy elements like stationary.  Lastly, she demonstrates the results of changing the format from HTML to Plain Text.
episodes.title: Format Message Body Part 2

478
00:27:51.508 --> 00:27:57.386
You can come in to the theme,
you could choose your capsules.

479
00:27:57.386 --> 00:28:01.307
Deep blue.

480
00:28:01.307 --> 00:28:04.245
I don't know, it looks dated to me.

481
00:28:04.245 --> 00:28:05.603
These have been around for a long time.

482
00:28:05.603 --> 00:28:06.467
>> They have.

483
00:28:06.467 --> 00:28:07.014
>> Yes, and

484
00:28:07.014 --> 00:28:10.859
the one that looks like a piece of
paper where the spirals are on it.

485
00:28:10.859 --> 00:28:16.258
I've gotten emails from people with,
they tell me like, you found the themes.

486
00:28:16.258 --> 00:28:19.037
[LAUGH] You found the themes and
the stationery and

487
00:28:19.037 --> 00:28:20.877
you're very excited about it.

488
00:28:20.877 --> 00:28:24.089
What's the difference between ones
that have the word stationery?

489
00:28:24.089 --> 00:28:26.257
It's just the background.

490
00:28:26.257 --> 00:28:29.983
My computer's slowing
down just a little bit.

491
00:28:29.983 --> 00:28:31.620
>> Nice.

492
00:28:31.620 --> 00:28:37.632
>> [LAUGH] So you can see that it's
choosing the background for every mail.

493
00:28:37.632 --> 00:28:39.784
I'm gonna click okay.

494
00:28:39.784 --> 00:28:41.719
That's kind of scary, click okay.

495
00:28:41.719 --> 00:28:45.513
Go over to New Mail.

496
00:28:45.513 --> 00:28:50.521
Yeah [LAUGH] so
this going to become the background fill.

497
00:28:50.521 --> 00:28:55.541
And the stationery is just a picture.

498
00:28:55.541 --> 00:28:58.849
The theme is where it will
format your font, your colors,

499
00:28:58.849 --> 00:29:01.761
your styles that you're using for
your headings.

500
00:29:01.761 --> 00:29:03.498
And it can do that.

501
00:29:03.498 --> 00:29:10.292
Not saying that they're bad,
I just don't think it's very new.

502
00:29:10.292 --> 00:29:16.071
The other thing is how it comes
over to non-Outlook users.

503
00:29:16.071 --> 00:29:21.129
Let's go over to Chris's email
cuz I have some examples.

504
00:29:21.129 --> 00:29:23.424
The handprint theme.

505
00:29:23.424 --> 00:29:26.015
It actually looks like handprints.

506
00:29:26.015 --> 00:29:32.091
Let me come over to my Sent items so
you could see here.

507
00:29:32.091 --> 00:29:33.233
Nope, this one.

508
00:29:33.233 --> 00:29:34.846
There we go.

509
00:29:34.846 --> 00:29:35.826
Looks like handprints.

510
00:29:35.826 --> 00:29:36.859
>> Mm-hm.

511
00:29:36.859 --> 00:29:39.410
>> I see it with the background.

512
00:29:39.410 --> 00:29:44.825
Chris sees it with this weird EMZ file.

513
00:29:44.825 --> 00:29:46.536
I actually had to look this up, Ronnie.

514
00:29:46.536 --> 00:29:47.983
[LAUGH]
>> Okay.

515
00:29:47.983 --> 00:29:51.288
>> It is
a Windows Compressed Enhanced Metafile.

516
00:29:51.288 --> 00:29:52.827
>> Okay.

517
00:29:52.827 --> 00:29:54.922
>> So it's very Windows specific.

518
00:29:54.922 --> 00:29:58.484
If I looked at that,
I would think that this was some type,

519
00:29:58.484 --> 00:30:00.538
I would be suspicious with this.

520
00:30:00.538 --> 00:30:01.285
>> Right.

521
00:30:01.285 --> 00:30:02.907
>> I'm not clicking on that EMZ file.

522
00:30:02.907 --> 00:30:04.154
I have no idea what that is.

523
00:30:04.154 --> 00:30:05.803
And why are you sending me this?

524
00:30:05.803 --> 00:30:08.926
Oop, Vonne got hacked,
something's going wrong.

525
00:30:08.926 --> 00:30:15.735
So I might stay away from using
themes and/or stationery.

526
00:30:15.735 --> 00:30:17.230
This is a theme example.

527
00:30:17.230 --> 00:30:18.815
It didn't show the background.

528
00:30:18.815 --> 00:30:25.212
This is actually some brown
in the background, yeah.

529
00:30:25.212 --> 00:30:27.438
It's kind of like a textured paper.

530
00:30:27.438 --> 00:30:28.030
It didn't show up.

531
00:30:28.030 --> 00:30:32.098
It didn't give me an EMZ file,
but it didn't come across.

532
00:30:32.098 --> 00:30:35.219
So just because it's there-
>> Doesn't mean you have to use it.

533
00:30:35.219 --> 00:30:37.618
>> Doesn't mean you have to use it.

534
00:30:37.618 --> 00:30:42.061
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I would probably suggest, don't.

535
00:30:42.061 --> 00:30:43.562
I know we're at the end,
I know we're really close but

536
00:30:43.562 --> 00:30:44.945
I have just one last thing to cover here,
Ronnie.

537
00:30:44.945 --> 00:30:46.997
>> Sure thing.

538
00:30:46.997 --> 00:30:51.043
>> Because we started off
the full formatting message

539
00:30:51.043 --> 00:30:55.945
body episodes with HTML, or
Rich Text format and plaintext.

540
00:30:55.945 --> 00:31:01.151
I wanted to show you if you convert it,
what happens?

541
00:31:01.151 --> 00:31:03.675
What is supported, what is not supported?

542
00:31:03.675 --> 00:31:08.667
We were doing a lot of formatting here.

543
00:31:08.667 --> 00:31:10.169
That was the cut, copy and paste.

544
00:31:10.169 --> 00:31:12.790
Let's come back over here.

545
00:31:12.790 --> 00:31:14.221
There we go.

546
00:31:14.221 --> 00:31:16.662
All of our texts, fancy stuff.

547
00:31:16.662 --> 00:31:17.632
>> Right.

548
00:31:17.632 --> 00:31:21.080
>> If I come over to my Format Tab-
>> [LAUGH]

549
00:31:21.080 --> 00:31:23.280
>> [LAUGH] Format Text, and

550
00:31:23.280 --> 00:31:26.692
I choose this to go down to Rich Text.

551
00:31:26.692 --> 00:31:29.244
Notice it's going to give me a warning.

552
00:31:29.244 --> 00:31:32.563
Hey guess what, shapes aren't supported,

553
00:31:32.563 --> 00:31:37.728
effects on text are gonna be removed,
are you sure you want to do this?

554
00:31:37.728 --> 00:31:42.037
If I click continue,
all of that kind of comes down, but

555
00:31:42.037 --> 00:31:45.904
then this is still here,
they're pictures now.

556
00:31:45.904 --> 00:31:48.295
It's thinks it's,
well It's still saying it's smart are.

557
00:31:48.295 --> 00:31:52.048
Okay, let's go one more level, okay?

558
00:31:52.048 --> 00:31:54.705
[LAUGH] Let's go to plaintext.

559
00:31:54.705 --> 00:31:55.371
There we go.

560
00:31:55.371 --> 00:31:56.599
Now pictures will be lost.

561
00:31:56.599 --> 00:31:57.386
Tables will be lost.

562
00:31:57.386 --> 00:31:59.236
Formatted, click Continue.

563
00:31:59.236 --> 00:32:00.534
There, that's the [LAUGH].

564
00:32:00.534 --> 00:32:01.854
That's all I get, okay?

565
00:32:01.854 --> 00:32:05.467
Cuz I believe Rich Text
has expanded its features.

566
00:32:05.467 --> 00:32:08.266
I notice it in my notes on my Mac.

567
00:32:08.266 --> 00:32:12.018
You can do a lot of things in there
that I didn't think you could.

568
00:32:12.018 --> 00:32:14.168
So I think that's why we went to.

569
00:32:14.168 --> 00:32:14.779
>> That's changed over time.

570
00:32:14.779 --> 00:32:18.372
>> Yeah, that's why we went to Rich Text,
a lot of the stuff kinda stayed with it.

571
00:32:18.372 --> 00:32:22.870
So this could be if you're
getting an email in HTML format.

572
00:32:22.870 --> 00:32:27.767
You're responding and you change it to
plain text, that's where it could be lost.

573
00:32:27.767 --> 00:32:32.606
But I at least wanted to close on that
of if you start it and convert it,

574
00:32:32.606 --> 00:32:37.530
you're not gonna be able to convert
it back to HTML because everything

575
00:32:37.530 --> 00:32:40.878
gets stripped out and
you will have plaintext.

576
00:32:40.878 --> 00:32:44.383
Which might be something good that you
need to do in case someone's like,

577
00:32:44.383 --> 00:32:45.576
I can't see your email.

578
00:32:45.576 --> 00:32:49.806
Go back to your Sent, Forward it,
strip out all the text formatting,

579
00:32:49.806 --> 00:32:51.895
put it to plaintext and send it on.

580
00:32:51.895 --> 00:32:54.234
They might not get much but, [LAUGH]
>> No, I understand.

581
00:32:54.234 --> 00:32:56.740
All right, Vonne, well thank you again for

582
00:32:56.740 --> 00:33:01.480
helping us out in seeing some of the other
ways that we can use the formatting that's

583
00:33:01.480 --> 00:33:05.566
available to us to change the way that
our message body ends up looking.

584
00:33:05.566 --> 00:33:09.142
We did talked about some of the other
things we can insert into the email

585
00:33:09.142 --> 00:33:10.299
message body itself.

586
00:33:10.299 --> 00:33:14.208
As well as address the different
options with cut, copy and

587
00:33:14.208 --> 00:33:18.366
pasting that we can also see and
then themes and stationeries.

588
00:33:18.366 --> 00:33:20.838
Remember, just because it's there,
it doesn't mean you have to use it.

589
00:33:20.838 --> 00:33:24.469
And, of course, lastly,
if you do convert from HTML to plaintext,

590
00:33:24.469 --> 00:33:27.803
realize you are probably going
to lose just about everything.

591
00:33:27.803 --> 00:33:31.575
But there are still some systems out
there that they only accept plaintext for

592
00:33:31.575 --> 00:33:32.165
the email.

593
00:33:32.165 --> 00:33:36.489
So make sure you address the content
if you do have something like that that

594
00:33:36.489 --> 00:33:37.057
goes on.

595
00:33:37.057 --> 00:33:41.077
So that's a great place for
us to also sign off then.

596
00:33:41.077 --> 00:33:44.352
For Office Pro TV,
I've been your host Ronnie Wong.

597
00:33:44.352 --> 00:33:45.408
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

598
00:33:45.408 --> 00:33:48.586
>> Stay tuned right here for
Outlook 2016 shows.

599
00:33:48.586 --> 00:33:58.586
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne begin looking at advanced email features found in Outlook 2016. Here they look over advanced features specific to the sender. You'll see options like Importance, Security, Delivery and Read Receipts, and Voting buttons.
episodes.title: Advanced Email Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.139 --> 00:00:05.506
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.506 --> 00:00:10.061
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:10.061 --> 00:00:13.543
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and today's episode, well,

4
00:00:13.543 --> 00:00:17.140
we're coming back with more
on our Outlook 2016 series.

5
00:00:17.140 --> 00:00:20.848
And joining us in the studio today,
our good friend, Ms. Vonne Smith.

6
00:00:20.848 --> 00:00:22.712
Vonne, welcome back, we're glad to
have you again, how's it going?

7
00:00:22.712 --> 00:00:26.970
>> Good, I'm glad to be here,
to talk about our advanced email features.

8
00:00:26.970 --> 00:00:27.886
>> Ooh.
>> Yeah, so

9
00:00:27.886 --> 00:00:31.550
we're going to be going into all
the different options that you can add

10
00:00:31.550 --> 00:00:34.547
to your message,
when you send the message to somebody.

11
00:00:34.547 --> 00:00:38.060
And then we're gonna go ahead, and
take a look at what it's like to be on

12
00:00:38.060 --> 00:00:40.887
the receiving end of those
messages with those options.

13
00:00:40.887 --> 00:00:45.692
And then we'll cover some recalling
messages and the @mention,

14
00:00:45.692 --> 00:00:49.049
which is a newer feature of Office,
Outlook.

15
00:00:49.049 --> 00:00:50.599
>> [LAUGH]
>> Outlook in Office.

16
00:00:50.599 --> 00:00:52.855
>> I know-
>> Which is an Office product, right?

17
00:00:52.855 --> 00:00:55.115
>> We've been mix-and-matching
those words the whole time.

18
00:00:55.115 --> 00:00:58.131
And so, yeah, we're just gonna
keep on keeping on with that one.

19
00:00:58.131 --> 00:00:58.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right,

20
00:00:58.750 --> 00:00:59.515
just bear with us, ladies and gentlemen.

21
00:00:59.515 --> 00:01:00.035
>> Yeah.

22
00:01:00.035 --> 00:01:02.664
>> [LAUGH]
>> When you have two products that start

23
00:01:02.664 --> 00:01:06.490
with an O, and end in 2016,
you're gonna flip-flop them.

24
00:01:06.490 --> 00:01:08.163
>> Exactly.
>> It does happen, so.

25
00:01:08.163 --> 00:01:10.634
>> Yeah, so well,
we'll try to say that we're in Outlook.

26
00:01:10.634 --> 00:01:11.387
>> Right.

27
00:01:11.387 --> 00:01:15.258
>> And we'll be going to our Outlook
options, so there's another O.

28
00:01:15.258 --> 00:01:16.875
>> There's another O.
>> [LAUGH]

29
00:01:16.875 --> 00:01:19.178
>> Let's jump down into my computer,

30
00:01:19.178 --> 00:01:21.565
and get into Joey's email account.

31
00:01:21.565 --> 00:01:26.706
And we're going to start composing
messages with these email options.

32
00:01:26.706 --> 00:01:33.149
So we've gone through our basic emails
with, what's our To field, our CC field.

33
00:01:33.149 --> 00:01:37.363
We even covered our BCC field,
addressing to multiple people.

34
00:01:37.363 --> 00:01:38.687
So, we're going to take that and
just expand.

35
00:01:38.687 --> 00:01:43.354
So we're going to start
in a New Message from our

36
00:01:43.354 --> 00:01:47.683
Home tab of our ribbon
in our Email section.

37
00:01:47.683 --> 00:01:51.967
And let's start over on our, well, why
don't I start here on this Message tab?

38
00:01:51.967 --> 00:01:57.010
Cuz some of the things that we are going
to be covering are on this particular tab.

39
00:01:57.010 --> 00:02:00.150
There's only a couple of them,
and they're over here.

40
00:02:00.150 --> 00:02:04.859
They're the Importance level, the High
Importance and the Low Importance.

41
00:02:04.859 --> 00:02:07.232
So I just wanted to point that
out that they are on this tab.

42
00:02:07.232 --> 00:02:10.876
But I'd like to go ahead and
explain what exactly that means,

43
00:02:10.876 --> 00:02:13.540
when we get over in to our Other section.

44
00:02:13.540 --> 00:02:18.046
We are going to get in to our Options tab,
of our New Message window.

45
00:02:18.046 --> 00:02:22.607
And so, we have our different fields
here that we've covered, the BCC field,

46
00:02:22.607 --> 00:02:24.457
which is our blind carbon copy.

47
00:02:24.457 --> 00:02:26.905
To where we can put people in there,

48
00:02:26.905 --> 00:02:31.159
that it makes it look like a CC
address to them, but only them.

49
00:02:31.159 --> 00:02:34.351
But if there's multiple
people in that BCC field,

50
00:02:34.351 --> 00:02:37.180
then there's multiple messages going out.

51
00:02:37.180 --> 00:02:40.035
And, of course, in there is
anything in the To or CC field,

52
00:02:40.035 --> 00:02:41.490
that gets shown up as well.

53
00:02:41.490 --> 00:02:43.180
But that was covered in another episode.

54
00:02:43.180 --> 00:02:47.110
But at least here,
you could go ahead and add that field

55
00:02:47.110 --> 00:02:51.640
into our Message window, if you wanted
to go ahead and do it from there.

56
00:02:51.640 --> 00:02:55.560
There's also the From field,
I'm not sure if we covered this yet.

57
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:56.500
And right now you're like,

58
00:02:56.500 --> 00:03:01.170
well, why would I ever need to have it
be from somebody else other than me?

59
00:03:01.170 --> 00:03:05.310
Well that's because Joey, right now,
is only managing his email,

60
00:03:05.310 --> 00:03:08.220
just one email account within Outlook.

61
00:03:08.220 --> 00:03:11.057
But you can configure Outlook
to manage multiple accounts.

62
00:03:11.057 --> 00:03:15.086
I could have, I might have access to,
say, my boss's email.

63
00:03:15.086 --> 00:03:18.134
And I can go ahead and
control his inbox, and

64
00:03:18.134 --> 00:03:21.140
be able to send email on behalf of him.

65
00:03:21.140 --> 00:03:24.302
So I need to determine, well,
who is this email coming from, and

66
00:03:24.302 --> 00:03:25.924
then I could switch the account.

67
00:03:25.924 --> 00:03:29.502
So if I click on that From field, you can
see, well, it gives you that field, and

68
00:03:29.502 --> 00:03:31.044
the little drop-down over here.

69
00:03:31.044 --> 00:03:35.580
This is where, if you did have multiple
accounts, you could then choose,

70
00:03:35.580 --> 00:03:39.430
which one is this going to
look like it's coming from?

71
00:03:39.430 --> 00:03:42.482
So I know in the University,
I manage multiple accounts,

72
00:03:42.482 --> 00:03:45.742
and so I would always have to make
sure that that was always on.

73
00:03:45.742 --> 00:03:49.525
And I'd have to think,
every time I send emails, who am I today?

74
00:03:49.525 --> 00:03:50.837
Kind of like how I am
in all these episodes.

75
00:03:50.837 --> 00:03:54.318
>> [LAUGH]
>> Am I Joey, am I Lance, am I JT?

76
00:03:54.318 --> 00:03:55.998
>> Poor Vonne has no idea
who she is sometimes.

77
00:03:55.998 --> 00:03:57.746
>> [LAUGH]
>> I know,

78
00:03:57.746 --> 00:04:01.709
it's kind of hard keeping
these all in check and track.

79
00:04:01.709 --> 00:04:03.653
>> She's like, what, email who?

80
00:04:03.653 --> 00:04:06.914
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah I have to watch myself, and

81
00:04:06.914 --> 00:04:08.262
I have to remind you.

82
00:04:08.262 --> 00:04:12.090
What account are we in today,
who are we saying that we are?

83
00:04:12.090 --> 00:04:15.649
And so, don't worry, we're going to get
into Chris and JC a little later, too.

84
00:04:15.649 --> 00:04:19.234
But for right now, we are Joey, and this
is where this email's coming from, and

85
00:04:19.234 --> 00:04:20.834
it's the only account that I have.

86
00:04:20.834 --> 00:04:25.859
So the From field isn't necessarily
applicable, in this instance.

87
00:04:25.859 --> 00:04:28.663
Let's get in over to these other options.

88
00:04:28.663 --> 00:04:32.374
Because a lot of the things that we're
going to be covering here are going to be

89
00:04:32.374 --> 00:04:33.960
right here on this ribbon.

90
00:04:33.960 --> 00:04:36.040
The Voting, which we'll get into,
the Delivery and

91
00:04:36.040 --> 00:04:39.650
Read Receipts, and the Delay options.

92
00:04:39.650 --> 00:04:41.530
Now I did mention the Importance, but

93
00:04:41.530 --> 00:04:46.378
the Importance buttons aren't on
this Options tab, but they are here.

94
00:04:46.378 --> 00:04:50.095
We're going to go to what
I call the More button,

95
00:04:50.095 --> 00:04:54.415
I think the technical name is
the Dialog Box Launcher button.

96
00:04:55.585 --> 00:04:57.695
>> Doesn't really roll off the tongue,
does it?

97
00:04:57.695 --> 00:05:00.412
>> No, no, and
it doesn't really describe what it does,

98
00:05:00.412 --> 00:05:05.022
which is gives you more options, so-
>> Well I love how they call it the dialog

99
00:05:05.022 --> 00:05:07.802
box, and you're thinking,
what the heck is a dialog box?

100
00:05:07.802 --> 00:05:11.442
And typically that's anytime you click
on something, and a window opens up.

101
00:05:11.442 --> 00:05:14.222
Something jumps up and
gives you options, Windows,

102
00:05:14.222 --> 00:05:16.372
or Microsoft likes to
call it a dialog box.

103
00:05:16.372 --> 00:05:17.911
>> Yes, yes,
I mean it could be like the prompt.

104
00:05:17.911 --> 00:05:21.120
Even like the Save,
if you wanna save or not save?

105
00:05:21.120 --> 00:05:23.935
Well, you can call it a prompt,
you can call it the Save window.

106
00:05:23.935 --> 00:05:26.955
I mean, we tend to kinda label
things the way we wanna label.

107
00:05:26.955 --> 00:05:28.667
>> The way we think we would label them,

00:27:56.920 --> 00:27:58.710
Join us in part two to see more.

00:27:58.710 --> 00:28:02.519
That being said, for OfficeProTV I've
been your host, Daniel Lowery.

561

>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

562
00:28:03.590 --> 00:28:05.534
And we'll see you next time.

563
00:28:05.534 --> 00:28:10.744
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne continue looking at advanced email features found in Outlook 2016. Here they look over advanced features specific to the receiving client. You'll see options like Importance, Read receipts, Expires, and Voting buttons.
episodes.title: Advanced Email Features Part 2

a part 3 nonetheless.

437
00:23:57.484 --> 00:24:01.990
So join us for that, learn some cool
extra features we have in store for you.

438
00:24:01.990 --> 00:24:06.000
That being said,
signing off for OfficeProTV,

439
00:24:06.000 --> 00:24:08.040
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

440
00:24:08.040 --> 00:24:08.700
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

441
00:24:08.700 --> 00:24:09.588
>> And we'll see you next time.

442
00:24:09.588 --> 00:24:14.013
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne continue looking at advanced email features found in Outlook 2016. Here they will finish with the 2 advanced options, Recall and Mention.
episodes.title: Advanced Email Features Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.431 --> 00:00:06.183
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.183 --> 00:00:07.719
All right, greetings, everyone.

3
00:00:07.719 --> 00:00:10.830
And welcome back to another
great episode of OfficeProTV.

4
00:00:10.830 --> 00:00:13.169
I am your host, Mr. Daniel Lowrie.

5
00:00:13.169 --> 00:00:15.581
And joining us in
the studio again today for

6
00:00:15.581 --> 00:00:18.194
a little more on our Outlook 2016 series,

7
00:00:18.194 --> 00:00:23.190
specifically looking at some advanced
options when you send and receive emails.

8
00:00:23.190 --> 00:00:24.620
Our good friend, Ms. Vonne Smith.

9
00:00:24.620 --> 00:00:25.940
Vonne, we're so glad to have you again.

10
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:26.800
How's it going today?

11
00:00:26.800 --> 00:00:30.237
>> I'm great,
ready to wrap this part three up.

12
00:00:30.237 --> 00:00:30.890
>> Tres.

13
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:33.530
>> Yes, of our advanced email options.

14
00:00:33.530 --> 00:00:35.189
Yes, there's that many options.

15
00:00:35.189 --> 00:00:35.803
>> [LAUGH] Are a few.

16
00:00:35.803 --> 00:00:37.767
>> [LAUGH] Three parts of them, so.

17
00:00:37.767 --> 00:00:42.144
But we only have two main areas
to go over in this episode.

18
00:00:42.144 --> 00:00:44.626
We're gonna go over recalling messages.

19
00:00:44.626 --> 00:00:48.173
And we're going to be
going over the @mention,

20
00:00:48.173 --> 00:00:51.208
which is a new little feature of Outlook.

21
00:00:51.208 --> 00:00:54.256
Well, it's new, it's not brand new.

22
00:00:54.256 --> 00:00:55.338
>> Okay.
>> It's been around for a little bit.

23
00:00:55.338 --> 00:00:59.926
But it's something that is kind of,
it's they're trying to stay,

24
00:00:59.926 --> 00:01:02.707
I call it, trendy, stay with the times.

25
00:01:02.707 --> 00:01:06.256
>> It's [LAUGH] Outlook hipster for
[INAUDIBLE], yeah.

26
00:01:06.256 --> 00:01:09.664
>> Yes, trying to be like the Insties and
the Faceies.

27
00:01:09.664 --> 00:01:12.775
I don't know if it's Faceies, but [LAUGH]-
>> It's something.

28
00:01:12.775 --> 00:01:16.776
>> Yeah, where you can do the @ and
then the person's name, like Twitter.

29
00:01:16.776 --> 00:01:17.419
>> Okay.

30
00:01:17.419 --> 00:01:22.070
>> We see it all the time with our
Twitter feeds that man all of our own.

31
00:01:22.070 --> 00:01:25.029
We have a person that does it for
us, and she's awesome.

32
00:01:25.029 --> 00:01:27.032
So [LAUGH] keeps us social.

33
00:01:27.032 --> 00:01:32.680
But yeah, the mentions, @whatever,
it's the same thing in Outlook.

34
00:01:32.680 --> 00:01:35.118
>> Well,
that'll be an interesting topic to broach.

35
00:01:35.118 --> 00:01:37.655
But let's start with the easier thing,

36
00:01:37.655 --> 00:01:42.737
which is something you might be familiar
with, which is I've sent out an email.

37
00:01:42.737 --> 00:01:47.320
And oops, the date and time was wrong for
the party that we're planning.

38
00:01:47.320 --> 00:01:50.113
Or something wasn't right,
I wanna recall that message.

39
00:01:50.113 --> 00:01:51.991
That was a functionality that we have,
right?

40
00:01:51.991 --> 00:01:55.967
>> It is a functionality,
but it has its limitations.

41
00:01:55.967 --> 00:01:56.783
>> It does.

42
00:01:56.783 --> 00:01:59.625
>> It does, it definitely does.

43
00:01:59.625 --> 00:02:03.486
I would say I'm gonna show you
how you could try to go ahead and

44
00:02:03.486 --> 00:02:04.706
recall a message.

45
00:02:04.706 --> 00:02:06.151
Cuz it is a feature,

46
00:02:06.151 --> 00:02:11.430
it's a function within Outlook that
you can attempt to recall a message.

47
00:02:11.430 --> 00:02:17.940
But I would say make sure you really
want to send this before you send this.

48
00:02:17.940 --> 00:02:23.450
[LAUGH] I've gotten emails where I'm like,
oo, I'm mad.

49
00:02:23.450 --> 00:02:24.277
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

50
00:02:24.277 --> 00:02:24.777
>> You know?

51
00:02:24.777 --> 00:02:25.994
[LAUGH] And you start typing a response.

52
00:02:25.994 --> 00:02:27.634
And your, da, da, da, da, da,

53
00:02:27.634 --> 00:02:30.675
and then you know what I do?
I type it all out and then I delete it.

54
00:02:30.675 --> 00:02:31.292
>> Yeah.

55
00:02:31.292 --> 00:02:33.424
>> It's like, get it out of my system and

56
00:02:33.424 --> 00:02:36.433
don't send it because once it's sent,
it's sent.

57
00:02:36.433 --> 00:02:38.812
You should always treat it as you will

58
00:02:38.812 --> 00:02:42.885
never be able to take back what you said.
>> Right, the box is open and it cannot be

59
00:02:42.885 --> 00:02:47.013
closed once it's been opened, right?
>> Yes, always think before you speak,

60
00:02:47.013 --> 00:02:50.325
which is something I need
to get better at, too.

61
00:02:50.325 --> 00:02:51.213
[LAUGH]

62
00:02:51.213 --> 00:02:52.661
>> And I don't even mean to say the wrong

63
00:02:52.661 --> 00:02:54.879
thing, it's just my brain gets haywired.
>> Exactly,

64
00:02:54.879 --> 00:02:56.373
that is totally not what I meant.

65
00:02:56.373 --> 00:02:58.905
Yeah.
>> Wrong

66
00:02:58.905 --> 00:02:59.815
words, my bad.

67
00:02:59.815 --> 00:03:00.486
>> Yeah.

68
00:03:00.486 --> 00:03:01.385
[LAUGH]
>> Let's try again.

69
00:03:01.385 --> 00:03:02.093
[LAUGH]

70
00:03:02.093 --> 00:03:03.779
>> Yeah, so I feel like we're talking

71
00:03:03.779 --> 00:03:04.852
about life right now.

72
00:03:04.852 --> 00:03:05.388
[LAUGH]

73
00:03:05.388 --> 00:03:06.196
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

74
00:03:06.196 --> 00:03:07.267
>> The meaning of life,

75
00:03:07.267 --> 00:03:11.735
make sure you think before you speak.
[LAUGH] Before you act, all those things.

76
00:03:11.735 --> 00:03:15.355
Same with emails, you gotta make sure
that before you hit that Send button,

77
00:03:15.355 --> 00:03:17.915
you really mean what you say.

78
00:03:17.915 --> 00:03:22.700
>> Right, and in email, there's no
inflection and tone and body language and

79
00:03:22.700 --> 00:03:27.120
facial expression that can kinda go,
well, I think they kinda meant this.

80
00:03:27.120 --> 00:03:30.890
It's all straight text, and
you can get in real trouble and

81
00:03:30.890 --> 00:03:32.450
didn't even mean anything by it.

82
00:03:32.450 --> 00:03:36.984
So this is something, yeah,
like Vonne says, please email responsibly.

83
00:03:36.984 --> 00:03:39.880
>> It doesn't matter how many
smiley faces you put in there,

84
00:03:39.880 --> 00:03:41.662
somebody might misconstrue that.

85
00:03:41.662 --> 00:03:47.256
So [LAUGH] let me show you how to
do this and what are the alerts,

86
00:03:47.256 --> 00:03:52.740
if you wanna say,
is if you were successful or not.

87
00:03:52.740 --> 00:03:54.670
So recalling a message,

88
00:03:54.670 --> 00:03:58.905
the way that you wanna do it is you
have to go into the sent items.

89
00:03:58.905 --> 00:04:04.468
Well, let's get an email started before we
go, and we're gonna address this to lance.

90
00:04:04.468 --> 00:04:08.190
And we're going to say,

91
00:04:08.190 --> 00:04:12.799
thanks, sarcastically, for

92
00:04:12.799 --> 00:04:17.885
throwing me under the bus-
>> You jerk.

93
00:04:17.885 --> 00:04:20.148
>> With Joey, yeah, boo.

94
00:04:20.148 --> 00:04:22.716
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

95
00:04:22.716 --> 00:04:24.379
>> Boo on you.

96
00:04:24.379 --> 00:04:26.307
>> This is a very strongly worded
letter you have going on here.

97
00:04:26.307 --> 00:04:27.299
>> Sad face.

98
00:04:27.299 --> 00:04:28.539
>> Man, he's mad.

99
00:04:28.539 --> 00:04:32.161
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, [LAUGH] yeah,

100
00:04:32.161 --> 00:04:36.685
I'm not this nice in real life sometimes.

101
00:04:36.685 --> 00:04:38.009
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, yeah, yeah,

102
00:04:38.009 --> 00:04:39.803
we're trying to be as nice as mean can be.

103
00:04:39.803 --> 00:04:42.646
[LAUGH]
>> Exactly, [LAUGH] so here you go, Lance,

104
00:04:42.646 --> 00:04:47.064
I'm going to send this, and
I'm not thinking I'm gonna send it.

105
00:04:47.064 --> 00:04:48.280
Wait, wait, let me hit the button.

106
00:04:48.280 --> 00:04:49.395
There, I'm gonna send it.

107
00:04:49.395 --> 00:04:52.601
[LAUGH] And then you're like, oo,
maybe I should take that back.

108
00:04:52.601 --> 00:04:55.300
Okay, how do you recall your message?

109
00:04:55.300 --> 00:04:59.788
You're gonna go in the sent mail and
you gotta act quick.

110
00:04:59.788 --> 00:05:05.050
You go into your sent mail,
there's my email to Lance that I sent.

111
00:05:05.050 --> 00:05:06.190
I'm gonna open it.

112
00:05:06.190 --> 00:05:10.500
You could also do it from, it's the same
ribbon button right there on the home tab.

113
00:05:10.500 --> 00:05:12.988
But in here, there's a little button, and

114
00:05:12.988 --> 00:05:17.843
you might actually see more information if
you have more real estate on your monitor.

115
00:05:17.843 --> 00:05:19.518
That is the wrong button.

116
00:05:19.518 --> 00:05:20.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> Okay,

117
00:05:20.350 --> 00:05:22.854
how about we come [LAUGH]
over here to our Actions.

118
00:05:22.854 --> 00:05:25.388
[LAUGH] Sorry, wrong one.

119
00:05:25.388 --> 00:05:28.314
Let's go over here to
the Move category and

120
00:05:28.314 --> 00:05:31.254
we'll go into their Recall this message.

121
00:05:31.254 --> 00:05:35.920
This is something you can try to delete
the message that you have already sent.

122
00:05:37.250 --> 00:05:40.643
So I'm gonna go ahead and
click on this and you can see in here.

123
00:05:40.643 --> 00:05:45.788
Do you want to delete the unread,
keyword, unread.

124
00:05:45.788 --> 00:05:48.764
If they've already read your email,
this ain't gonna work.

125
00:05:48.764 --> 00:05:49.596
>> They already read your email.

126
00:05:49.596 --> 00:05:53.364
[LAUGH] Outlook cannot go
inside people's minds and go,

127
00:05:53.364 --> 00:05:57.709
you have forgotten all of this
information which you just read.

128
00:05:57.709 --> 00:05:59.610
>> These are not the emails
you're looking for.

129
00:05:59.610 --> 00:06:03.614
[LAUGH] Yeah, so it's one of those things
of, okay, yes, I would like to, and

130
00:06:03.614 --> 00:06:04.780
you could replace it.

131
00:06:04.780 --> 00:06:08.820
I could say, hey, thank you really for
talking to Joey for me.

132
00:06:08.820 --> 00:06:12.160
I really appreciate it, smiley face.

133
00:06:12.160 --> 00:06:14.360
So I'm gonna say, yep,
I definitely wanted to.

134
00:06:14.360 --> 00:06:18.640
And notice tell me if recall succeeds or
fails.

135
00:06:18.640 --> 00:06:22.040
Probably would like know that too,
I'm gonna click OK.

136
00:06:22.040 --> 00:06:27.055
You tried to recall, so it's telling
you when you tried to recall it,

137
00:06:27.055 --> 00:06:31.221
the date and time and
I'm going to go ahead and close this.

138
00:06:31.221 --> 00:06:36.677
And because I know that Lance did not,
at least I hope Lance didn't read that.

139
00:06:36.677 --> 00:06:41.724
I am Lance, so [LAUGH] I should be able
to get a recall message that says,

140
00:06:41.724 --> 00:06:43.276
yes, you're okay.

141
00:06:43.276 --> 00:06:46.831
Nothing was received and it was.

142
00:06:46.831 --> 00:06:47.606
>> It was read, yeah.

143
00:06:47.606 --> 00:06:49.111
>> Yes, thank you,
that's what I was trying to do.

144
00:06:49.111 --> 00:06:50.003
There it is.

145
00:06:50.003 --> 00:06:51.411
I was like, come on in.

146
00:06:51.411 --> 00:06:54.168
Notice what I did is I went
into the send and receive and

147
00:06:54.168 --> 00:06:56.445
I clicked the send and
receive all folders.

148
00:06:56.445 --> 00:07:00.235
So it was just kinda forcing it,
so that's what I was doing there.

149
00:07:00.235 --> 00:07:04.840
And you can see that it was
recalled successfully, phew.

150
00:07:04.840 --> 00:07:06.985
[INAUDIBLE]-
>> [CROSSTALK] It tells them, though,

151
00:07:06.985 --> 00:07:08.965
you had a message that was recalled,
right?

152
00:07:08.965 --> 00:07:09.565
It was telling you, okay.

153
00:07:09.565 --> 00:07:11.447
>> This is me, yeah.

154
00:07:11.447 --> 00:07:12.410
Cuz right now I'm Joey.

155
00:07:12.410 --> 00:07:15.533
>> Right, gotcha, I should've
looked at the top, it says Joey S.

156
00:07:15.533 --> 00:07:18.106
>> Yes, [LAUGH] we've been so
many people in this episode, so.

157
00:07:18.106 --> 00:07:19.357
>> It gets confusing, ladies and gents.

158
00:07:19.357 --> 00:07:25.098
>> So it says that my message that was to
Lance with this subject was recalled and

159
00:07:25.098 --> 00:07:27.260
everything should be fine.

160
00:07:27.260 --> 00:07:32.188
I'm gonna switch over to Lance just
to go ahead and see that, yep,

161
00:07:32.188 --> 00:07:36.590
in my inbox,
I don't see anything that says thanks.

162
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:39.410
I don't see anything
that says in the Sent,

163
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:43.090
so yeah, you-
>> Successfully recalled that message.

164
00:07:43.090 --> 00:07:43.976
>> You're good.

165
00:07:43.976 --> 00:07:47.717
But if Lance had opened that email,
then you wouldn't have been able to do it.

166
00:07:47.717 --> 00:07:54.318
And I actually have a recall
that I have from down here.

167
00:07:54.318 --> 00:07:55.022
There we go.

168
00:07:55.022 --> 00:07:58.582
So you could see that Joey
sent an email to Justin.

169
00:07:58.582 --> 00:08:03.138
And the first one to Justin
was recalled successfully.

170
00:08:03.138 --> 00:08:05.690
Cuz I was trying to give you
an error message as well.

171
00:08:05.690 --> 00:08:09.565
Well, the second one recall to,
question mark,

172
00:08:09.565 --> 00:08:15.676
that one could not be recalled, so Justin
read it, so you tried and it failed.

173
00:08:15.676 --> 00:08:20.054
So this is your failure message
[LAUGH] of, it didn't work, so

174
00:08:20.054 --> 00:08:24.115
you better go down that hall and
start apologizing, so.

175
00:08:24.115 --> 00:08:28.164
>> I wish it would just play
a little MP3 of [SOUND]

176
00:08:28.164 --> 00:08:29.589
>> [LAUGH]

177
00:08:29.589 --> 00:08:30.746
>> Like, no.

178
00:08:30.746 --> 00:08:33.336
[LAUGH]
>> And you hang your head.

179
00:08:33.336 --> 00:08:34.822
>> You failed.

180
00:08:34.822 --> 00:08:41.066
>> Exactly, and so this is great if
you're on the same Exchange server.

181
00:08:41.066 --> 00:08:44.032
So what if you're not on
the same Exchange server?

182
00:08:44.032 --> 00:08:45.531
What if you're using Gmail?

183
00:08:45.531 --> 00:08:46.991
That's where it won't work.

184
00:08:46.991 --> 00:08:48.010
>> It really doesn't work.

185
00:08:48.010 --> 00:08:54.039
>> Yeah, and I found this on the Internet,
but I thought it was a pretty decent one.

186
00:08:54.039 --> 00:08:58.844
You could Google all of this, but I liked
this article on this recall-email.com,

187
00:08:58.844 --> 00:09:00.343
[LAUGH] rightfully named.

188
00:09:00.343 --> 00:09:02.338
>> Yeah, somebody was thinking ahead.

189
00:09:02.338 --> 00:09:03.692
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, and it's nice,

190
00:09:03.692 --> 00:09:06.288
cuz it talks about how the different
servers that you could do this on.

191
00:09:06.288 --> 00:09:12.890
But the one in Outlook, and the biggest
one, act quickly, you better go quick.

192
00:09:12.890 --> 00:09:15.840
And it does have to be that
you're on the same Exchange,

193
00:09:15.840 --> 00:09:18.510
with Exchange account on the same server.

194
00:09:18.510 --> 00:09:22.200
So even you're on Exchange, but
it's on a different server.

195
00:09:22.200 --> 00:09:25.187
So you could see right here,
sent to a different Exchange server.

196
00:09:25.187 --> 00:09:28.169
We're all using Outlook,
we're all using Exchange, but

197
00:09:28.169 --> 00:09:30.743
we're not within the same
circle if you wanna say.

198
00:09:30.743 --> 00:09:32.498
So that could be a difference.

199
00:09:32.498 --> 00:09:37.830
Or if you're using Yahoo or Gmail outside,
then that's not gonna work.

200
00:09:37.830 --> 00:09:42.713
And it has to be that they
haven't opened the email yet.

201
00:09:42.713 --> 00:09:47.087
So those are a couple variants that-
>> Couple of provisos, yeah.

202
00:09:47.087 --> 00:09:49.489
>> Yeah, but that's a lot.

203
00:09:49.489 --> 00:09:52.791
Cuz how many times are you gonna
be emailing people that aren't on

204
00:09:52.791 --> 00:09:54.000
your Exchange server?

205
00:09:54.000 --> 00:09:56.055
What if you're not even
on an Exchange server?

206
00:09:56.055 --> 00:09:59.501
What if you start doing something that,
somebody's just sitting there reading

207
00:09:59.501 --> 00:10:01.689
their email every single
second that they come in?

208
00:10:01.689 --> 00:10:06.560
So you shouldn't rely on this
as your kinda safety net.

209
00:10:06.560 --> 00:10:10.000
Just really think before you send.

210
00:10:10.000 --> 00:10:12.530
And then it goes through the same
options that we just did.

211
00:10:12.530 --> 00:10:15.785
It is in the actions,
there's not that button.

212
00:10:15.785 --> 00:10:18.120
[LAUGH] Not that one, it's this one.

213
00:10:18.120 --> 00:10:21.630
So I think they kinda look the same.

214
00:10:21.630 --> 00:10:23.200
>> Yeah.
>> There's two little things in there.

215
00:10:23.200 --> 00:10:23.990
>> We all make mistakes.

216
00:10:23.990 --> 00:10:24.858
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

217
00:10:24.858 --> 00:10:25.754
>> But you can't recall that.

218
00:10:25.754 --> 00:10:26.274
>> Yeah.

219
00:10:26.274 --> 00:10:30.094
>> [LAUGH]
>> Exactly, [LAUGH] so that email, or the,

220
00:10:30.094 --> 00:10:31.180
what is this?

221
00:10:31.180 --> 00:10:33.803
This is a web page that I
wanted a reference for that.

222
00:10:33.803 --> 00:10:35.738
I just thought it was
pretty decent information.

223
00:10:35.738 --> 00:10:38.535
And so, that is recall messages.

224
00:10:38.535 --> 00:10:45.524
The other topic that we mentioned
was the mention, the whole @whoever.

225
00:10:45.524 --> 00:10:49.254
I have emails that somebody emailed.

Another thing that kind of helps

You do the @ and the name and the contact,

So it's a nice thing for you to do so

To where, I need to bring Lance in,

And that way you could even do

[LAUGH] But that's how it works and

That being said,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne show you how to create an email signature in Outlook 2016. Here they will define what an email signature is and then proceed to walking you step-by-step through creating one and adding it to your message body.
episodes.title: Signatures
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

So why don't I go ahead and show you some

51

52

You can be in a creative outlet.

00:02:20.340 --> 00:02:21.690

54
00:02:21.690 --> 00:02:23.150

So, let's maybe not use that signature.

64

Well, you can control that in Outlook.

You can determine, hey,

68

You can go ahead and pick which ones

69

And I think actually somebody

72
00:03:12.374 --> 00:03:14.030
[LAUGH]
>> The director of awesomeness.

73
00:03:14.030 --> 00:03:16.930

people within your organization.

74
00:03:16.930 --> 00:03:20.370
But to the outside organization,
you're the director of marketing, or

75
00:03:20.370 --> 00:03:21.960
something to that sense.

76
00:03:21.960 --> 00:03:28.090
And so you can pick which signature
you want to insert into your message,

77
00:03:28.090 --> 00:03:30.410
and when you want it to do it by default.

78
00:03:30.410 --> 00:03:33.649
And all of those kind of
settings that you can, well, set.

79
00:03:33.649 --> 00:03:37.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So here's Justin's fancy

signature with his address and

81

Road.

Miraval Lane.

84

You made that up.

85
