>> Well, yes I, well,
it's not, I made it up.

86
00:03:50.455 --> 00:03:51.355
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> Yeah.

87
00:03:51.355 --> 00:03:52.290
>> That's his actual signature.

88
00:03:52.290 --> 00:03:54.315
>> Miraval is one of his tours.

89
00:03:54.315 --> 00:03:56.268
Okay, so and then from.

90
00:03:56.268 --> 00:04:00.102
But 12345 is not the right zip code but-
>> No, probably not.

91
00:04:00.102 --> 00:04:01.352
>> Anyways-
>> [LAUGH]

92
00:04:01.352 --> 00:04:05.632
>> Huge JT fan over here ladies and gents.

93
00:04:05.632 --> 00:04:08.180
>> Yes.
Just slightly, so [LAUGH]

94
00:04:08.180 --> 00:04:13.470
we have his signature and you can see that
Joey said hey nice picture, that's great.

95
00:04:13.470 --> 00:04:17.900
And then back here that the one that,
I have it to where he says thanks and

96
00:04:17.900 --> 00:04:19.090
there's another signature.

97
00:04:19.090 --> 00:04:20.330
Here, let me switch over to Joey.

98
00:04:20.330 --> 00:04:21.380
There we go.

99

There's Joey's response from Justin.

It says, hey, thanks.

00:15:53.784 --> 00:15:57.429
And now you can see that it
didn't do two signatures.

335
00:15:57.429 --> 00:16:00.971
It just saw, well this isn't the most
recent version of it, so here is.

336
00:16:00.971 --> 00:16:05.330
The simple signature that you have
edited and put in that website address.

337
00:16:06.550 --> 00:16:10.630
Let's move over to business card before
we get into the fancier signature like

338
00:16:10.630 --> 00:16:13.610
the picture because a lot of people
wanna put their pictures in there.

339
00:16:14.740 --> 00:16:16.100
Get that to then, in just a second.

340
00:16:17.880 --> 00:16:19.590
Let me jump over to the context.

341
00:16:19.590 --> 00:16:23.257
I'm gonna close this out because I did
wanna show you where that business card is

342
00:16:23.257 --> 00:16:23.923
coming from.

343
00:16:23.923 --> 00:16:27.860
And while like I said,
this isn't the context area of our show.

344
00:16:27.860 --> 00:16:33.120
We have over here, I just realized,
I don't think I have Joey as a contact.

345
00:16:33.120 --> 00:16:35.520
So I wouldn't be able to
add him as a business card.

346
00:16:35.520 --> 00:16:40.552
So you know what, instead of that, let's
jump over to JT, [LAUGH] cuz JT has one.

347
00:16:40.552 --> 00:16:45.050
So in his contacts, you could see that
there are some contacts in here for

348
00:16:45.050 --> 00:16:46.890
Lance and for Joey.

349
00:16:46.890 --> 00:16:51.110
And there is a contact in
Justin Timberlake's Outlook for

350
00:16:51.110 --> 00:16:52.100
Justin Timberlake.

351
00:16:52.100 --> 00:16:56.090
He went ahead and created and
put all of his work information, and

352
00:16:56.090 --> 00:16:58.200
his address, and links.

353
00:16:58.200 --> 00:17:03.030
So you create your own contact, you put
in your own picture in your contact,

354
00:17:03.030 --> 00:17:06.240
this will become the business card.

355
00:17:06.240 --> 00:17:09.646
Jumping back over into our mail,
I'm going to go to mail,

356
00:17:09.646 --> 00:17:13.340
new mail and go into signature cuz
this is always a place I go to.

357
00:17:13.340 --> 00:17:16.272
I don't really go over in the options,
for some reason.

358
00:17:16.272 --> 00:17:18.610
I don't know why, I just,
this is the way I go.

359
00:17:18.610 --> 00:17:20.800
So come in and do signatures.

360
00:17:20.800 --> 00:17:23.512
I'm going to delete this one,
cuz this is another thing.

361
00:17:23.512 --> 00:17:25.420
I don't want this signature.

362
00:17:25.420 --> 00:17:28.880
Go ahead and click on it and
make it go away.

363
00:17:28.880 --> 00:17:32.840
Now it's gone, so
I just have the simple and the fancy.

364
00:17:32.840 --> 00:17:36.216
Now I'm gonna make a new one so
you can see how I did the business card.

365
00:17:36.216 --> 00:17:39.432
And we'll say card, click OK.

366
00:17:39.432 --> 00:17:42.600
Here is the named signature I want.

367
00:17:42.600 --> 00:17:44.380
Just click the button,
it's that simple and

368
00:17:44.380 --> 00:17:47.765
then that's I have to click which
card I'm gonna put in there.

369
00:17:47.765 --> 00:17:49.570
[LAUGH] Sorry, forgot that extra step.

370
00:17:49.570 --> 00:17:52.394
>> So you're just choosing a contact out
of your contacts and it creates the card.

371
00:17:52.394 --> 00:17:56.415
>> Yeah, so I don't think you'd really
wanna put Joey Fatona as your signature in

372
00:17:56.415 --> 00:18:00.455
Justin's email, but that's why you need
to make sure you pick your contact.

373
00:18:00.455 --> 00:18:03.463
>> Well, and this comes into play because
you might be connecting to different

374
00:18:03.463 --> 00:18:04.645
address books.

375
00:18:04.645 --> 00:18:09.134
And you'll go, I want my contact from
this address book, so that's why it

376
00:18:09.134 --> 00:18:13.633
gives you ability to choose, and not
just go, well, you are you, here you go.

377
00:18:13.633 --> 00:18:15.680
[LAUGH]
>> That's a great point, yes,

378
00:18:15.680 --> 00:18:19.190
cuz you can have multiple
contacts in multiple places, and

379
00:18:19.190 --> 00:18:21.778
you have global addresses,
you have your own contacts.

380
00:18:21.778 --> 00:18:24.279
Yes, definitely different
storage places for

381
00:18:24.279 --> 00:18:26.664
different reasons of why
you are who you are.

382
00:18:26.664 --> 00:18:30.270
Click OK here,
there's my business card, click OK.

383
00:18:30.270 --> 00:18:34.350
And now any time that I
insert that signature card.

384
00:18:34.350 --> 00:18:35.530
I named it card.

385
00:18:35.530 --> 00:18:37.880
It goes ahead and
it puts it at the bottom.

386
00:18:37.880 --> 00:18:40.650
And it always adds it as an attachment.

387
00:18:40.650 --> 00:18:44.680
And these business cards,
when you're sharing it this way, they work

388
00:18:44.680 --> 00:18:49.058
on not only everything in Outlook like
Exchange Servers, it goes past that.

389
00:18:49.058 --> 00:18:54.490
Gmail, cuz we send this to Chris over
on his Gmail account, works just fine.

390
00:18:54.490 --> 00:18:56.661
And they can go ahead and click on it and
put it into the contacts.

391
00:18:56.661 --> 00:19:00.630
That VCF, it's not Outlook specific.

392
00:19:00.630 --> 00:19:03.020
It's not a Microsoft specific format.

393
00:19:03.020 --> 00:19:08.310
It is a more universal for all platforms,
for all different types of mail servers.

394
00:19:08.310 --> 00:19:11.140
And that's why it's nice because
you can start exchanging it.

395
00:19:11.140 --> 00:19:13.080
And we will talk about
sharing contacts and

396
00:19:13.080 --> 00:19:16.210
everything when we get
into those episodes.

397
00:19:16.210 --> 00:19:17.960
So we've covered all of those.

398
00:19:17.960 --> 00:19:20.020
Where's my fancy signature?

399
00:19:20.020 --> 00:19:24.067
The easiest way to do a fancy,
and when I say fancy,

400
00:19:24.067 --> 00:19:28.869
is to create one with a picture and
with your alignment cuz you

401
00:19:28.869 --> 00:19:34.410
don't get these options in
the edit signature dialogue box.

402
00:19:34.410 --> 00:19:37.250
The easiest way to do it, and
you get a lot more options,

403
00:19:37.250 --> 00:19:41.820
is to create the signature
in a new message.

404
00:19:41.820 --> 00:19:48.580
Select it all, copy it, and
then paste it into the signature edit box.

405
00:19:48.580 --> 00:19:49.599
So that's what we're gonna do.

406
00:19:49.599 --> 00:19:50.567
Dan is over here going.

407
00:19:50.567 --> 00:19:53.493
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I've done this before.

408
00:19:53.493 --> 00:19:57.759
[LAUGH] I've had people go, how do I make
the cool Gliffy things with, you know,

409
00:19:57.759 --> 00:20:00.195
the rainbows and
the sparkles, I need that!

410
00:20:00.195 --> 00:20:02.863
And I'm like, I don't think you
can just throw it in there.

411
00:20:02.863 --> 00:20:05.539
And we had to go through the whole
process and figure it out.

412
00:20:05.539 --> 00:20:09.745
You create a new email and put all
this stuff, cuz it's an HTML editor.

413
00:20:09.745 --> 00:20:10.445
>> Exactly.

414
00:20:10.445 --> 00:20:12.875
>> Chuck your stuff in there, copy it,
and throw it in, and you're good to go.

415
00:20:12.875 --> 00:20:14.360
>> Actually like, yeah!

416
00:20:14.360 --> 00:20:14.976
>> It's like a blast from the past.

417
00:20:14.976 --> 00:20:18.405
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, it's all coming back to me now.

418
00:20:18.405 --> 00:20:19.765
>> [LAUGH]
>> Like waves of nostalgia.

419
00:20:19.765 --> 00:20:22.132
[LAUGH]
>> You make me really wanna sing

420
00:20:22.132 --> 00:20:22.840
right now.

421
00:20:22.840 --> 00:20:26.560
[LAUGH] So we're going to say,
this is Joey Fatone.

422
00:20:26.560 --> 00:20:29.060
I'm not putting in the picture first.

423
00:20:29.060 --> 00:20:33.630
From experience, you put your text in
first, and then you put your picture in.

424
00:20:33.630 --> 00:20:34.510
It's a little bit easier.

425
00:20:34.510 --> 00:20:38.367
When you put your picture in from
the very first thing you do in Word,

426
00:20:38.367 --> 00:20:42.357
it takes up space, and sometimes
it's hard to get underneath it, and

427
00:20:42.357 --> 00:20:45.083
move it around, so
text first, picture last.

428
00:20:45.083 --> 00:20:51.240
So we'll say, Joey Fatone,
555 Dance Shoes Lane.

429
00:20:52.255 --> 00:20:53.131
>> He was on Dancing with the Stars.

430
00:20:53.131 --> 00:20:54.492
[LAUGH]
>> He was.

431
00:20:54.492 --> 00:20:55.885
>> He was, he was.

432
00:20:55.885 --> 00:21:00.038
And we'll just say, New York, New York,
cuz I can't think of anything else, right?

433
00:21:00.038 --> 00:21:01.134
Where's the Y?

434
00:21:01.134 --> 00:21:01.759
There it is.

435
00:21:01.759 --> 00:21:02.639
[LAUGH]
>> It's on the keyboard.

436
00:21:02.639 --> 00:21:07.049
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] 12345, and I could go ahead and

437
00:21:07.049 --> 00:21:08.475
format my text.

438
00:21:08.475 --> 00:21:10.935
We'll make this, well, we can go with red.

439
00:21:10.935 --> 00:21:13.905
We'll make it bold and
we'll make it a little bit bigger.

440
00:21:13.905 --> 00:21:17.780
You could put your website address and
anything else that you would want into.

441
00:21:17.780 --> 00:21:20.270
But for times' sake,
we'll just leave it right here.

442
00:21:20.270 --> 00:21:21.620
Wanna put in my picture.

443
00:21:21.620 --> 00:21:26.690
I'm gonna click back in front of the J,
because I do want it off to the left.

444
00:21:26.690 --> 00:21:29.560
We'll insert, we'll put in a photo.

445
00:21:29.560 --> 00:21:35.034
I do have a picture of Mr Joey,
[LAUGH] and we will insert him there.

446
00:21:35.034 --> 00:21:39.516
>> He's a little big, so I'll take my
corner, always grab from the corner so

447
00:21:39.516 --> 00:21:41.630
it stays the-
>> I love how it scales, yeah.

448
00:21:41.630 --> 00:21:44.580
>> Yes, the, my gosh, aspect ratio.

449
00:21:44.580 --> 00:21:45.769
>> Yeah.
>> It constrains the proportions,

450
00:21:45.769 --> 00:21:46.844
that's what I was trying to say.

451
00:21:46.844 --> 00:21:49.500
[LAUGH] Move it on over here.

452
00:21:49.500 --> 00:21:52.090
Because I have the picture selected,
I get my picture tools.

453
00:21:52.090 --> 00:21:56.442
I could go ahead and format it, and
make it pretty, but what I really want is

454
00:21:56.442 --> 00:22:00.329
the wrap text of how I want the text
to wrap around this photograph.

455
00:22:00.329 --> 00:22:01.930
You can choose square.

456
00:22:01.930 --> 00:22:04.906
I'll probably go ahead and
pick square, and

457
00:22:04.906 --> 00:22:09.370
maybe make this a little bit smaller,
so it kinda lines up.

458
00:22:09.370 --> 00:22:10.559
Okay, I need to stop right now,

459
00:22:10.559 --> 00:22:12.732
because I can start feeling
my designing stuff coming on.

460
00:22:12.732 --> 00:22:13.760
>> Yeah, it's getting crazy.

461
00:22:13.760 --> 00:22:19.920
>> Stop, got my signature or what's going
to become my signature, ready to go.

462
00:22:19.920 --> 00:22:22.980
You can do a Ctrl+A for Select All.

463
00:22:22.980 --> 00:22:24.090
You could do click, hold, and

464
00:22:24.090 --> 00:22:27.650
drag, whichever way you wanna make
sure you get everything selected.

465
00:22:27.650 --> 00:22:28.552
And I'm going to copy.

466
00:22:28.552 --> 00:22:31.930
I'm gonna click on this button up here so
you can see that I am copying,

467
00:22:31.930 --> 00:22:34.370
besides me just using
my keyboard shortcuts.

468
00:22:34.370 --> 00:22:36.280
Copy this.

469
00:22:36.280 --> 00:22:42.660
Come into signature, go to signatures,
you're gonna go ahead and make a new one.

470
00:22:42.660 --> 00:22:44.366
We'll name this Fancy.

471
00:22:44.366 --> 00:22:47.270
I'm gonna say Fancy Pants
cuz I want to say that.

472
00:22:48.350 --> 00:22:49.730
I'm in my Fancy Pants signature.

473
00:22:51.050 --> 00:22:52.180
Click down into the editor.

474
00:22:53.750 --> 00:22:57.740
I am going to paste and I'm just,
you know I'm pasting, but

475
00:22:57.740 --> 00:22:59.670
I'm just gonna go ahead and do Ctrl+V.

476
00:22:59.670 --> 00:23:00.260
Where's the picture?

477
00:23:00.260 --> 00:23:00.810
Where's the picture?

478
00:23:00.810 --> 00:23:02.080
And this always freaks people out.

479
00:23:02.080 --> 00:23:03.315
It freaks me out, too.

480
00:23:03.315 --> 00:23:06.226
Cuz I know the picture's
supposed to be in there.

481
00:23:06.226 --> 00:23:07.260
Just trust me.

482
00:23:07.260 --> 00:23:08.330
>> It's there, right?

483
00:23:08.330 --> 00:23:09.150
>> It is.

484
00:23:09.150 --> 00:23:13.994
It just doesn't want to show you so
you click Save, you click OK.

485
00:23:13.994 --> 00:23:16.860
I'm going to close this message so
we don't get kind of, well,

486
00:23:16.860 --> 00:23:17.878
it's already there.

487
00:23:17.878 --> 00:23:19.640
I'm not saving any changes.

488
00:23:19.640 --> 00:23:23.951
Starting from scratch, let's go, new mail.

489
00:23:23.951 --> 00:23:26.610
You know why this is happening?

490
00:23:26.610 --> 00:23:30.230
It set this as the default and
I wasn't looking at it.

491
00:23:30.230 --> 00:23:32.280
>> What are you gonna do?
>> We'll come over and fix that.

492
00:23:32.280 --> 00:23:33.300
Come over to Signature.

493
00:23:34.320 --> 00:23:36.490
I'm going to see right there,
new messages, the first one, and

494
00:23:36.490 --> 00:23:38.520
I think it does that by default.

495
00:23:38.520 --> 00:23:41.750
>> Right, well, if you have a signature,
it thinks you want to use a signature,

496
00:23:41.750 --> 00:23:44.070
so it thinks, well,
we'll go with one by default.

497
00:23:44.070 --> 00:23:46.560
>> Okay, so we'll go ahead and
jump onto this side right here, and

498
00:23:46.560 --> 00:23:51.450
say I don't want it to have any
default signature in my message body,

499
00:23:51.450 --> 00:23:53.240
so I'm gonna go ahead and click None.

500
00:23:53.240 --> 00:23:54.910
>> Click OK here.

501
00:23:54.910 --> 00:23:55.708
Moment of truth.

502
00:23:55.708 --> 00:23:57.140
Did the picture come over?

503
00:23:58.390 --> 00:23:58.990
It did.

504
00:23:58.990 --> 00:24:01.994
>> There it is.
>> Yes, so just a big note on that one,

505
00:24:01.994 --> 00:24:03.970
trust that it will work.

506
00:24:03.970 --> 00:24:07.920
It does come over, it's just that
you will never get it in the preview

507
00:24:07.920 --> 00:24:09.860
of the edit signature dialogue box.

508
00:24:09.860 --> 00:24:12.950
Once you insert it, it will come on in.

509
00:24:12.950 --> 00:24:15.968
And yes, kind of going back
to those settings of hey,

510
00:24:15.968 --> 00:24:18.919
I always want this to be
the signature that comes when

511
00:24:18.919 --> 00:24:23.100
I make my first message that I want to
send to somebody or my business card.

512
00:24:23.100 --> 00:24:27.374
But then on all of my replies I just want
a smaller one that just has my name.

513
00:24:27.374 --> 00:24:31.090
Because it is always good to put
a signature like who is this from?

514
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:34.487
Cuz I've gone back through some emails
especially if I'm going back and

515
00:24:34.487 --> 00:24:37.337
forth to people and
they don't put their name at the bottom.

516
00:24:37.337 --> 00:24:39.642
I get kind of confused.

517
00:24:39.642 --> 00:24:40.951
Who said that?

518
00:24:40.951 --> 00:24:42.990
>> It's just a real easy way to realize,

519
00:24:42.990 --> 00:24:46.060
okay, this was the person
who sent this email.

520
00:24:46.060 --> 00:24:49.150
>> Even if it's just sincerely,
Vonne Smith.

521
00:24:49.150 --> 00:24:50.460
Something very, very simple and

522
00:24:50.460 --> 00:24:55.870
just make that the default of every
mail whether it's new and/or forwarding.

523
00:24:55.870 --> 00:25:00.003
Then people know that that is who
I am receiving this message from.

524
00:25:00.003 --> 00:25:03.319
So I remember in elementary school we
had to do like the parts of a letter.

525
00:25:03.319 --> 00:25:05.520
>> Learned how to type a letter,
write a letter, yeah.

526
00:25:05.520 --> 00:25:07.520
>> Yeah, and the address block and
the salutation.

527
00:25:07.520 --> 00:25:12.248
>> Sincerely, your name and it was always,
you always ended a letter that way.

528
00:25:12.248 --> 00:25:14.370
>> Exactly, yes.

529
00:25:14.370 --> 00:25:15.960
I wonder if they still
teach that in school?

530
00:25:15.960 --> 00:25:16.514
Cuz I mean, we were writing this out.

531
00:25:16.514 --> 00:25:20.067
>> I hope so, but nowadays they tell
you not even to write stuff anymore.

532
00:25:20.067 --> 00:25:20.590
>> Yeah, I know.
[LAUGH]

533
00:25:20.590 --> 00:25:21.470
>> Who'd get rid of a written language?

534
00:25:21.470 --> 00:25:22.314
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

535
00:25:22.314 --> 00:25:23.463
let's just go ahead and text each other.

536
00:25:23.463 --> 00:25:24.852
[LAUGH]
>> It's all text, here's an emoji for ya.

537
00:25:24.852 --> 00:25:27.836
[LAUGH]
>> We're veering, so we should come back.

538
00:25:27.836 --> 00:25:29.796
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, we're starting to digress.

539
00:25:29.796 --> 00:25:34.387
>> Just go ahead and set those different
defaults by coming into our signatures.

540
00:25:34.387 --> 00:25:35.920
What do I want?

541
00:25:35.920 --> 00:25:38.070
What signature do I want for
my new message?

542
00:25:38.070 --> 00:25:40.660
What signature do I want for my replies?

543
00:25:40.660 --> 00:25:44.981
And if you're managing multiple accounts,
if I had multiple inboxes in here,

544
00:25:44.981 --> 00:25:47.883
you could just go ahead and
set it up for each account,

545
00:25:47.883 --> 00:25:51.707
would have different signatures,
and different default settings.

546
00:25:51.707 --> 00:25:56.606
So I think that is everything that I can
think of, honestly, about signatures, and

547
00:25:56.606 --> 00:26:01.305
now you know to go ahead and put your
little, no, salutation's the beginning.

548
00:26:01.305 --> 00:26:04.027
Your closing,
close every message with a signature.

549
00:26:04.027 --> 00:26:05.068
>> All right, well, Vonne,

550
00:26:05.068 --> 00:26:07.680
you have made us all signature masters,
at least hopefully.

551
00:26:07.680 --> 00:26:08.600
I know that was your goal and

552
00:26:08.600 --> 00:26:11.820
I think you did a great job of walking us
through each of the individual steps that

553
00:26:11.820 --> 00:26:16.100
we can go through to make a very
effective signature for us.

554
00:26:16.100 --> 00:26:19.163
That being said, Vonne, I'm looking at
our clock and we have run out of time for

555
00:26:19.163 --> 00:26:19.773
this episode.

556
00:26:19.773 --> 00:26:20.701
We do thank you for joining us.

557
00:26:20.701 --> 00:26:22.925
We thank you good folks out there for
watching.

558
00:26:22.925 --> 00:26:26.190
Signing off for Office ProTV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowry.

559
00:26:26.190 --> 00:26:26.960
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

560
00:26:26.960 --> 00:26:29.303
>> And we'll see you next time.

561
00:26:29.303 --> 00:26:34.022
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne look at tools and functions that aid in organizing, customizing, and searching in Outlook 2016. Watch as they demonstrate Reading Pane settings, creating folders, and cleaning up/deleting email.
episodes.title: Organize, Customize and Search
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.962
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.962 --> 00:00:10.271
All right, greetings everyone, and welcome
to another great episode of OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:10.271 --> 00:00:13.260
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:13.260 --> 00:00:16.345
we are continuing on with more
on our Outlook 2016 series.

5
00:00:16.345 --> 00:00:19.740
And of course, joining us in the studio
to light up our lives, our good friend,

6
00:00:19.740 --> 00:00:22.490
Ms Vonne Smith, Vonne, we're so glad
to have you back, how's it going today?

7
00:00:22.490 --> 00:00:26.793
>> Thank you, it's going great,
today we are going to organize,

8
00:00:26.793 --> 00:00:29.671
customize, and search, my [LAUGH].

9
00:00:29.671 --> 00:00:31.597
>> [LAUGH] It sounded like a cheer.

10
00:00:31.597 --> 00:00:36.780
>> Yeah, I like the whole organize,
customize, and search.

11
00:00:36.780 --> 00:00:38.240
Just really rolls of the tongue?

12
00:00:38.240 --> 00:00:39.948
>> I really wanna keep saying it but
we should probably go ahead with just-

13
00:00:39.948 --> 00:00:42.071
>> Order some pom-poms here in a second.

14
00:00:42.071 --> 00:00:42.701
>> Don't get me started.

15
00:00:42.701 --> 00:00:45.326
>> Yeah [LAUGH].

16
00:00:45.326 --> 00:00:49.711
>> We're gonna go over all the different
things to try to just keep you in check

17
00:00:49.711 --> 00:00:53.123
when you are using Outlook
because this is your day planner

18
00:00:53.123 --> 00:00:55.718
that we talked about
in the very beginning.

19
00:00:55.718 --> 00:01:01.758
The things that will get you through your
day and everything in your business and

20
00:01:01.758 --> 00:01:07.840
in your office and emails, contacts,
tasks, how do I keep myself organized?

21
00:01:07.840 --> 00:01:11.396
So, I'm gonna go ahead and show you
some different things that you can do in

22
00:01:11.396 --> 00:01:16.040
Outlook, so jump down into the computer,
I'm Joey and

23
00:01:16.040 --> 00:01:20.140
in this episode, so
we are gonna stay in Joey's inbox.

24
00:01:20.140 --> 00:01:24.410
Some of the things that we are going to
cover is gonna be a little bit of a review

25
00:01:24.410 --> 00:01:26.720
if you have seen the other episodes.

26
00:01:26.720 --> 00:01:30.237
But I just wanna gloss over them
a little bit, not necessarily gloss, but

27
00:01:30.237 --> 00:01:34.115
just review them, like I've already said,
so you get what I'm talking about.

28
00:01:34.115 --> 00:01:38.918
One of the first things we can
do is Show as conversations,

29
00:01:38.918 --> 00:01:44.222
Joey's inbox is showing as conversations,
did I turn it back?

30
00:01:44.222 --> 00:01:50.393
No it's not showing as conversations,

31
00:01:50.393 --> 00:01:54.260
JT was showing as conversations.

32
00:01:54.260 --> 00:01:58.300
Going back and forth a little bit but
that is something nice that I did this for

33
00:01:58.300 --> 00:02:01.220
a review of, why would you
wanna show those conversations?

34
00:02:01.220 --> 00:02:05.490
Well, it keeps it organized to me
as to we went back and forth, and

35
00:02:05.490 --> 00:02:10.020
it also shows me right in the inbox
when I have sent something.

36
00:02:10.020 --> 00:02:15.729
So i really like to see that and
the whole conversation,

37
00:02:15.729 --> 00:02:18.860
so I'm gonna click on that check box and
it is going to prompt me,

38
00:02:18.860 --> 00:02:22.380
do I want to do it for
this particular folder, or all mailboxes?

39
00:02:22.380 --> 00:02:28.276
I'm only in the inbox, All mailboxes
would be Drafts, Sent, your Junk mail,

40
00:02:28.276 --> 00:02:33.827
I wanna keep those separate but if you
wanted to do that option, you could.

41
00:02:33.827 --> 00:02:36.794
So I'm going to go ahead and
click on this folder and

42
00:02:36.794 --> 00:02:41.150
I can see that now I have some
conversations here, especially right here.

43
00:02:41.150 --> 00:02:44.470
This is the signature from
Justin Timberlake, it went back and

44
00:02:44.470 --> 00:02:49.660
forth a couple times and I can go ahead
and click the little drop down to see that

45
00:02:49.660 --> 00:02:54.130
Justin sent it, I responded as Joey.

46
00:02:54.130 --> 00:02:57.890
So you can see that that says Sent
over there and it is italicized, and

47
00:02:57.890 --> 00:03:02.780
then Justin said something back to me and
then Justin said something back

48
00:03:02.780 --> 00:03:07.140
to me again because I missed
something over in JT's inbox.

49
00:03:07.140 --> 00:03:09.570
So I like to Show as conversations,

50
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:12.700
that's one way that we can go ahead and
keep organized.

51
00:03:13.940 --> 00:03:18.797
All of these emails right now in my
inbox are marked as that I've read them,

52
00:03:18.797 --> 00:03:20.350
I've clicked on them.

53
00:03:20.350 --> 00:03:25.766
The reason I've read them though is
because I also have the reading paint over

54
00:03:25.766 --> 00:03:31.620
here on the right, set by default, to mark
it as Read after I've clicked off of it.

55
00:03:31.620 --> 00:03:35.890
But this is another way that I like
to try to keep myself organised,

56
00:03:35.890 --> 00:03:39.610
is, let me go ahead and
mark it as unread again.

57
00:03:39.610 --> 00:03:44.147
So when I come back in it's bold,
I get those visual indications,

58
00:03:44.147 --> 00:03:49.171
that you need to pay attention to this,
so if I wanted to mark that Lance's

59
00:03:49.171 --> 00:03:53.895
tour bus talk and this meeting
request that I have received from him.

60
00:03:53.895 --> 00:03:57.897
I haven't followed up with it just set,
marker is on Read,

61
00:03:57.897 --> 00:04:02.810
I right-click to get to him and
then I can mark right here as Unread.

62
00:04:02.810 --> 00:04:05.801
It takes it back to where
it is that bold and

63
00:04:05.801 --> 00:04:10.940
there's that indication in my inbox
also shows me the number one here.

64
00:04:10.940 --> 00:04:13.155
But about that reading pane,

65
00:04:13.155 --> 00:04:17.951
maybe I don't want the reading
pane to be treated as being read.

66
00:04:17.951 --> 00:04:19.930
Cuz sometimes I'm just clicking
back up through the emails and

67
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:21.434
I'm not really paying
attention to anything.

68
00:04:21.434 --> 00:04:24.918
>> Yeah, you wanna change that default
option to where it says, yeah, if you look

69
00:04:24.918 --> 00:04:28.230
at this email at all I'm just going to
go ahead and mark it as you read it.

70
00:04:28.230 --> 00:04:31.288
Even though a lot of the times you're
just scrolling through your inbox, and

71
00:04:31.288 --> 00:04:34.674
you click on something, and it says,
yeah, he read that, no, I didn't read it,

72
00:04:34.674 --> 00:04:35.918
I just happened to click on it.

73
00:04:35.918 --> 00:04:40.436
>> Yeah, and the way that I could
make sure that I can either mark it

74
00:04:40.436 --> 00:04:44.526
manually as I have read this,
or if I double click on it and

75
00:04:44.526 --> 00:04:50.310
actually open up the message,
then that's okay, I have read this email.

76
00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:54.468
You can change that reading pane setting
if you go over into your options,

77
00:04:54.468 --> 00:04:57.216
if you go over the file and
then you go to options,

78
00:04:57.216 --> 00:05:00.255
I wanna make sure it's in
the right place in the mail.

79
00:05:00.255 --> 00:05:05.358
And then if we scroll on down into, no,

80
00:05:05.358 --> 00:05:12.637
it's not there, I wrote it down,
there it is [LAUGH].

81
00:05:13.960 --> 00:05:16.909
>> Well, it says, Options, Mail, Reading
pane, and I'm looking for, I was like,

82
00:05:16.909 --> 00:05:18.294
that doesn't say Reading Pane [LAUGH].

83
00:05:18.294 --> 00:05:19.250
>> I know.

84
00:05:19.250 --> 00:05:23.671
So I probably should have put Compose
message, and then Reading pane,

85
00:05:23.671 --> 00:05:26.763
I need to make a note to check that,
in your notes so

86
00:05:26.763 --> 00:05:30.540
when you watch, or
look at them you have the right one.

87
00:05:30.540 --> 00:05:33.800
So I'm gonna come over to Reading pane,
customize how items are marked as read,

88
00:05:33.800 --> 00:05:38.580
that's where I wanna go,
I want to turn off here,

89
00:05:38.580 --> 00:05:41.640
mark item as red when selection changes.

90
00:05:41.640 --> 00:05:45.170
And that's where I'm selecting
my messages in my inbox,

91
00:05:45.170 --> 00:05:48.220
you uncheck that and
it will stop doing that.

92
00:05:49.230 --> 00:05:52.500
So that is a setting that I
would suggest doing to keep

93
00:05:52.500 --> 00:05:54.410
yourself a little bit more organized.

94
00:05:54.410 --> 00:05:58.300
Some of the other things you
can do to keep you organized,

95
00:05:58.300 --> 00:06:02.990
I'm a big color coder person,
I put sticky notes on everything.

96
00:06:02.990 --> 00:06:07.270
My pink sticky notes mean something
different than my blue sticky notes,

97
00:06:07.270 --> 00:06:10.802
then and my yellow sticky notes,
they mean something to me.

98
00:06:10.802 --> 00:06:14.413
[LAUGH] I don't actually remember
which one's are which right now.

99
00:06:14.413 --> 00:06:15.837
>> It's gonna be different on any given
day but it means something to you.

100
00:06:15.837 --> 00:06:20.458
>> Yeah, and I'm still getting into
my own flow of what they actually

101
00:06:20.458 --> 00:06:24.004
mean just right now, but
back at my old job, yeah,

102
00:06:24.004 --> 00:06:28.170
the sticky notes actually
meant something for real.

103
00:06:28.170 --> 00:06:32.630
So you could go ahead and
put categories on your e-mails,

104
00:06:32.630 --> 00:06:35.540
now categories expand across
everything in Outlook.

105
00:06:35.540 --> 00:06:39.740
It's not just an e-mail, you could
categorize or tag if you wanna say,

106
00:06:39.740 --> 00:06:45.200
a contact, you could tag a task,
you could tag a meeting,

107
00:06:45.200 --> 00:06:50.340
and that's where you have to know
that the orange tags mean something.

108
00:06:50.340 --> 00:06:53.920
Maybe orange tags are your
marketing projects and

109
00:06:53.920 --> 00:06:58.730
the blue tags are categories,
those are your HR categories.

110
00:07:00.430 --> 00:07:04.460
You set what the colors mean and
you can go ahead and

111
00:07:04.460 --> 00:07:08.480
set the names of those categories as well,
so

112
00:07:08.480 --> 00:07:13.080
how do I add a category to an email?

113
00:07:13.080 --> 00:07:17.740
Maybe we'll go with, here,
Lance, this thanks email,

114
00:07:17.740 --> 00:07:21.080
maybe we'll go with this one instead,
we'll go with Lance and the redirect Joey.

115
00:07:21.080 --> 00:07:24.810
I want to categorize this as green, you

116
00:07:26.020 --> 00:07:31.270
come over to your home tab and
on the home tab right there is Categorize.

117
00:07:31.270 --> 00:07:35.250
I believe you can also right-click and
you can categorize as well,

118
00:07:35.250 --> 00:07:38.200
so either way you wanna go,
did I say green?

119
00:07:38.200 --> 00:07:38.980
>> You did.
>> Yeah, okay well,

120
00:07:38.980 --> 00:07:42.010
so we'll go with green,
anything from Lance is green, and

121
00:07:42.010 --> 00:07:47.323
Lance is associated with
the green category [LAUGH].

122
00:07:47.323 --> 00:07:49.942
>> [LAUGH]
>> I just totally lost it there, so

123
00:07:49.942 --> 00:07:54.380
we're gonna go and say the Green
category and it has been applied,

124
00:07:54.380 --> 00:07:58.756
now if you have never used a category
before, it will prompt you.

125
00:07:58.756 --> 00:08:02.281
And the very first time you use it,
it's saying hey, so

126
00:08:02.281 --> 00:08:07.460
you really haven't used this before, do
you know what you want to say about this?

127
00:08:07.460 --> 00:08:10.700
So maybe we'll go with this business
card from Justin Timberlake.

128
00:08:10.700 --> 00:08:14.293
This is going to be categorized in the,
I don't know if I've used yellow before,

129
00:08:14.293 --> 00:08:14.875
there we go.

130
00:08:14.875 --> 00:08:18.747
So yellow, this is the first time,
do you wanna rename it, so

131
00:08:18.747 --> 00:08:21.840
it's not just saying yellow category?

132
00:08:21.840 --> 00:08:24.843
Maybe we could say that this
is associated with the band.

133
00:08:24.843 --> 00:08:29.310
And so anything that's associated with
the band is going to be colored yellow.

134
00:08:29.310 --> 00:08:32.560
And if you don't like yellow, you could go
ahead and choose all these other colors.

135
00:08:32.560 --> 00:08:33.835
Maybe some pinks in there and

136
00:08:33.835 --> 00:08:35.840
some purples-
>> Chartreuse.

137
00:08:35.840 --> 00:08:37.940
>> Chartreuse, I love a chartreuse.

138
00:08:37.940 --> 00:08:40.840
So we're [LAUGH] gonna keep the yellow.

139
00:08:40.840 --> 00:08:45.778
Say yes, and now I've started to catalog,
or categorize, our different things.

140
00:08:45.778 --> 00:08:53.058
Let's say maybe this is yellow as well,
and maybe this one is going to be yellow.

141
00:08:53.058 --> 00:08:56.970
I'm just getting a couple of different
things in there that have that category,

142
00:08:56.970 --> 00:08:59.400
because why would you wanna
keep it as a category?

143
00:08:59.400 --> 00:09:02.920
Because if you attach it with a category,
we get into searching.

144
00:09:02.920 --> 00:09:06.651
You could use that as one of your
criterias of what you are looking for.

145
00:09:06.651 --> 00:09:09.938
I know it's banned, and
I know I marked it.

146
00:09:09.938 --> 00:09:14.530
So show me everything that
has a category of yellow.

147
00:09:14.530 --> 00:09:19.135
And again,
crosses over to all items in Outlook.

148
00:09:19.135 --> 00:09:23.742
Another thing that you could do to give
you some more visual indications of hey,

149
00:09:23.742 --> 00:09:25.250
you know what?

150
00:09:25.250 --> 00:09:27.300
I need to make sure that
I don't forget this.

151
00:09:27.300 --> 00:09:32.750
And this is a system that I implemented
a lot when I was back at the university.

152
00:09:32.750 --> 00:09:38.140
It's flagging my emails that I
need to follow up with this.

153
00:09:38.140 --> 00:09:44.770
So maybe this one here, my Lance tour bus,
I definitely need to not forget this.

154
00:09:44.770 --> 00:09:48.224
Just click the little red flag
that's off to the right hand side.

155
00:09:48.224 --> 00:09:51.660
>> I remember I used to do flagging, and
there would be on the right hand pane

156
00:09:51.660 --> 00:09:55.950
next to the reading pane, it would give me
a list of all the ones that I had flagged.

157
00:09:55.950 --> 00:09:58.550
So I could just easily and
quickly reference those.

158
00:09:58.550 --> 00:10:01.510
>> Yes, and
that's how we can customize our views.

159
00:10:01.510 --> 00:10:07.400
So while we're talking about it, it's the
view, and it's your to do bar over here.

160
00:10:07.400 --> 00:10:10.770
And so you can go ahead and
go to your tasks, and those are the ones.

161
00:10:10.770 --> 00:10:13.960
And because the flags are not
just like a follow up for

162
00:10:13.960 --> 00:10:18.570
you in email, it is associated with tasks.

163
00:10:18.570 --> 00:10:21.400
Tasks are a specific
place in Outlook that,

164
00:10:21.400 --> 00:10:26.470
well, they're tasks that you have to do,
and that's why they call it a to do list.

165
00:10:26.470 --> 00:10:28.719
And then all of these
emails that are here,

166
00:10:28.719 --> 00:10:32.000
that these are the ones
that I've already flagged.

167
00:10:32.000 --> 00:10:35.950
Now right now,
Lance's email about the tour bus talk,

168
00:10:35.950 --> 00:10:39.740
it's not showing anything but
the red flag off to the right.

169
00:10:39.740 --> 00:10:44.020
If I scroll down to some other emails,
like right here,

170
00:10:44.020 --> 00:10:48.200
I flagged this one a while ago, and
look at what color it is, it's red.

171
00:10:48.200 --> 00:10:53.340
So I know that if I'm going through
my inbox and I see red emails,

172
00:10:53.340 --> 00:10:57.430
that's something that I have marked
as you need to follow up with this.

173
00:10:57.430 --> 00:10:58.353
And so okay,

174
00:10:58.353 --> 00:11:02.140
I need to make sure that Lance is
going to be followed up with this.

175
00:11:02.140 --> 00:11:03.230
This is everyone in the to field,

176
00:11:03.230 --> 00:11:07.160
this is when we're going back and
forth with creating our messages.

177
00:11:07.160 --> 00:11:10.650
Let's say I did this,
maybe he wanted me to water his plants or

178
00:11:10.650 --> 00:11:11.320
something like that.

179
00:11:11.320 --> 00:11:12.692
So I went ahead and did that.

180
00:11:12.692 --> 00:11:16.162
I wanna check this off as being completed,
click on it.

181
00:11:16.162 --> 00:11:19.226
And now that has become
a little green checkmark.

182
00:11:19.226 --> 00:11:20.714
So it's a nice, like,
I've done it and notice-

183
00:11:20.714 --> 00:11:21.370
>> It's a checklist.

184
00:11:21.370 --> 00:11:23.002
>> Yeah,
that's exactly what a checklist is.

185
00:11:23.002 --> 00:11:24.481
At least, well, it is a checklist.

186
00:11:24.481 --> 00:11:25.637
[LAUGH]
>> It is a checklist,

187
00:11:25.637 --> 00:11:26.466
literally a checklist.

188
00:11:26.466 --> 00:11:29.501
[LAUGH]
>> It's literally a checklist, and

189
00:11:29.501 --> 00:11:34.102
it has come off of my to do pane over
here on the right hand side that

190
00:11:34.102 --> 00:11:37.695
I was using in my view
while customizing our view.

191
00:11:37.695 --> 00:11:41.025
And we'll turn that off,
come back over to home.

192
00:11:41.025 --> 00:11:43.331
And so those are some
different things you can do.

193
00:11:43.331 --> 00:11:46.551
The other things I would suggest is make
sure that you're always checking your

194
00:11:46.551 --> 00:11:47.248
drafts folder.

195
00:11:47.248 --> 00:11:49.845
Your drafts folder are the ones
that you're using as,

196
00:11:49.845 --> 00:11:51.715
whether you're saving it on purpose.

197
00:11:51.715 --> 00:11:55.764
And we talked about that auto-saving in
some of our other episodes of where I've

198
00:11:55.764 --> 00:11:59.218
actually come back to my draft folder
maybe like every couple weeks,

199
00:11:59.218 --> 00:12:02.360
and there's a whole bunch of
emails that are just blank.

200
00:12:02.360 --> 00:12:06.380
Blank, blank, blank, blank, blank because
it just auto-saved, and it just was like,

201
00:12:06.380 --> 00:12:08.500
I'm leaving for the day, close, close,
close, close, close, close, close.

202
00:12:08.500 --> 00:12:11.000
And I've got all this stuff just
hanging out in my drafts folder.

203
00:12:11.000 --> 00:12:15.250
So come in here, clean it up,
delete the ones that you need to delete.

204
00:12:15.250 --> 00:12:20.140
Another thing to keep you organized,
make sure you go and delete your trash,

205
00:12:20.140 --> 00:12:21.900
your deleted items.

206
00:12:21.900 --> 00:12:24.420
Because we talked about that,
once you delete something,

207
00:12:24.420 --> 00:12:26.220
it doesn't actually delete delete.

208
00:12:26.220 --> 00:12:28.620
It's still kinda hanging
out in the trash can.

209
00:12:28.620 --> 00:12:32.580
This will also help you with space,
keeping you organized that way.

210
00:12:32.580 --> 00:12:36.170
So, emptying your trash can here, and

211
00:12:36.170 --> 00:12:40.090
then this is permanently deleting it,
that will help you keep organized and

212
00:12:40.090 --> 00:12:43.120
even just organized more for,
like I said, mailbox size.

213
00:12:44.250 --> 00:12:46.930
You could also use
what's known as cleanup.

214
00:12:46.930 --> 00:12:50.162
Now cleaning up is just
what it sounds like.

215
00:12:50.162 --> 00:12:54.975
It's gonna clean up your inbox,
or clean up a conversation.

216
00:12:54.975 --> 00:12:58.970
Cleanup is used to where maybe
you have a conversation, so

217
00:12:58.970 --> 00:13:01.920
you need to have things
shown as a conversation.

218
00:13:01.920 --> 00:13:04.618

00:23:21.248 --> 00:23:23.877
Just drag, drop, let go.

453
00:23:23.877 --> 00:23:25.580
>> Give it a little droppy.

454
00:23:25.580 --> 00:23:26.510
>> [LAUGH] Give it a little droppy drop.

455
00:23:26.510 --> 00:23:30.100
So I have in here, now if I click it.

456
00:23:30.100 --> 00:23:33.370
This is the email that is
associated with Lance.

457
00:23:33.370 --> 00:23:35.150
Come back out to the inbox.

458
00:23:35.150 --> 00:23:41.860
Let's scroll up a little bit,
find one from just Justin.

459
00:23:41.860 --> 00:23:45.000
Hey, come on, there you are.

460
00:23:45.000 --> 00:23:47.160
Justin needs to come over into his folder.

461
00:23:47.160 --> 00:23:49.624
Click, hold, and drag.

462
00:23:49.624 --> 00:23:51.450
I think you get the idea here.

463
00:23:51.450 --> 00:23:56.423
Taking things from the inbox
in my big all inclusive inbox.

464
00:23:56.423 --> 00:24:01.970
Start filing you away into the places
where I want you to go into to keep myself

465
00:24:01.970 --> 00:24:02.890
organized.

466
00:24:02.890 --> 00:24:06.410
Keep my brain in check,
make sure I know what I'm doing,

467
00:24:06.410 --> 00:24:08.680
and that is something that you can do.

468
00:24:08.680 --> 00:24:11.632
So I know that I wanna talk
about customizing our views and

469
00:24:11.632 --> 00:24:13.301
I also wanna talk about search.

470
00:24:13.301 --> 00:24:15.479
But I have a lot to say about that.

471
00:24:15.479 --> 00:24:17.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I can see you over there saying-

472
00:24:17.670 --> 00:24:19.703
>> Maybe a little more than the time

473
00:24:19.703 --> 00:24:21.520
allotted for this episode?

474
00:24:21.520 --> 00:24:22.909
>> Exactly, and why do I know that?

475
00:24:22.909 --> 00:24:24.620
Cuz you're giving me the signal.

476
00:24:24.620 --> 00:24:25.120
>> I am.
>> [LAUGH]

477
00:24:25.120 --> 00:24:27.049
>> I'm standing here like listen here

478
00:24:27.049 --> 00:24:28.183
girl, it is time.
>> [LAUGH]

479
00:24:28.183 --> 00:24:29.643
>> We're getting run out of time.

480
00:24:29.643 --> 00:24:31.129
I know how much because we have the notes

481
00:24:31.129 --> 00:24:32.713
in front of us, so I know
>> [LAUGH] Yes.

482
00:24:32.713 --> 00:24:33.760
>> I know she has a bit more to go, but

483
00:24:33.760 --> 00:24:36.523
Vonne that is totally fine.
We can just roll this right into one of

484
00:24:36.523 --> 00:24:37.785
our famous part two's,

485
00:24:37.785 --> 00:24:39.348
which I enjoy doing with you.
>> Yes.

486
00:24:39.348 --> 00:24:40.000
>> Hopefully,

487
00:24:40.000 --> 00:24:44.029
you enjoy that with us as well, but like
we said, we're kind of skirting the line

488
00:24:44.029 --> 00:24:45.639
here when it comes to the time.
>> [LAUGH]

489
00:24:45.639 --> 00:24:46.693
>> So we're gonna call this a day.

490
00:24:46.693 --> 00:24:47.790
We're gonna call this an episode,

491
00:24:47.790 --> 00:24:50.779
we'll come back for that part two.
We do thank you for joining us, but

492
00:24:50.779 --> 00:24:53.610
signing off for OfficeProTV.
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

493
00:24:53.610 --> 00:24:54.543
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

494
00:24:54.543 --> 00:24:55.486
>> And we'll see you next time.

495
00:24:55.486 --> 00:24:59.589
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne look at tools and functions that aid in organizing, customizing, and searching in Outlook 2016. Here they cover using the View tab, Preview views, and Grouping, as well as using the Search bar.
episodes.title: Organize, Customize and Search Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:07.086
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.086 --> 00:00:10.660
Greetings everyone, and welcome to
another great episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:10.660 --> 00:00:12.070
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

4
00:00:12.070 --> 00:00:13.720
And in today's episode, that's right,

5
00:00:13.720 --> 00:00:16.950
we're back with more on
our Outlook 2016 series.

6
00:00:16.950 --> 00:00:20.700
Specifically, well you know,
Part 2 of Customization, Organization,

7
00:00:20.700 --> 00:00:24.400
and Searching through your
Outlook device there.

8
00:00:24.400 --> 00:00:27.480
And joining us in the studio to
help continue that conversation

9
00:00:27.480 --> 00:00:29.205
our good friend Ms Vonne Smith.

10
00:00:29.205 --> 00:00:30.130
Vonne, we're so glad to have you again.

11
00:00:30.130 --> 00:00:30.920
How's it going today?

12
00:00:30.920 --> 00:00:34.785
>> It's great, glad to be back for
Organize, Customize, and Search.

13
00:00:34.785 --> 00:00:36.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I just love that.

14
00:00:36.990 --> 00:00:38.490
I really wanna cheer it out.

15
00:00:38.490 --> 00:00:39.650
>> Man, I'm telling you.

16
00:00:39.650 --> 00:00:41.920
>> [LAUGH] So yes, we are back for Part 2.

17
00:00:41.920 --> 00:00:44.270
We had talked about the different
ways we can organize ourselves.

18
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:48.020
Now we're gonna move on to
the customize and search.

19
00:00:49.260 --> 00:00:50.090
Jump right in, let's get started.

20
00:00:50.090 --> 00:00:51.530
>> Hit the ground running.

21
00:00:51.530 --> 00:00:55.230
>> Yes, and we have done some of
these things in our other episodes.

22
00:00:55.230 --> 00:00:56.120
And actually, in our Part 1,

23
00:00:56.120 --> 00:00:58.910
you talked about the To Do list
over on the right hand side.

24
00:00:58.910 --> 00:01:00.720
I remember that that was over there and

25
00:01:00.720 --> 00:01:03.650
that is a customization that
we can do in our views.

26
00:01:03.650 --> 00:01:06.510
We also talked about this a lot
in our Outlook interface.

27
00:01:06.510 --> 00:01:08.950
So let's just go and
review really quickly.

28
00:01:08.950 --> 00:01:13.470
On the View tab, these buttons
over onto the right hand side.

29
00:01:13.470 --> 00:01:15.910
The folder pane is off to the left, and

30
00:01:15.910 --> 00:01:18.400
that is where you want to
keep it either normal.

31
00:01:18.400 --> 00:01:19.490
I like it as normal.

32
00:01:19.490 --> 00:01:23.650
I don't want to really keep it as
minimized cuz then I don't see

33
00:01:23.650 --> 00:01:28.440
all of the folders and it's just not
the way that I'm used to seeing it.

34
00:01:28.440 --> 00:01:31.250
But if you wanted to,
you're more than welcome to do that.

35
00:01:31.250 --> 00:01:32.730
I'm gonna put that back over here.

36
00:01:32.730 --> 00:01:34.950
The reading pane is the one on the right.

37
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:38.490
If you wanted to keep that,
it's the default setting so

38
00:01:38.490 --> 00:01:40.900
I've got used to that way.

39
00:01:40.900 --> 00:01:44.530
But maybe you don't want the reading pane.

40
00:01:44.530 --> 00:01:48.120
Turn it off.
The To Do is where you can choose to put

41
00:01:48.120 --> 00:01:53.456
the calendar, your people and/or
your tasks over on that pane.

42
00:01:53.456 --> 00:01:55.650
Actually the tasks are behind
my head right there.

43
00:01:55.650 --> 00:02:00.270
And so you can go ahead and
organize the ones that you want to do and

44
00:02:00.270 --> 00:02:02.172
you can scroll through them.

45
00:02:02.172 --> 00:02:06.090
And I can keep them on or
keep them off, if I wanted to.

46
00:02:06.090 --> 00:02:09.290
I'll take that To Do bar off.

47
00:02:09.290 --> 00:02:12.850
The people pane is something that
you could use to where it puts it at

48
00:02:12.850 --> 00:02:15.640
the bottom of the email messages.

49
00:02:15.640 --> 00:02:20.160
And actually the people pane, and
the reading pane, the folder pane,

50
00:02:20.160 --> 00:02:23.680
it does not matter if
you are in the mail or

51
00:02:23.680 --> 00:02:28.550
the calendar or your contacts all of
these buttons are going to be available

52
00:02:28.550 --> 00:02:33.400
to you because they are kind of
fundamental pieces of Outlook.

53
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:37.970
But I will say your reading pane and
your people pane,

54
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:42.190
they look a little different
if you're in say the calendar.

55
00:02:42.190 --> 00:02:46.330
The calendar is going to be the reading
pane on the actual meeting,

56
00:02:46.330 --> 00:02:48.740
it's not going to be on your email.

57
00:02:48.740 --> 00:02:54.470
So we normally associate with reading
an email, but does go across other areas.

58
00:02:54.470 --> 00:02:58.020
So those are all things
that we have done before.

59
00:02:58.020 --> 00:03:01.280
And coming over here to the left
hand side of our View tab,

60
00:03:01.280 --> 00:03:06.490
we have different ways that we can look at
it, it's like a theme, if you wanna say.

61
00:03:06.490 --> 00:03:12.420
The compact view that we're looking at
now is what we're looking at right now.

62
00:03:12.420 --> 00:03:17.820
If I click on single,
this puts everything into single lines.

63
00:03:17.820 --> 00:03:23.142
And if I come over here to Preview, the
preview just takes off the reading pane,

64
00:03:23.142 --> 00:03:25.929
puts everything into a columnized list.

65
00:03:25.929 --> 00:03:30.322
And it's kind of like in Windows Explorer
where you can show as icons or

66
00:03:30.322 --> 00:03:31.300
show details.

67
00:03:31.300 --> 00:03:34.495
You can show all the details
of like the file size and

68
00:03:34.495 --> 00:03:37.070
like the date that it was created.

69
00:03:37.070 --> 00:03:40.024
I usually like that view because
I want to see all these pieces.

70
00:03:40.024 --> 00:03:44.720
So I can see from this Details view
that I have different columns.

71
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:48.810
And across the top, I have these
row headers, where the exclamation,

72
00:03:48.810 --> 00:03:50.370
that's our importance.

73
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:55.420
I have my alert, if I have set
a reminder for that, if what type of

74
00:03:55.420 --> 00:04:01.890
icon that that is associated with, either
like a forward, or a medium request.

75
00:04:01.890 --> 00:04:03.490
The from, the subject received,

76
00:04:03.490 --> 00:04:08.200
think you can kinda read them across
to see that the different categories or

77
00:04:08.200 --> 00:04:11.380
column headers,
that you have within this particular view.

78
00:04:12.470 --> 00:04:18.080
You can change all of this, you could add
new columns, you could move them around.

79
00:04:18.080 --> 00:04:22.076
Maybe you want to have the subject first,
and then who it's from.

80
00:04:22.076 --> 00:04:25.410
Maybe you want it to have received
as the first thing that you see

81
00:04:25.410 --> 00:04:26.510
after these little icons.

82
00:04:26.510 --> 00:04:28.730
Maybe you don't want any
of these icon columns.

83
00:04:28.730 --> 00:04:32.760
You can go crazy with how
much you want to change this.

84
00:04:32.760 --> 00:04:37.610
In this particular view,
you also can change the column widths.

85
00:04:37.610 --> 00:04:41.150
You get the line with the two
pointed arrows on either side and

86
00:04:41.150 --> 00:04:45.800
you can change how wide or how not wide

87
00:04:45.800 --> 00:04:50.560
you want one of these columns
to show the information.

88
00:04:50.560 --> 00:04:52.730
Maybe the subject would
be a little bit bigger.

89
00:04:52.730 --> 00:04:54.440
Whoops, I actually just sorted it.

90
00:04:54.440 --> 00:04:57.730
The subject would be a little bit
bigger than the received or from.

91
00:04:57.730 --> 00:04:59.940
I want received over on that side.

92
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:01.455
You just click, hold, and drag it.

93
00:05:01.455 --> 00:05:06.776
Click+hold drag and you just watch for
those little red lines that come

94
00:05:06.776 --> 00:05:12.020
to show you where it's going to be in
that new location when you let go.

95
00:05:12.020 --> 00:05:19.270
And now you can see that I'm reordering or
restructuring what columns are where.

96
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:24.130
The little triangle things on the top
of each one of these columns,

97
00:05:24.130 --> 00:05:25.710
these are your sorts.

98
00:05:25.710 --> 00:05:32.100
Now we will get into the sort and
search in just little bit.

99
00:05:32.100 --> 00:05:35.502
Since we are here,
the receive means it is going to show like

100
00:05:35.502 --> 00:05:40.760
this is the latest date on top,
like the newest.

101
00:05:40.760 --> 00:05:42.020
So if I scroll up.

102
00:05:42.020 --> 00:05:43.440
So here's today.

103
00:05:43.440 --> 00:05:47.750
If I click on here it's
going to sort by the oldest.

104
00:05:47.750 --> 00:05:52.330
So those are some quick ways within
this particular view that you can sort.

105
00:05:52.330 --> 00:05:55.050
Maybe I want to sort from the person.

106
00:05:55.050 --> 00:05:56.759
From Justin and then from Justin.

107
00:05:56.759 --> 00:05:59.070
[LAUGH] There's a lot
of things from Justin.

108
00:05:59.070 --> 00:06:02.721
There we go, Yammer,
so you can see Yammer,

109
00:06:02.721 --> 00:06:07.633
this is sorting descending as
oppose to sorting ascending.

110
00:06:07.633 --> 00:06:12.531
And so, b, there we go, so the band Boys,
is the one that's going to be in

111
00:06:12.531 --> 00:06:16.334
the first thing of our ascending
order of the from field.

112
00:06:16.334 --> 00:06:20.930
So you can change it right from dragging
and dropping and changing the columns.

113
00:06:20.930 --> 00:06:24.520
But the other columns, I wanna add,
say like a sensitivity column,

114
00:06:24.520 --> 00:06:29.030
cuz we talked about adding sensitivity
levels in our email options,

115
00:06:29.030 --> 00:06:31.040
in our advanced features episode.

116
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:32.310
I don't see that in here.

117
00:06:33.390 --> 00:06:37.320
Over on the left hand side,
you can customize these view settings.

118
00:06:37.320 --> 00:06:41.507
When you come into your Advanced View
settings in the columns,

119
00:06:41.507 --> 00:06:45.062
that first option right there,
this is where it shows

120
00:06:45.062 --> 00:06:49.027
you the columns that in this
particular view in this order.

121
00:06:49.027 --> 00:06:53.000
And these are all of
the different properties or

122
00:06:53.000 --> 00:06:58.175
columns that are available for
you to see your list of emails.

123
00:06:58.175 --> 00:07:01.410
The one that I had set
was the sensitivity.

124
00:07:01.410 --> 00:07:03.885
I wanna bring that over,
so I click on the left.

125
00:07:03.885 --> 00:07:08.290
Tell it come on over by
clicking the add on the right.

126
00:07:08.290 --> 00:07:12.016
I don't want the sensitivity to be on
the very last column, so you click and

127
00:07:12.016 --> 00:07:12.950
move it up.

128
00:07:12.950 --> 00:07:15.740
I can click the move up button
to put it whatever I want.

129
00:07:15.740 --> 00:07:19.151
You might go ahead and
put it in the very beginning.

130
00:07:19.151 --> 00:07:21.067
Click OK.
We'll come back to this is just a sec and

131
00:07:21.067 --> 00:07:23.190
go through some of these other ones.

132
00:07:23.190 --> 00:07:28.020
And you can see the results of the
sensitivity now has it's own column within

133
00:07:28.020 --> 00:07:30.040
this Preview view.

134
00:07:31.350 --> 00:07:35.520
Other things that I could set,
the Group By, this is the one that where

135
00:07:35.520 --> 00:07:40.780
it's grouping by the today,
or last week, or yesterday.

136
00:07:40.780 --> 00:07:42.060
That's on by default.

137
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:46.795
But you could also if you wanted to have
it stop grouping automatically based on

138
00:07:46.795 --> 00:07:47.953
the arrangement.

139
00:07:47.953 --> 00:07:53.179
So if I had arranged this to be by
the To field or by the Subject,

140
00:07:53.179 --> 00:07:57.212
then it would group it
in automatically for me.

141
00:07:57.212 --> 00:08:00.854
I can choose to group it by,
let's say, and

142
00:08:00.854 --> 00:08:05.110
this is where we could go,
we could say from.

143
00:08:05.110 --> 00:08:06.930
Who is it from, and then by?

144
00:08:06.930 --> 00:08:11.790
So you can have multiple
level types of grouping, and

145
00:08:11.790 --> 00:08:13.920
I guess in the same sense sorting as well.

146
00:08:13.920 --> 00:08:16.189
It is sorting your information around.

147
00:08:17.790 --> 00:08:21.160
So we could choose which one and
let's say by attachment.

148
00:08:21.160 --> 00:08:24.840
So who it's from and
then with the attachment click OK.

149
00:08:24.840 --> 00:08:25.870
Click OK.

150
00:08:25.870 --> 00:08:28.670
Well, I can tell you right now
I'm starting to get a, actually,

151
00:08:28.670 --> 00:08:31.330
I don't even know what I'm
looking at anymore [LAUGH].

152
00:08:31.330 --> 00:08:33.380
>> You've really gone
berserk on this thing.

153
00:08:33.380 --> 00:08:34.390
>> I have, yes.

154
00:08:34.390 --> 00:08:38.540
But it is, but
you can see from Joey by attachments.

155
00:08:38.540 --> 00:08:41.550
I don't really have a lot of attachments,
so

156
00:08:41.550 --> 00:08:46.670
that might not have been the best
criteria to go ahead and group by.

157
00:08:46.670 --> 00:08:51.220
But I hope you're getting the idea
here is that you can sit here and

158
00:08:51.220 --> 00:08:57.210
customize to your heart's content
to how you want to see this view.

159
00:08:57.210 --> 00:09:01.990
Now, I already said I'm kinda getting
a little far off the track where like, so,

160
00:09:01.990 --> 00:09:04.070
can we just go back to
the way it used to be?

161
00:09:04.070 --> 00:09:08.284
>> Yeah, I love, I always end up tweaking
these things to where they're unusable.

162
00:09:08.284 --> 00:09:09.640
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,

163
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:12.085
kinda like what I'm doing right now.

164
00:09:12.085 --> 00:09:13.560
[LAUGH] You can always reset it.

165
00:09:13.560 --> 00:09:15.240
Yay, reset button.

166
00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:17.700
Over here on the left-hand side.

167
00:09:17.700 --> 00:09:20.910
You click it, are you sure you
would like to reset the preview?

168
00:09:20.910 --> 00:09:24.360
Remember, we had the compact,
preview, and single?

169
00:09:24.360 --> 00:09:28.100
I want to set the preview back
to its original settings.

170
00:09:28.100 --> 00:09:31.150
You click yes, and phew,
okay, now it's good.

171
00:09:31.150 --> 00:09:31.965
>> Things look normal.

172
00:09:31.965 --> 00:09:32.551
[LAUGH]
>> Yes.

173
00:09:32.551 --> 00:09:35.080
[LAUGH] We're back to where we started,
but

174
00:09:35.080 --> 00:09:37.010
that's the nice thing,
it's like a safety net.

175
00:09:37.010 --> 00:09:39.160
So get in there, dig in there,

176
00:09:39.160 --> 00:09:43.780
customize it cuz maybe you might find I
really like this, for you to keep it.

177
00:09:43.780 --> 00:09:46.690
And then you can move on and then if you
don't like it you can always reset it.

178
00:09:46.690 --> 00:09:52.600
A few of the ones that I did want to point
out that I had been using to help me in

179
00:09:52.600 --> 00:09:56.860
what I'm looking at, it's the customizing,
but then it goes back into the organizing.

180
00:09:56.860 --> 00:09:58.848
So organize and customize.

181
00:09:58.848 --> 00:10:04.920
[LAUGH] Go into view, we have our other
settings and the conditional formats.

182
00:10:04.920 --> 00:10:07.150
The other settings in here.

183
00:10:07.150 --> 00:10:12.960
What is the font of my column heading,
my column fonts and my row fonts.

184
00:10:12.960 --> 00:10:13.950
What does that mean?

185
00:10:13.950 --> 00:10:16.450
I'm gonna click OK, and OK here.

186
00:10:16.450 --> 00:10:20.780
Your rows are basically the list

that sent me that email about

422
00:21:49.990 --> 00:21:52.492
the cheese that I'm gonna bring.

423
00:21:52.492 --> 00:21:54.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because I was talking about the cheese.

424
00:21:54.440 --> 00:21:58.030
[LAUGH] So you can come into here,
let's say Justin Timberlake.

425
00:21:58.030 --> 00:22:00.659
I don't have a lot of people that
we've been emailing back and forth on.

426
00:22:00.659 --> 00:22:06.850
But if you right-click on that message,
the find related, that's a big one for me.

427
00:22:06.850 --> 00:22:07.680
I love this one.

428
00:22:07.680 --> 00:22:11.096
So find related, people,
messages within this conversation,

429
00:22:11.096 --> 00:22:12.686
message from the sender.

430
00:22:12.686 --> 00:22:15.310
That's what I want to do and
then it's going to go ahead and

431
00:22:15.310 --> 00:22:17.380
find all of the different messages.

432
00:22:17.380 --> 00:22:20.940
If I had right-clicked,
let me right-click on this one.

433
00:22:20.940 --> 00:22:22.330
I could go ahead and find related.

434
00:22:22.330 --> 00:22:26.481
Notice that depending on what is in
that message, say, a category or

435
00:22:26.481 --> 00:22:28.208
a conversation or a center.

436
00:22:28.208 --> 00:22:31.938
It's going to give you different
options of what it's going to be,

437
00:22:31.938 --> 00:22:35.190
the thing that it's finding
that is relatable to.

438
00:22:35.190 --> 00:22:40.570
So just make a note of that one and
also remember to clear out your searches.

439
00:22:40.570 --> 00:22:41.270
There's been times,

440
00:22:41.270 --> 00:22:45.960
where I'm like, why is this look this way,
I'm still in this search.

441
00:22:45.960 --> 00:22:51.187
It is filtering out, emails or
messages that I don't want,

442
00:22:51.187 --> 00:22:53.860
so go ahead and close that out.

443
00:22:53.860 --> 00:22:58.125
And the other thing, that we've already
gone over, in the preview view,

444
00:22:58.125 --> 00:22:59.700
was the sorting.

445
00:22:59.700 --> 00:23:05.010
Up at the top, we do have the,
what are we arranging our messages by?

446
00:23:05.010 --> 00:23:09.900
The by date or
I could arrange it by the from or the to,

447
00:23:09.900 --> 00:23:13.310
and those are the different
columns that we were clicking on.

448
00:23:13.310 --> 00:23:18.320
And then what order do I want them to be,
newest or oldest?

449
00:23:18.320 --> 00:23:23.210
And depending on if I had switched this
let's say on over to attachments, so

450
00:23:23.210 --> 00:23:26.090
anything with an attachment that's
the one that I would use a lot because I

451
00:23:26.090 --> 00:23:27.420
know they sent it.

452
00:23:27.420 --> 00:23:30.790
So if I just sort it by attachments,

453
00:23:30.790 --> 00:23:35.000
then I can start kind of
drilling down from there.

454
00:23:36.180 --> 00:23:40.530
And then, with or without, so all of
these different buttons will change,

455
00:23:40.530 --> 00:23:44.760
depending on what you are going to
sort by and that can sometimes help.

456
00:23:44.760 --> 00:23:49.280
This is the, depending on the time
that you're watching this video,

457
00:23:49.280 --> 00:23:54.090
the old way that things look,
we did that focused inbox back on JT,

458
00:23:54.090 --> 00:23:58.360
oops my Virtual Machine shut down so
let's go ahead and bring it up.

459
00:23:58.360 --> 00:24:00.077
And of course, now I got to login.

460
00:24:00.077 --> 00:24:01.130
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

461
00:24:01.130 --> 00:24:02.950
>> But JT has the newer or

462
00:24:02.950 --> 00:24:04.830
the focused inbox.

463
00:24:04.830 --> 00:24:09.740
And so, his mail up at the top,
it doesn't say the,

464
00:24:09.740 --> 00:24:13.450
well I'm trying to talk and
do, whoops that's wrong too.

465
00:24:13.450 --> 00:24:17.450
Okay well, we have done this
in the focused inbox episode.

466
00:24:17.450 --> 00:24:18.200
There we go!

467
00:24:18.200 --> 00:24:20.585
Thank you, thank you good old fast Mac.

468
00:24:20.585 --> 00:24:22.578
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] If I was just,

469
00:24:22.578 --> 00:24:24.212
that was a PEBCAK Error.

470
00:24:24.212 --> 00:24:25.352
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah it was. [LAUGH] >> Yes,

471
00:24:25.352 --> 00:24:29.820
if you don't know what a PEBCAK Error is.
It's one of my favorite.

472
00:24:29.820 --> 00:24:33.215
Problem exists between keyboard and chair.

473
00:24:33.215 --> 00:24:34.609
Well, I'm not sitting [LAUGH].

474
00:24:34.609 --> 00:24:36.620
>> Yeah there's no chair but
you get the idea.

475
00:24:36.620 --> 00:24:38.700
>> What's between the keyboard and
the chair?

476
00:24:38.700 --> 00:24:39.914
>> Vonne Smith.

477
00:24:39.914 --> 00:24:42.960
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I love that one.

478
00:24:42.960 --> 00:24:46.780
So you can see that JT's inbox does
not have those same buttons, but

479
00:24:46.780 --> 00:24:50.700
it's all right here in that
drop down over to the right.

480
00:24:50.700 --> 00:24:54.920
And so you can go ahead and sort and
what is it being arranged by, so

481
00:24:54.920 --> 00:25:00.690
it's still there just in a newer,
fancier look, the focused inbox.

482
00:25:00.690 --> 00:25:05.645
But I feel that those are all
different things that you can do to

483
00:25:05.645 --> 00:25:10.230
keep yourself organized,
customized, and searched.

484
00:25:10.230 --> 00:25:11.196
[LAUGH]
>> Searchized.

485
00:25:11.196 --> 00:25:13.960
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, okay, that one fell down.

486
00:25:13.960 --> 00:25:14.770
But, yes.

487
00:25:14.770 --> 00:25:16.755
>> It's like going to the TSA with you.

488
00:25:16.755 --> 00:25:18.601
[LAUGH] I've been searched.

489
00:25:18.601 --> 00:25:21.245
>> [LAUGH] Hey, you can find it in here.

490
00:25:21.245 --> 00:25:22.206
>> That's right, it's in there.

491
00:25:22.206 --> 00:25:23.245
>> And you know how.

492
00:25:23.245 --> 00:25:26.814
>> All right, Vonne, thanks for so
much for to helping us keep organized,

493
00:25:26.814 --> 00:25:28.813
customized and searched, if you will.

494
00:25:28.813 --> 00:25:30.140
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

495
00:25:30.140 --> 00:25:31.230
>> We do appreciate that.

496
00:25:31.230 --> 00:25:32.770
We appreciate our viewers for watching but

497
00:25:32.770 --> 00:25:35.810
it looks like that is the culmination
of our two little episodes here.

498
00:25:35.810 --> 00:25:37.430
But we've got more to come
when it comes to Outlook.

499
00:25:37.430 --> 00:25:39.630
So definitely join us for those.

500
00:25:39.630 --> 00:25:43.201
But signing off for our OfficeProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

501
00:25:43.201 --> 00:25:44.005
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

502
00:25:44.005 --> 00:25:45.581
>> We'll see you next time.

503
00:25:45.581 --> 00:25:50.382
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne explore employing rules and automation to reduce the time needed to complete repetitive tasks and increase productivity. Watch here as they explain and demonstrate Quick Parts, Quick Steps, Tap, Rules, and Out-of-Office replies.
episodes.title: Rules and Automation
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.081
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.081 --> 00:00:09.890
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another great episode of OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:09.890 --> 00:00:12.860
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode, well,

4
00:00:12.860 --> 00:00:17.210
we're coming back at you with
more of our Outlook 2016 series.

5
00:00:17.210 --> 00:00:21.020
Joining us in the studio, the Outlook
mistress herself, Miss Vonne Smith.

6
00:00:21.020 --> 00:00:22.796
Miss Vonne Smith, welcome,
how's it going today?

7
00:00:22.796 --> 00:00:24.502
>> I like that title [LAUGH].

8
00:00:24.502 --> 00:00:28.274
>> We give her cool titles
that she enjoys [LAUGH].

9
00:00:28.274 --> 00:00:31.950
>> Yeah, so we are here today to
talk about rules and automation.

10
00:00:31.950 --> 00:00:33.864
Actually I had to look down,
I'm like, which one are we doing?

11
00:00:33.864 --> 00:00:38.700
We are doing rules and automation, we're
going to be faster and leaner, and quicker

12
00:00:38.700 --> 00:00:43.460
and meaner, and sounds like we're training
for a boxing match or something [LAUGH].

13
00:00:43.460 --> 00:00:46.505
But this is just ways that we
could go ahead and start, well,

14
00:00:46.505 --> 00:00:50.350
automating some of our tests that we do
in Outlook to make us more efficient.

15
00:00:50.350 --> 00:00:55.048
So let's jump down into Justin's email,
because I wanted to give you an example

16
00:00:55.048 --> 00:00:58.158
of the finished product of
where we're going to, and

17
00:00:58.158 --> 00:01:01.079
the first one that we gonna
do is just Quick Parts.

18
00:01:01.079 --> 00:01:06.577
Well, Quick Parts, putting in parts of
an email that, well, are quick [LAUGH].

19
00:01:06.577 --> 00:01:08.317
>> [LAUGH] Very descriptive.

20
00:01:08.317 --> 00:01:09.583
>> I know, right?

21
00:01:09.583 --> 00:01:11.275
>> Tell us more about that
thing you said [LAUGH].

22
00:01:11.275 --> 00:01:16.440
>> They label it very well, so I'm in
JT's email and let's start a new email.

23
00:01:16.440 --> 00:01:21.386
Maybe you have to send out a bunch of
emails that always have the same amount of

24
00:01:21.386 --> 00:01:22.091
content.

25
00:01:22.091 --> 00:01:26.617
Maybe you're running a contest or
some type of promotion and it's like,

26
00:01:26.617 --> 00:01:28.880
click here to ask us more questions.

27
00:01:28.880 --> 00:01:31.962
And they email you like,
I'd like to know more about

28
00:01:31.962 --> 00:01:35.900
that trip that you're promoting
to Australia, or what have you.

29
00:01:35.900 --> 00:01:39.371
I think that's what the Quick Parts, at
least that's what I already made it into,

30
00:01:39.371 --> 00:01:40.581
[LAUGH], so we'll find out.

31
00:01:40.581 --> 00:01:41.855
So I don't wanna have to keep typing.

32
00:01:41.855 --> 00:01:44.397
Now, yes, you could go and
find another email,

33
00:01:44.397 --> 00:01:46.815
copy up the information,
paste it into here.

34
00:01:46.815 --> 00:01:49.760
But what if it was just ready to go,
kinda like a stamp?

35
00:01:49.760 --> 00:01:52.630
I want that stamp, and
then you put it on the email,

36
00:01:52.630 --> 00:01:54.550
and it just puts the content in.

37
00:01:54.550 --> 00:01:57.500
>> So you're rubber stamping
things that you want to do

38
00:01:57.500 --> 00:02:00.260
very quickly that you normally tend to do.

39
00:02:00.260 --> 00:02:04.755
>> Yeah, and you can put in pictures,
tables, charts,

40
00:02:04.755 --> 00:02:08.192
whatever you want, any type of content.

41
00:02:08.192 --> 00:02:12.900
Well, you create it first, you select it,
you add it into the Quick Parts library.

42
00:02:12.900 --> 00:02:16.180
And then when you're ready to go, you just
pick out a library and just put it in.

43
00:02:16.180 --> 00:02:17.910
>> All right, I'm sold.

44
00:02:17.910 --> 00:02:21.245
I wanna see how to do this,
cuz this actually sounds very efficient.

45
00:02:21.245 --> 00:02:24.240
>> It is, so here we go,
I'm in a new email body.

46
00:02:24.240 --> 00:02:27.930
We go over to the Insert tab,
and in this Insert tab,

47
00:02:27.930 --> 00:02:32.570
over towards the right-hand side in
the Text group, there is Quick Parts.

48
00:02:32.570 --> 00:02:35.010
Now Quick Parts, this is not just
something that's in Outlook,

49
00:02:35.010 --> 00:02:36.430
this is something that's in Word too.

50
00:02:36.430 --> 00:02:40.340
Because, of course, we're really
using Word inside of Outlook anyways.

51
00:02:40.340 --> 00:02:42.160
And so we have our Quick Parts gallery,

52
00:02:42.160 --> 00:02:46.640
you can see that the very first one that I
have, I've already made something in here.

53
00:02:46.640 --> 00:02:49.203
So I wanna put my cursor
where I want that to be.

54
00:02:49.203 --> 00:02:53.680
Go into Quick Parts, click it, and
boom, it just put in all of that.

55
00:02:53.680 --> 00:02:56.950
It went ahead and put in the paragraphs,
the link that I wanted to,

56
00:02:56.950 --> 00:02:58.920
a bulleted list, a picture.

57
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:02.987
And here we go, this is like, hey, thank
you for your inquiry, here's our page.

58
00:03:02.987 --> 00:03:06.659
And this is an actual live page,
and I was looking through and

59
00:03:06.659 --> 00:03:08.753
now I wanna go to Australia [LAUGH].

60
00:03:08.753 --> 00:03:09.803
So you can see, and

61
00:03:09.803 --> 00:03:14.345
I took it right from the website about the
information about going to the Outback.

62
00:03:14.345 --> 00:03:17.660
And there you go, address it, send it off.

63
00:03:17.660 --> 00:03:18.918
And there you go, wonderful.

64
00:03:18.918 --> 00:03:22.356
I can add as many things as I
want into my Quick Parts Library.

65
00:03:22.356 --> 00:03:27.690
There is something known as AutoText
as well, how are they different?

66
00:03:27.690 --> 00:03:31.340
Well, I would say AutoText is more for
just text,

67
00:03:31.340 --> 00:03:36.410
the Quick Parts is where you can put
a bunch of other things, the images, and

68
00:03:36.410 --> 00:03:39.340
the links, and the tables,
and things like that.

69
00:03:39.340 --> 00:03:44.070
But you could save anything to either
part, the Quick Parts or the AutoText.

70
00:03:44.070 --> 00:03:47.590
And this is just a bulleted
list that I added in here.

71
00:03:47.590 --> 00:03:48.980
I'm gonna make sure,

72
00:03:48.980 --> 00:03:51.190
always make sure your cursor's in
the place where you want it to go.

73
00:03:51.190 --> 00:03:56.215
So let me go to Quick Parts, AutoText,
come down to this list of chapters,

74
00:03:56.215 --> 00:03:58.415
and then it just goes ahead and
puts that list of chapters in.

75
00:03:58.415 --> 00:04:00.605
So really it's more for
text information, but

76
00:04:00.605 --> 00:04:03.613
it all is part of what's
known as building blocks.

77
00:04:03.613 --> 00:04:05.420
And there's these building blocks,

78
00:04:05.420 --> 00:04:08.587
these are called, I think they
actually used to call it AutoText.

79
00:04:08.587 --> 00:04:12.111
And now AutoText has become just
like a piece of the building blocks,

80
00:04:12.111 --> 00:04:14.070
which is part of Quick Parts.

81
00:04:14.070 --> 00:04:15.890
All words that you might see,

82
00:04:15.890 --> 00:04:18.490
well you will see if you
start looking this stuff up.

83
00:04:18.490 --> 00:04:22.598
But for the most part it just
saves stuff for you, it's great.

84
00:04:22.598 --> 00:04:24.000
Yeah, so how do I make it?

85
00:04:24.000 --> 00:04:27.580
Let's come over here to Joey's machine.

86
00:04:27.580 --> 00:04:31.571
And I have that email with all
the same content ready to go,

87
00:04:31.571 --> 00:04:36.065
because Joey doesn't have anything
in his Quick Parts Library.

88
00:04:36.065 --> 00:04:41.251
So, to make it go a little faster,
I have one ready to go for us.

89
00:04:41.251 --> 00:04:45.740
And I have it in the Draft folder, so
I'd saved it for Joey to be able to use.

90
00:04:45.740 --> 00:04:48.775
So I've composed everything that I want.

91
00:04:48.775 --> 00:04:52.935
I can do a Ctrl+A, Ctrl+A is select all,
or you can click, hold and drag,

92
00:04:52.935 --> 00:04:55.300
whichever way makes you feel better.

93
00:04:55.300 --> 00:05:00.552
To go ahead and select the information
that you want to become a Quick Part.

94
00:05:00.552 --> 00:05:03.882
You go back over the same place I
was just in on the Insert tab, and

95
00:05:03.882 --> 00:05:07.461
then in the Quick Parts,
notice that this looks a little different,

96
00:05:07.461 --> 00:05:10.460
because the resolution
will change on this one.

97
00:05:10.460 --> 00:05:13.550
Save Selection to Quick Part Gallery.

98
00:05:13.550 --> 00:05:18.206
l think l called it a library, gallery,
library, it's close enough [LAUGH].

99
00:05:18.206 --> 00:05:20.700
The container of where it's going to.

100
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:25.481
And so we can name this our,
not Outlook, Outback promo,

101
00:05:25.481 --> 00:05:29.688
and it's going to go into
the Quick Parts Gallery.

102
00:05:29.688 --> 00:05:32.990
Notice there are other things in here,
but these are the things that are,

103
00:05:32.990 --> 00:05:34.702
like I said, that are coming to Word.

104
00:05:34.702 --> 00:05:38.216
That, if you do use Word, and you can
insert your headers, your footers, and

105
00:05:38.216 --> 00:05:39.130
your page numbers.

106
00:05:39.130 --> 00:05:43.080
This is where it stores
everything into those quick to

107
00:05:43.080 --> 00:05:46.340
use selections when you say Insert Header.

108
00:05:46.340 --> 00:05:49.485
Don't worry about where it's going,
just keep the default,

109
00:05:49.485 --> 00:05:51.750
you can keep the category
as general as well.

110
00:05:51.750 --> 00:05:53.775
I wouldn't get too crazy with this,

111
00:05:53.775 --> 00:05:56.989
just keep it all in the same
place as where it tells it to go.

112
00:05:56.989 --> 00:06:02.510
You click OK, now I'm ready to start my
new mail just like we did with Justin.

113
00:06:02.510 --> 00:06:07.090
Insert, Quick Parts, and
there it is, easy peasy [LAUGH].

114
00:06:07.090 --> 00:06:09.043
>> Lemon squeezy [LAUGH].

115
00:06:09.043 --> 00:06:10.745
>> [LAUGH] Exactly.

116
00:06:10.745 --> 00:06:15.556
Now, another thing that you
could do within your messages

117
00:06:15.556 --> 00:06:17.823
is something known as Tap.

118
00:06:17.823 --> 00:06:22.850
And this is definitely newer than,
old, wow.

119
00:06:22.850 --> 00:06:24.910
>> [LAUGH] Newer than old.

120
00:06:24.910 --> 00:06:30.927
>> Yeah, I just said that [LAUGH],
it's a newer feature.

121
00:06:30.927 --> 00:06:34.769
It works by adding parts of a document.

122
00:06:34.769 --> 00:06:38.874
Instead of inserting an entire file,
hey, go ahead and look at this report,

123
00:06:38.874 --> 00:06:41.940
what if you only wanted
the chart out of that report?

124
00:06:41.940 --> 00:06:45.420
Or maybe you just wanted
to send somebody one slide

125
00:06:45.420 --> 00:06:47.470
out of your PowerPoint presentation.

126
00:06:47.470 --> 00:06:50.390
That's where you get into
your Tap functions, and

127
00:06:50.390 --> 00:06:52.350
it's called a document item.

128
00:06:52.350 --> 00:06:56.698
Notice it says, find and reuse parts
of documents within your organization.

129
00:06:56.698 --> 00:07:01.218
Within your organization,
cuz I did do some research on this,

130
00:07:01.218 --> 00:07:05.760
it pulls from your OneDrive
and/or your SharePoint account.

131
00:07:05.760 --> 00:07:11.161
So you can't necessarily go out and
search for it on your desktop.

132
00:07:11.161 --> 00:07:12.290
>> Interesting feature.

133
00:07:12.290 --> 00:07:14.440
>> Yeah, that's why I was like, well,

134
00:07:14.440 --> 00:07:17.150
I wanna do something that's
files on my computer.

135
00:07:17.150 --> 00:07:21.955
But it seems to only want to pull from
a OneDrive account or a SharePoint.

136
00:07:21.955 --> 00:07:23.245
It's part of the Office 365,

137
00:07:23.245 --> 00:07:26.390
you do have to have an Office 365
account to be able to use this feature.

138
00:07:26.390 --> 00:07:30.050
So you have a standalone,
not 365-associated account,

139
00:07:30.050 --> 00:07:32.320
then that's not going to work.

140
00:07:32.320 --> 00:07:34.490
So just make sure you're
kind of looking for that.

141
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:37.950
So there are items in my
One Drive account for

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne take a look at handling junk mail within Outlook 2016.  They discuss what junk mail is and where it’s controlled for Outlook 2016. They also show the Junk Mail Options that users can setup to help handle junk mail that may get through the administrative handling of it too.
episodes.title: Junk Mail
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

[MUSIC]

So, it's one of those things

It's not necessarily, well,

This is kind of coming down the pipeline

So it's trying to determine what is
