We're actually past that

Actually, mail that we get in our mailbox,

And that's kind of the same

Out there on the Internet,

90 plus percent of all

Now you might go, so

Well, the big deal is,
if you have a company and

they've set up an infrastructure to build

56
00:03:22.740 --> 00:03:26.900

58
00:03:32.418 --> 00:03:33.152
>> [LAUGH]
>> And I mean,

59
00:03:33.152 --> 00:03:36.910
that's a waste of resources

60
00:03:36.910 --> 00:03:39.072
So, the problem is simple, right?

61
00:03:39.072 --> 00:03:43.180
As you have to check junk mail, as Vonne

piece of email, it's wasting time and

63
00:03:47.354 --> 00:03:48.760

So, just like what Vonne explained,
Microsoft and Outlook, and of course,

65

67

68

It's kind of presorted for us,

69

>> And like you were kind of hinting in
there, sometimes, it's trying to help us,

70
00:04:17.550 --> 00:04:20.720

which is like, wait, wait,

no, that's actually real,

72
00:04:24.410 --> 00:04:28.960
What might look like a Spam or just kinda
like a blanket email of trying to sell

73

me something, that's the sales person that
I was talking to from this particular

74
00:04:32.990 --> 00:04:37.520
company that maybe had pushed

75
00:04:37.520 --> 00:04:41.660
And so, Outlook was starting to look at
like, company X is sending you a lot of

76

X, and you started working with Bob there,

77

78
00:04:48.970 --> 00:04:53.524
Now you have to say, no, no, no,
come back, let's put Bob on the good list,

79
00:04:53.524 --> 00:04:54.766
in the safe senders,

80

which we're going to get into of

81
00:04:58.921 --> 00:05:03.041
And now, Ronnie, I know that you

as like we are a client-level.

84

>> Right.
>> So, would you mind kind of expanding

a little bit on what you could do as

00:05:15.653 --> 00:05:20.730
of managing our little system, as opposed
to Outlook doing it itself but then

87
00:05:20.730 --> 00:05:25.840
there's the level of you administratively
setting parameters as well.

88
00:05:25.840 --> 00:05:29.757
>> Sure thing, what normally ends up

00:17:40.930 --> 00:17:46.010
>> It is, it works in that same
very that fashion, normally,

when we have something like the safe

as well as to the other hosts

So it is a little bit convoluted, and
it's not as easy to explain as it seems.

00:19:13.550 --> 00:19:16.810
But that's the whole idea behind
the safe recipients is so

00:19:16.810 --> 00:19:20.010

[LAUGH]
>> That's why it's confusing.

I know if I'm the person

I can then add that in there and

it's coming from the group,

>> Yeah, [LAUGH] yeah, and it really comes

Ronnie or Lance or JT, whoever I'm sending

so that's that whole we have our own

00:20:49.367 --> 00:20:53.928
We're on good terms and we're not blocked,

But while we're talking about a bad list

We have the blocked senders,

And it knows that we're okay, like I said,

I really don't wanna see anymore emails

00:21:26.640 --> 00:21:30.781
It needs to come down and I think there's
one from me, yeah, right here, and

00:21:30.781 --> 00:21:34.250
it's funny, this particular email's,

00:21:34.250 --> 00:21:38.777
I was helping you test out those settings
for your show of doing the quarantines and

00:21:38.777 --> 00:21:39.573
everything.

00:21:39.573 --> 00:21:43.181
And so it's like, Ronnie's like,
hey send me an email so

I can block you on

376

And so we were testing this out,
in this scenario now,

Joey doesn't really wanna see

It's like mm I'm done with you,

you need to be blocked, same way that we

00:22:00.640 --> 00:22:05.030
We can take our safe and send it to

381
00:22:05.030 --> 00:22:08.870
coming into our junk options and

382
00:22:08.870 --> 00:22:14.480
I can say you are going to be blocked,

and notice that Vonne@itprotv has been

00:22:19.510 --> 00:22:21.760
thank you very much for doing that.

385
00:22:21.760 --> 00:22:23.385
I have just blocked myself.

00:22:23.385 --> 00:22:27.361
[LAUGH] And now I'm on the blocked email,
if I, Vonne, sorry,

all these pronouns are starting to get

388
00:22:32.628 --> 00:22:37.560
Vonne emails Joey,
Vonne will go into the spam

of Joey's mail and we go from there.

00:22:41.484 --> 00:22:47.074
Jumping back into the junk mail options,

and I say I promise I will stop emailing

and kittens, and bunnies.

00:22:54.160 --> 00:22:55.881
I promise I will stop doing that,

okay I'll take you off

395
00:22:59.280 --> 00:23:02.764
Take this and I could go ahead and

00:23:02.764 --> 00:23:06.920
and the same way that if I wanted to

00:23:06.920 --> 00:23:11.730
maybe you and I get on bad terms, and
mm no, you're going back down to the list.

I can control my options here.

Export to a file, this is really neat.

Because if for some reason there are 15 or

20 emails that Vonne really

And I've actually done this

>> [LAUGH]
>> That's true, I did it for years.

>> You will never get

>> Well, that's a great example, and

And so if you had that list and

it's then usually separated out by

So all you have to to is type in eGMail

00:24:48.708 --> 00:24:51.475

>> That's a great example.

Because-

Because you are setting your e-mail up on

00:25:05.660 --> 00:25:07.170
I mean, I just finished doing that.

Lance's inboxes at least

that's not actually not

The .tv is the top, and

In this tab,

Like dot we have examples here .ca,

I wouldn't wanna block anybody from

The thing is, if you start blocking at

00:26:44.590 --> 00:26:45.960

Anything that ends in these domains,

if you block that, that means every e-mail

You may be running this in

00:27:17.440 --> 00:27:19.780

00:27:24.650 --> 00:27:28.150
And so, they wanna give you that power and

Even if you're running just from

00:27:41.520 --> 00:27:44.970
You can block those types of domain lists,

But you gotta be careful, especially if

00:27:49.540 --> 00:27:53.780
So most of us are probably never

00:27:53.780 --> 00:27:56.940
If it's done in an organization, that's

488
00:27:56.940 --> 00:27:59.460
not so
much at the individual computer level.

489
00:27:59.460 --> 00:28:00.010
>> Exactly, great.

490
00:28:00.010 --> 00:28:02.950
And so,
I think the moral of the story is this is,

00:28:02.950 --> 00:28:07.030
it's all dependent on every single piece.

492
00:28:07.030 --> 00:28:12.780
Outlook, administrative, client, and then

we're okay and we're both on the good
senders, and whether or not I see it.

494
00:28:17.460 --> 00:28:19.880
And, I mean,
if there is somebody like I don't

00:28:20.880 --> 00:28:23.720
know why I am not getting your e-mail,
call your IT.

496
00:28:23.720 --> 00:28:27.046
They are like, well,
we can't change that parameter.

497
00:28:27.046 --> 00:28:30.250
Then, hey, Bob, from company x,

498
00:28:30.250 --> 00:28:33.420
Can you just go ahead and start
e-mailing me from your Gmail account or

499
00:28:33.420 --> 00:28:34.280
something else?

500
00:28:34.280 --> 00:28:37.968
I can't get you off of
the blocked sender's list.

501
00:28:37.968 --> 00:28:41.690
Because there are certain things
that will be out of your control.

502
00:28:41.690 --> 00:28:45.170
But at least hopefully in this episode
that we've given you a nice overview

503
00:28:45.170 --> 00:28:47.640
of the different pieces so
you have a better understanding.

504
00:28:47.640 --> 00:28:51.460
It's one of those, sometimes it's out
of our hands, we can't control it.

505
00:28:51.460 --> 00:28:56.240
But if we understand why,
it makes it a little easier for us.

506
00:28:56.240 --> 00:28:58.130
>> All right, Vonne,
well, thank you again for

507
00:28:58.130 --> 00:29:01.370
helping us out to understand a little
bit more about the junk mail and

508
00:29:01.370 --> 00:29:05.290
some of the settings that we can
control right from Outlook as well.

509
00:29:05.290 --> 00:29:09.330
Well, that's a great place for
us to also sign off for this episode.

510
00:29:09.330 --> 00:29:12.090
For OfficeProTV,
I've been your host, Ronnie Wong.

511
00:29:12.090 --> 00:29:13.010
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

512
00:29:13.010 --> 00:29:17.204
>> Stay tuned right here for
more Outlook 2016 shows.

513
00:29:17.204 --> 00:29:21.929

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Vonne explain archiving emails in Outlook 2016.  They cover a range of archiving topics including sending email messages to archive folder, changing the location of your archive folder, auto archive settings, and .pst and .ost data files .

00:25:45.018 --> 00:25:48.676
And it's basically just doing a file save,
file save, file save.

462
00:25:48.676 --> 00:25:50.440
And then it's just kind of keeping.

463
00:25:50.440 --> 00:25:52.100
>> It's adding more information to it.

464
00:25:52.100 --> 00:25:54.350
Yes, that's what you're actually doing.

465
00:25:54.350 --> 00:25:57.502
So, when we start thinking
about archiving, remember

466
00:25:57.502 --> 00:26:02.276
that in an organization, you're probably
not the one that's setting all this up.

467
00:26:02.276 --> 00:26:06.538
But if you're on your own, or if you
don't have that exchange organization and

468
00:26:06.538 --> 00:26:07.820
everything's set up.

469
00:26:07.820 --> 00:26:10.381
These are some of the things
you might want to consider,

470
00:26:10.381 --> 00:26:12.899
especially if those emails
in the past are important.

471
00:26:12.899 --> 00:26:16.059
But at the same time, you don't wanna
be flooded with a ton of emails and

472
00:26:16.059 --> 00:26:18.709
having to search through things
you don't really want to.

473
00:26:18.709 --> 00:26:23.377
It is a great feature, it's something that
we don't really have to worry too much

474
00:26:23.377 --> 00:26:26.708
inside of Office 365,
because the online archiving.

475
00:26:26.708 --> 00:26:30.670
But on your own though,
it's something that you should consider,

476
00:26:30.670 --> 00:26:34.230
especially if you really get
a ton of emails at the same time.

477
00:26:34.230 --> 00:26:39.441
>> And I actually have one last little
anecdote if you want to say for,

478
00:26:39.441 --> 00:26:44.300
where I actually [SOUND] [LAUGH]
experience this just recently.

479
00:26:44.300 --> 00:26:46.391
In some of the other episodes
you have been watching,

480
00:26:46.391 --> 00:26:49.545
I was mentioning that I have had to
set up a lot of virtual machines.

481
00:26:49.545 --> 00:26:52.650
Many, many times in the last couple of
weeks, because of one computer dying and

482
00:26:52.650 --> 00:26:54.910
another computer having to get back on.

483
00:26:54.910 --> 00:26:56.490
Online, if you want to say.

484
00:26:56.490 --> 00:26:58.870
And I'm an Office 365 subscriber.

485
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:05.730
And I had installed Joey's inbox,
Outlook on Joey's account.

486
00:27:05.730 --> 00:27:08.586
And then that computer died,
and then I brought it back up.

487
00:27:08.586 --> 00:27:15.435
And then I'm resetting Joey's
settings on Outlook for that machine.

488
00:27:15.435 --> 00:27:18.552
It brought it back up but
it was from two weeks ago, and

489
00:27:18.552 --> 00:27:20.853
it wasn't showing any of the new mail.

490
00:27:20.853 --> 00:27:24.180
But I'm like, but
I'm connected to my account.

491
00:27:24.180 --> 00:27:28.260
Why isn't it showing and it gave me
an actual little warning that said,

492
00:27:28.260 --> 00:27:33.730
what you are going to need to do is
you're going to delete that PST file.

493
00:27:33.730 --> 00:27:37.454
And then, once you delete that
when I turn back on Outlook,

494
00:27:37.454 --> 00:27:40.000
it's going to reset everything for me.

495
00:27:40.000 --> 00:27:44.684
So, I have actually encountered
this same file in the same context,

496
00:27:44.684 --> 00:27:49.170
it was archiving,
it was remembering all of my settings.

497
00:27:49.170 --> 00:27:53.300
But now I'm re-setting up that
machine with that account.

498
00:27:53.300 --> 00:27:55.425
I had to start it over.

499
00:27:55.425 --> 00:27:58.000
So, that's something that I had to find.

500
00:27:58.000 --> 00:28:00.913
And I actually have like
a little PowerPoint.

501
00:28:00.913 --> 00:28:03.589
Yeah, let's go ahead and
check Ronnie's account really or sorry,

502
00:28:03.589 --> 00:28:05.307
check Ronnie's computer really quickly.

503
00:28:05.307 --> 00:28:07.581
Because I sent this to him.

504
00:28:07.581 --> 00:28:10.879
Is I had to actually go find that file,
and

505
00:28:10.879 --> 00:28:16.270
what I did is I went back into my
account settings into the data file.

506
00:28:16.270 --> 00:28:18.632
And I have the steps written out for
you, and I can go ahead and

507
00:28:18.632 --> 00:28:20.250
attach it to this episode.

508
00:28:20.250 --> 00:28:20.880
There we go.

509
00:28:20.880 --> 00:28:21.630
Perfect.

510
00:28:21.630 --> 00:28:26.050
And so you can see that I had to, it gave
me a warning and then I had to go into it.

511
00:28:26.050 --> 00:28:29.940
I deleted those two JT files
right there at the bottom.

512
00:28:29.940 --> 00:28:33.012
I deleted it out of there, and
then restarted Outlook, and

513
00:28:33.012 --> 00:28:34.372
everything was perfect.

514
00:28:34.372 --> 00:28:38.514
So, the one thing is you have to check
on that hidden files in the file,

515
00:28:38.514 --> 00:28:40.846
one is explorer to be able to look at it.

516
00:28:40.846 --> 00:28:44.019
But, definitely check out that little
PowerPoint presentation that's attached to

517
00:28:44.019 --> 00:28:44.920
this episode.

518
00:28:44.920 --> 00:28:48.550
So you can see the steps in case
you encounter that as well, so.

519
00:28:48.550 --> 00:28:50.110
Well, thank you very much Ronnie.

520
00:28:50.110 --> 00:28:53.010
Great information about archiving,
when to do it.

521
00:28:53.010 --> 00:28:56.100
You might not ever need to do it if
your organization does it for you, but

522
00:28:56.100 --> 00:28:59.370
at least you'll understand the concept and
where it's all going.

523
00:28:59.370 --> 00:29:01.390
And it's never really gone, is it Ronnie?

524
00:29:01.390 --> 00:29:02.050
>> True.
>> [LAUGH]

525
00:29:02.050 --> 00:29:03.890
>> Well, thank you so much for that.

526
00:29:03.890 --> 00:29:04.753
I hope you all enjoy it.

527
00:29:04.753 --> 00:29:06.467
This is a great time to sign off.

528
00:29:06.467 --> 00:29:09.519
For OfficePro.TV,
I'm your host Vonne Smith.

529
00:29:09.519 --> 00:29:10.587
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

530
00:29:10.587 --> 00:29:11.191
>> See you soon.

531
00:29:12.692 --> 00:29:22.120
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne dive into sharing and managing multiple email accounts in Outlook 2016. Here they demonstrate and explain how to setup email delegation to grant access as well as viewing the delegated inbox in the Outlook client. They also cover need to know characteristics that happen when managing a shared account.
episodes.title: Share and Manage Multiple Accounts
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.803
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.803 --> 00:00:07.303
All right, greetings everyone and

3
00:00:07.303 --> 00:00:10.200
welcome back to another great
episode of Office Pro TV.

4
00:00:10.200 --> 00:00:13.281
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode, well,

5
00:00:13.281 --> 00:00:15.600
we are dishing up some more Outlook 2016.

6
00:00:15.600 --> 00:00:19.100
And joining us in the studio, yet again,
our good friend Ms. Vaughn Smith.

7
00:00:19.100 --> 00:00:20.223
Vaughn, we are so glad to have you again.

8
00:00:20.223 --> 00:00:21.200
How's it going today?

9
00:00:21.200 --> 00:00:22.220
>> It's going great.

10
00:00:22.220 --> 00:00:28.194
We're gonna talk about different ways that
we can share and manage multiple accounts.

11
00:00:28.194 --> 00:00:29.380
So this is where we're gonna,

12
00:00:29.380 --> 00:00:32.040
[LAUGH] We're gonna start getting
a little circular in this episode.

13
00:00:32.040 --> 00:00:34.440
So you're gonna need to
stick with me on this,

14
00:00:34.440 --> 00:00:37.750
because I'm going to be demonstrating
from all three accounts.

15
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:40.730
Today we're gonna be talking about JT,
and Joey, and

16
00:00:40.730 --> 00:00:44.390
Lance and
how they all kind of work together.

17
00:00:44.390 --> 00:00:47.480
And so,
I'm gonna try to kind of start with

18
00:00:47.480 --> 00:00:52.300
some terminology right away
of the owner and the manager.

19
00:00:52.300 --> 00:00:58.324
So let's say that JT is
the CEO of Boyband.com,

20
00:00:58.324 --> 00:01:02.490
or whatever, and
he is going to be the main guy.

21
00:01:02.490 --> 00:01:07.210
He is going to be the owner
of his email account.

22
00:01:07.210 --> 00:01:13.920
Joey and Lance, they are assistants for
JT, or we're using both,

23
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:18.150
just so I can see some variations on
how we're going to be sending emails.

24
00:01:18.150 --> 00:01:22.786
But they're going to be managing his
email account, cuz JT is a very busy man,

25
00:01:22.786 --> 00:01:25.541
and he's going to be out
of the office at time.

26
00:01:25.541 --> 00:01:28.239
And so his assistant, or assistants,

27
00:01:28.239 --> 00:01:32.320
are going to be managing
everything within his Outlook.

28
00:01:32.320 --> 00:01:37.794
Maybe his email, his calendar,
his tasks, all those different things

29
00:01:37.794 --> 00:01:42.834
that he is going to delegate access
to the managers of his account.

30
00:01:42.834 --> 00:01:44.840
So that's what we're gonna start with.

31
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:49.920
JT is the owner, and
Lance and Joey are managers.

32
00:01:49.920 --> 00:01:53.970
And when you set this is up, you're going
to have to have two sides of the coin.

33
00:01:53.970 --> 00:01:59.065
The owner is going to have to give
permission, is going to have to delegate

34
00:01:59.065 --> 00:02:04.261
authority, or access, to those people
to allow them into their account.

35
00:02:04.261 --> 00:02:08.181
The other thing that owner is going to
have to do is they are going to have

36
00:02:08.181 --> 00:02:12.670
to make sure that the folders are visible
for them to be able to access.

37
00:02:12.670 --> 00:02:15.840
So that's kind of side
one on the owner part.

38
00:02:15.840 --> 00:02:18.230
Side two as the manager,

39
00:02:18.230 --> 00:02:23.620
they're going to have to configure their
accounts to be able to show that owner's

40
00:02:23.620 --> 00:02:28.400
mailbox in their side navigation pane
over on the left to make sure that

41
00:02:28.400 --> 00:02:33.250
they can start monitoring the inbox and
then sending out emails on behalf.

42
00:02:33.250 --> 00:02:35.960
So those are the two different
parts that we're going to get.

43
00:02:35.960 --> 00:02:38.961
So we're going to jump into here and
I'm gonna start demonstrating.

44
00:02:38.961 --> 00:02:42.237
And I have these things,
I have all of this already set up, and

45
00:02:42.237 --> 00:02:44.380
some examples of emails back and forth.

46
00:02:44.380 --> 00:02:49.560
Just so we can kind of not have to wait
for some of the things to take hold.

47
00:02:49.560 --> 00:02:54.790
Because we are working in an Office 365
environment, which means that anything

48
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:59.530
that we do here has to go up into the
cloud, and then back down to the cloud.

49
00:02:59.530 --> 00:03:02.990
And it is very possible that these things,
it takes some time.

50
00:03:02.990 --> 00:03:06.032
So it-
>> So timing might not be perfect.

51
00:03:06.032 --> 00:03:08.997
>> Exactly, yeah so if I wanted to say,
let me go ahead and delegate this

52
00:03:08.997 --> 00:03:12.594
authority, and then on the other part, let
me go ahead and get this mailbox setup.

53
00:03:12.594 --> 00:03:15.782
Well, if this has been mail
that's been going on for years,

54
00:03:15.782 --> 00:03:18.910
it might take a while for
all of these things to happen.

55
00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:22.690
So I kinda set all of this up before
the show, [LAUGH] so we can go ahead and

56
00:03:22.690 --> 00:03:24.080
have this.

57
00:03:24.080 --> 00:03:26.772
And the same would be like if we
were going to be removing access.

58
00:03:26.772 --> 00:03:29.530
Where I'm, okay,
now I don't want you managing anymore.

59
00:03:29.530 --> 00:03:32.900
Well, I could try to demonstrate that but
that takes a while.

60
00:03:32.900 --> 00:03:35.926
So it's like, well,
it's supposed to be removed but

61
00:03:35.926 --> 00:03:38.206
[LAUGH] it's not really showing right now.

62
00:03:38.206 --> 00:03:40.510
[LAUGH] So
that's why I'm just gonna go ahead and

63
00:03:40.510 --> 00:03:43.350
just demonstrate all of
these different pieces.

64
00:03:43.350 --> 00:03:47.975
All right, so,
there are some other emails, not emails.

65
00:03:47.975 --> 00:03:51.840
[LAUGH] Web addresses that are in
the show notes that I would

66
00:03:51.840 --> 00:03:55.870
really want you guys to look at because
it's going to outline all of these steps

67
00:03:55.870 --> 00:03:57.190
that I'm going to be going through.

68
00:03:57.190 --> 00:04:01.219
So there's the part of like how to
delegate your access as the owner,

69
00:04:01.219 --> 00:04:04.422
they call it, and
this is where they call it a manager.

70
00:04:04.422 --> 00:04:06.820
Even though now I'm using
manager on the other side.

71
00:04:06.820 --> 00:04:08.205
>> Yeah.
>> So don't get too confused.

72
00:04:08.205 --> 00:04:10.730
[LAUGH] I know, I'm already circling.

73
00:04:10.730 --> 00:04:11.503
>> That's right.

74
00:04:11.503 --> 00:04:16.467
>> Yeah, but then there's another website
and a page in there that talks about how

75
00:04:16.467 --> 00:04:21.010
you, as the manager or person,
I don't know what other word to use.

76
00:04:21.010 --> 00:04:23.008
The other person managing
somebody else's account.

77
00:04:23.008 --> 00:04:25.250
>> Well, I mean, if you think about it,
the way you're using it,

78
00:04:25.250 --> 00:04:28.510
you have the owner,
its the person that this is their account.

79
00:04:28.510 --> 00:04:31.070
They are also a manager because
they can manage the account.

80
00:04:31.070 --> 00:04:33.536
They can say I want to do this,
I don't wanna do that.

81
00:04:33.536 --> 00:04:35.905
And they can make settings and
changes, right?

82
00:04:35.905 --> 00:04:39.172
Anybody else that can make settings
changes is also a manager.

83
00:04:39.172 --> 00:04:43.228
>> Yes. [LAUGH] >> It might not be
the owner, might not be them, right?

84
00:04:43.228 --> 00:04:44.550
But they can manage it.

85
00:04:44.550 --> 00:04:45.870
So think of it in those terms.

86
00:04:45.870 --> 00:04:47.470
The owner, it is their mailbox.

87
00:04:47.470 --> 00:04:50.340
The manager, anyone that can make
changes and manage the mailbox.

88
00:04:50.340 --> 00:04:51.520
>> I like that, that's perfect.

89
00:04:51.520 --> 00:04:55.632
So we have all of our mailboxes and all of
our accounts open, on all of my machines,

90
00:04:55.632 --> 00:04:58.745
all of my virtual machines I keep
switching back and forth to.

91
00:04:58.745 --> 00:05:00.104
So this JT.

92
00:05:00.104 --> 00:05:05.820
As the owner, he wants to have
somebody else manage his email.

93
00:05:05.820 --> 00:05:09.762
So what that person is going to
need to do is come over into File.

94
00:05:09.762 --> 00:05:15.710
Come over into the account settings,
and we're going to delegate access.

95
00:05:15.710 --> 00:05:19.830
This is where they're going
to allow somebody to be

96
00:05:19.830 --> 00:05:22.195
added onto managing their account.

97
00:05:22.195 --> 00:05:26.550
And as you can see, Joey and
Lance are already both there.

98
00:05:26.550 --> 00:05:29.800
But if this was blank, and
you're adding your assistant into here,

99
00:05:29.800 --> 00:05:35.780
you would then click the Add button,
pick the person from your organization,

100
00:05:35.780 --> 00:05:39.830
and then go in to the next field or
the next window which is gonna show up,

101
00:05:39.830 --> 00:05:42.810
which is about how you want
to set the permissions.

102
00:05:42.810 --> 00:05:47.550
If you go ahead also make a big note here,
like big asterisks.

103
00:05:47.550 --> 00:05:51.300
You have to be on an Exchange Server
to be able to do this.

104
00:05:51.300 --> 00:05:54.597
Or on Office 365,
which in a sense is an Exchange Server.

105
00:05:54.597 --> 00:05:59.050
So if you are not on Exchange,
none of this is applicable.

106
00:05:59.050 --> 00:06:02.030
So that's a big, big note here.

107
00:06:02.030 --> 00:06:04.670
And that's why it's pulling
from my global address list.

108
00:06:04.670 --> 00:06:09.380
And that's pretty much the only place
you would be able to pick people from.

109
00:06:09.380 --> 00:06:12.184
Because in a global address list,
you're all in the same Exchange Server.

110
00:06:12.184 --> 00:06:14.983
So let's pretend we picked somebody.

111
00:06:14.983 --> 00:06:18.065
And I am gonna come into one
of these people's accounts.

112
00:06:18.065 --> 00:06:20.645
And I'm gonna click on
the permissions over here,

113
00:06:20.645 --> 00:06:23.831
because this box is gonna show up
in just a second, there it is.

114
00:06:23.831 --> 00:06:27.674
This is what's going to come up next
after you say, I've added my person,

115
00:06:27.674 --> 00:06:28.597
what do I do next?

116
00:06:28.597 --> 00:06:35.086
And this is where you give the permission
to that manager of your account.

117
00:06:35.086 --> 00:06:39.950
This is where if you didn't want them to
be able to send email on your behalf,

118
00:06:39.950 --> 00:06:42.990
maybe that assistant is
just there to monitor,

119
00:06:42.990 --> 00:06:45.270
just to be able to read your mail.

120
00:06:45.270 --> 00:06:47.960
Then they can just be a reviewer.

121
00:06:47.960 --> 00:06:52.998
So you don't have to give them full access
to be able to write emails on your behalf.

122
00:06:52.998 --> 00:06:54.912
You could just have them
look at everything.

123
00:06:54.912 --> 00:07:00.281
I mean, it's up to you on what permissions
that you, or what access that you want to

124
00:07:00.281 --> 00:07:05.520
grant to that person that you're wanting
to help manage your life, basically.

125
00:07:05.520 --> 00:07:09.134
[LAUGH] So if I wanted to, you could
change these different parts here and

126
00:07:09.134 --> 00:07:12.900
maybe you wanna give them just access
to your inbox and not your calendar.

127
00:07:12.900 --> 00:07:16.370
But a lot of times an assistant,
they're probably gonna be putting

128
00:07:16.370 --> 00:07:20.310
things on your calendar and
managing your schedule as well.

129
00:07:20.310 --> 00:07:24.480
Everything is up to you on how
you want to delegate that access.

130
00:07:24.480 --> 00:07:27.720
But these are the different
settings that Joey has.

131
00:07:27.720 --> 00:07:32.110
He can edit and do everything in
the inbox and the calendar, but

132
00:07:32.110 --> 00:07:35.860
does not have access to contacts,
tasks, or notes.

133
00:07:35.860 --> 00:07:39.510
You could also send a message to that
person that's going to summarize,

134
00:07:39.510 --> 00:07:44.020
I'll give you an example of that when we
go over to Lance's account and see that.

135
00:07:44.020 --> 00:07:46.430
And I'm pretty sure Lance
has the same permissions.

136
00:07:46.430 --> 00:07:49.842
Yes, so we've got two people
that are able to delegate.

137
00:07:49.842 --> 00:07:53.220
Now I'm not sure if you'd
really wanna have two people.

138
00:07:53.220 --> 00:07:54.918
Because then if-
>> Right,

139
00:07:54.918 --> 00:07:58.303
you get too many chefs in the kitchen,
the soup starts getting salty, right?

140
00:07:58.303 --> 00:07:59.909
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, and

141
00:07:59.909 --> 00:08:00.783
I do like a lot of salt.

142
00:08:00.783 --> 00:08:01.498
>> Yeah, so.

143
00:08:01.498 --> 00:08:02.153
[LAUGH]
>> But yeah,

144
00:08:02.153 --> 00:08:03.032
that's a great point right there.

145
00:08:03.032 --> 00:08:07.691
And the other thing, as I'm gonna
show you Is that as the owner,

146
00:08:07.691 --> 00:08:13.401
if they're sending e-mails out on your
behalf, you're not gonna see them.

147
00:08:13.401 --> 00:08:15.180
Just keep that in the back
of your mind for one second.

148
00:08:15.180 --> 00:08:18.547
So if you think about two different
people, Lance isn't gonna see what Joey's

149
00:08:18.547 --> 00:08:21.059
sending and Joey's not gonna
see what Lance is sending, so

150
00:08:21.059 --> 00:08:22.433
that could get a little sticky.

151

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne begin exploring the use of contacts in Outlook 2016. Here they will start at the beginning by describing what a contact is, how to create a contact, and edit an existing contact, as well as creating a contact group and printing contacts.
episodes.title: Create and Manage Contacts

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Vonne take a look at sharing and/or transferring contacts. Watch as they show you how to forward a contact, sharing by asking for access or providing permissions, and finally importing/exporting contacts as a .csv file.
episodes.title: Share and Transfer Contacts

00:24:39.640 --> 00:24:42.810
for the summer, those types of things,
or on sabbatical.

485
00:24:42.810 --> 00:24:46.670
I could go ahead and see all of those
features, but you can't touch them.

486
00:24:46.670 --> 00:24:53.040
So opening a calendar within your
Exchange network, that's okay.

487
00:24:53.040 --> 00:24:57.350
When you share a calendar,
notice here I could share a calendar

00:24:57.350 --> 00:25:00.920
just like we talked about in the context
session, if you look at that,

489
00:25:00.920 --> 00:25:04.130
there's an episode called share and
transfer contacts.

490
00:25:04.130 --> 00:25:07.960
So I could share this out with
somebody else in my network,

491
00:25:07.960 --> 00:25:11.150
and I can request them to
share out their calendar.

492
00:25:11.150 --> 00:25:14.260
And then I can have different
permission levels of whether or

493
00:25:14.260 --> 00:25:18.870
not I can change any of their information,
or I can just view it.

494
00:25:18.870 --> 00:25:21.670
So, sharing and opening,
they look similar and

495
00:25:21.670 --> 00:25:25.380
they kind of go under this category over
here, but they are a little bit different.

496
00:25:25.380 --> 00:25:29.780
I'm going to check the boxes for Joey and
I'm going to check the boxes for Justin.

497
00:25:29.780 --> 00:25:32.520
I'm going to turn off
the cat show over here.

498
00:25:32.520 --> 00:25:34.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

499
00:25:34.040 --> 00:25:39.230
if I look at Joey's calendar as Lance,
I could say well let me look at this one.

500
00:25:40.620 --> 00:25:43.040
Notice it says when I
try to double click it,

501
00:25:43.040 --> 00:25:45.710
you do not have permission
to view this calendar.

502
00:25:45.710 --> 00:25:48.710
But do you want to ask Joey for
permission?

503
00:25:48.710 --> 00:25:50.140
I'm going to say no for this one.

504
00:25:50.140 --> 00:25:54.980
As opposed to Justin Timberlake, Justin
Timberlake gave me access to his calendar.

505
00:25:54.980 --> 00:25:59.090
So it I double clicked over here on
June 2nd, that's, yes that's true.

506
00:25:59.090 --> 00:26:04.320
Notices it opens up into a windows where
I can start creating an appointment for

507
00:26:04.320 --> 00:26:08.990
Justin because he have me
that access to his calendar.

508
00:26:10.270 --> 00:26:14.780
So all of the different ways that
you can use that calendar interface.

509
00:26:14.780 --> 00:26:17.690
Let's turn off these shared calendars,

510
00:26:17.690 --> 00:26:22.310
notice that it automatically turns

511
00:26:22.310 --> 00:26:25.280
I did mention those options
in the beginning of the show,

512
00:26:25.280 --> 00:26:27.780
like what if my work week is
not Monday through Friday?

513
00:26:27.780 --> 00:26:29.490
What if my time is not eight to five?

514
00:26:29.490 --> 00:26:33.890
If you go into the File tab,
you come into the Options,

515
00:26:33.890 --> 00:26:37.090
we've been here quite a few
times throughout this show.

516
00:26:37.090 --> 00:26:42.740
Where do you think we're going to go to if
we're talking about our calendar options?

517
00:26:42.740 --> 00:26:44.752
>> I'm going to say language.

518
00:26:44.752 --> 00:26:46.658
>> [LAUGH] And that would be wrong.

519
00:26:46.658 --> 00:26:49.200
>> Wrong.
[LAUGH] Like some weird stroke of events,

520
00:26:49.200 --> 00:26:51.294
so this is actually,
no I'm kidding it's on the calendar.

521
00:26:51.294 --> 00:26:53.270
[LAUGH]
>> It's the calendar right here.

522
00:26:53.270 --> 00:26:57.660
So this is where you can set the settings
for your different meetings,

523
00:26:57.660 --> 00:26:58.420
and time zones.

524
00:26:58.420 --> 00:27:01.780
Maybe you're working with a lot of
people over on the West Coast, or

525
00:27:01.780 --> 00:27:06.050
maybe over in China, or India, and

00:27:06.050 --> 00:27:09.220
you need to make sure that you know,
if you're trying to schedule meetings,

527
00:27:09.220 --> 00:27:13.620
you should see what their time is, and
how it correlates I'll show you that.

528
00:27:13.620 --> 00:27:15.920
So where do you want my start time to be?

529
00:27:15.920 --> 00:27:17.670
What are my work weeks?

530
00:27:17.670 --> 00:27:19.080
What is the first day of my week?

531
00:27:20.310 --> 00:27:20.950
It's Sunday.

532
00:27:20.950 --> 00:27:22.040
Maybe I don't want to be Sunday.

533
00:27:22.040 --> 00:27:23.740
I know a lot of times
when I do my iCalendars,

534
00:27:23.740 --> 00:27:26.650
I really want it to be on Monday, so
I always want the weekends to be on

535
00:27:26.650 --> 00:27:30.000
the side, because that's where
I walk out on my weekend.

536
00:27:30.000 --> 00:27:32.410
What is the first day of the year?

537
00:27:32.410 --> 00:27:34.360
Well, fiscal calendars.

538
00:27:34.360 --> 00:27:34.870
>> That's right.

539
00:27:34.870 --> 00:27:35.560
>> There we go.

540
00:27:35.560 --> 00:27:37.980
Yeah.
If you work on a fiscal calendar, and

541
00:27:37.980 --> 00:27:40.110
that's, that's what your,
that is your year.

542
00:27:40.110 --> 00:27:41.340
Doesn't matter what January is.

543
00:27:42.480 --> 00:27:45.090
You can see the default reminders.

544
00:27:45.090 --> 00:27:50.000
Adding holidays into your calendar, that's
different than having a separate calendar.

545
00:27:50.000 --> 00:27:53.320
Once you add them in, and
I actually remember when you add them in,

546
00:27:53.320 --> 00:27:56.820
it was hard to get rid of them.

547
00:27:56.820 --> 00:27:59.860
I've Googled this and it was back in the
day, how do you actually get rid of it?

548
00:27:59.860 --> 00:28:00.960
It's been some time,

549
00:28:00.960 --> 00:28:05.390
but I'm pretty sure that's why they
separate it out into US holidays.

550
00:28:05.390 --> 00:28:09.750
To where you don't have to add them all
in and want to get rid of them all.

551
00:28:09.750 --> 00:28:10.700
So you can add but

552
00:28:10.700 --> 00:28:15.850
if you wanted to, you can import which
you want to say into default calendar.

553
00:28:15.850 --> 00:28:18.850
You also have this different
colors that we were talking about.

554
00:28:18.850 --> 00:28:22.480
Scroll on down a litter bit further,
this is the time zone.

555
00:28:22.480 --> 00:28:25.830
So we're in Eastern Time,
because we're in Gainesville, Florida.

556
00:28:25.830 --> 00:28:27.745
But if I wanted to show
a second time zone,

557
00:28:27.745 --> 00:28:31.220
because I would like to
have it over in California.

558
00:28:31.220 --> 00:28:33.350
We'll just say, Cali to be cool.

559
00:28:33.350 --> 00:28:35.440
So what is California?

560
00:28:35.440 --> 00:28:41.560
They are in Pacific Time, and that's what
I'd like to show a second time zone.

561
00:28:41.560 --> 00:28:43.300
And the other thing is the weather.

562
00:28:43.300 --> 00:28:45.650
Maybe you don't want to see what
the weather is on your calendar.

563
00:28:45.650 --> 00:28:46.770
You can turn it off.

564
00:28:46.770 --> 00:28:47.600
I kind of like it.

565
00:28:47.600 --> 00:28:49.630
It's cute, so we'll click okay.

566
00:28:49.630 --> 00:28:51.190
Now I'm changed it.

567
00:28:51.190 --> 00:28:53.830
Well okay,
now where's that other timezone?

568
00:28:53.830 --> 00:28:54.690
I don't see it.

569
00:28:54.690 --> 00:28:56.620
You're not going to see
it in the month view.

570
00:28:56.620 --> 00:29:01.340
You will see it in the week view,
the work week view and

571
00:29:01.340 --> 00:29:03.570
the day view, and so no month view.

572
00:29:03.570 --> 00:29:06.790
So if you've set it, and
you don't think it happened, it did.

573
00:29:06.790 --> 00:29:13.240
So now, you can see that it is 12 PM in
Gainesville, but it is 9 AM in California.

574
00:29:13.240 --> 00:29:15.120
So I like those timezones.

575
00:29:15.120 --> 00:29:19.980
It gives you some different variations for
maybe clients that are in that place.

576
00:29:21.230 --> 00:29:23.100
Last little bit, printing your calendar.

577
00:29:24.220 --> 00:29:28.220
If you wanted, you can come over
to your file, you go to Print,

578
00:29:29.280 --> 00:29:35.133
depending on what day you had selected is
where you can go into the daily style,

579
00:29:35.133 --> 00:29:37.744
weekly, monthly.

580
00:29:37.744 --> 00:29:40.680
I'll tell you that [LAUGH] I do this.

581
00:29:40.680 --> 00:29:44.350
I actually make new calendars,
I keep them completely blank, and

582
00:29:44.350 --> 00:29:47.265
I print them out, and then I physically
write them on a piece of paper.

583
00:29:47.265 --> 00:29:50.500
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's just my way.

584
00:29:50.500 --> 00:29:51.965
>> Old habits die hard.

585
00:29:51.965 --> 00:29:55.780
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, it's just the way
I would do it for a long time, and

586
00:29:55.780 --> 00:29:59.040
then I'd staple them altogether and
put them in my filing cabinet.

587
00:29:59.040 --> 00:30:02.880
And I have all this technology, at my
fingertips literally on my phone, and

588
00:30:02.880 --> 00:30:03.970
I still print them out.

589
00:30:03.970 --> 00:30:06.160
>> That reminds me of Miss Headbury,

590
00:30:06.160 --> 00:30:08.409
who said people with flyers
it's like saying here.

591
00:30:10.640 --> 00:30:12.380
Feel this way for me.

592
00:30:12.380 --> 00:30:15.600
>> Exactly It's just I can't help it so,
but

593
00:30:15.600 --> 00:30:19.650
if you wanted to print your calendar
that's where you go to do it and so

594
00:30:19.650 --> 00:30:24.750
being from, there's a lot of pieces
within the calendar interface so that's

595
00:30:24.750 --> 00:30:28.430
why I wanted to take this episode just to
kinda get you familiar with everything.

596
00:30:28.430 --> 00:30:32.520
Clicking on stuff, know what's going
on and then will going to go ahead and

597
00:30:32.520 --> 00:30:36.020
dive into creating our appointment,
creating our meaning,

598
00:30:36.020 --> 00:30:40.420
moving our meanings and then how to
share our calendar so more to come.

599
00:30:40.420 --> 00:30:45.060
>> That sounds awesome, I know there are
good audience probably looking a lot for

600
00:30:45.060 --> 00:30:49.350
to that and I will say that a good email,

601
00:30:49.350 --> 00:30:54.860
a client worth its salt, really is tested
and tried by how well the calendar and

602
00:30:54.860 --> 00:30:59.570
the email portion of that functionality
works together, and Outlook does a great

603
00:30:59.570 --> 00:31:03.530
job of doing that just being able to put
in an item and it shows up in email.

604
00:31:03.530 --> 00:31:05.600
You can send emails from the calendar,

605
00:31:05.600 --> 00:31:08.250
you can add items to
the calendar from email events.

606
00:31:08.250 --> 00:31:12.560
It's very, very intertwined and very
interconnected and it works super well.

607
00:31:12.560 --> 00:31:15.380
It's the unsung hero of Outlook that's for
sure.

608
00:31:15.380 --> 00:31:17.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> Vonne you've definitely got

609
00:31:17.040 --> 00:31:18.750
us acclimated to the calendar waters.

610
00:31:18.750 --> 00:31:22.020
We appreciate that, but looking at
that clock and it's that time again.

611
00:31:22.020 --> 00:31:23.660
>> It's that time.
>> Time for us to sign off.

612
00:31:23.660 --> 00:31:25.660
For Office ProTV,
we do thank you for watching.

613
00:31:25.660 --> 00:31:26.950
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

614
00:31:26.950 --> 00:31:27.630
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

615
00:31:27.630 --> 00:31:29.735
>> And we'll see you next time.

616
00:31:29.735 --> 00:31:35.431
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne take a look at creating and managing appointments inside of Outlook. They discuss creating a new appointment, the attributes of the appointment, recurring appointments as well as editing, forwarding and moving appointments.
episodes.title: Create and Manage Appointments
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.701
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.701 --> 00:00:07.940
Thanks for tuning in to OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:07.940 --> 00:00:11.112
I'm your host, Wes Bryan, and we got
a great show for you in store today.

4
00:00:11.112 --> 00:00:14.781
And joining us back in the studios is
OfficeProTV's very own Vonne Smith,

5
00:00:14.781 --> 00:00:15.960
how you doing, Vonne?

6
00:00:15.960 --> 00:00:18.770
>> I'm doing great,
ready to make some appointments.

7
00:00:18.770 --> 00:00:19.310
>> All right.

8
00:00:19.310 --> 00:00:22.610
>> Yes, that's what we're going to
be concentrating on in this episode.

9
00:00:22.610 --> 00:00:26.239
So we took some time getting familiar
with the calendar interface, and

10
00:00:26.239 --> 00:00:29.139
now we're gonna go ahead and
start using the calendar and

11
00:00:29.139 --> 00:00:30.907
start scheduling appointments.

12
00:00:30.907 --> 00:00:34.034
Cuz it's going to be very important
to keep your life in order,

13
00:00:34.034 --> 00:00:37.855
make sure you've got to know where
you're supposed to be at all times.

14
00:00:37.855 --> 00:00:41.226
I know I struggle with that every
day a little bit there, Wes.

15
00:00:41.226 --> 00:00:43.089
I'm like, what am I doing today?

16
00:00:43.089 --> 00:00:44.057
What is my purpose?

17
00:00:44.057 --> 00:00:45.353
Where am I going [LAUGH]?

18
00:00:45.353 --> 00:00:48.455
>> I would say that if I didn't
have a neck, I'd forget my head.

19
00:00:48.455 --> 00:00:50.275
So it's a good design, great design.

20
00:00:50.275 --> 00:00:51.625
So when it comes to appointments,

21
00:00:51.625 --> 00:00:54.080
what are we gonna see here
when it comes to creating it?

22
00:00:54.080 --> 00:00:57.100
Well we're gonna do all of the different
details like what is the appointment

23
00:00:57.100 --> 00:01:01.010
about, where is it going to be, and any
type of notes that I might need to add.

24
00:01:01.010 --> 00:01:04.800
And if you've worked with appointments or
a calendar on your phone,

25
00:01:04.800 --> 00:01:06.560
I mean I know we all live on our phones.

26
00:01:06.560 --> 00:01:08.760
If you've scheduled it on your Android or

27
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:11.950
your iPhone, it's pretty much
the same thing in Outlook.

28
00:01:11.950 --> 00:01:14.810
It's just that Outlook is going to
be a lot more robust of what it's

29
00:01:14.810 --> 00:01:16.150
going to be able to do.

30
00:01:16.150 --> 00:01:19.652
But now appointments, to be specific,
are going to be for us.

31
00:01:19.652 --> 00:01:25.940
We put it to where we're the only person
really invited to the party to say.

32
00:01:25.940 --> 00:01:28.680
Now of course, you could have this as
an appointment that you're going to be

33
00:01:28.680 --> 00:01:34.110
meeting somebody, but it's different
than a meeting, per se, in Outlook.

34
00:01:34.110 --> 00:01:37.900
So if you schedule a meeting,
you're going to be inviting attendees.

35
00:01:37.900 --> 00:01:41.710
And then, of course, that interacts with
how that's going to email people and

36
00:01:41.710 --> 00:01:45.568
put it on your calendars, and
then put it on the invitees, or

37
00:01:45.568 --> 00:01:48.080
attendees` [LAUGH]
the people you're inviting.

38
00:01:48.080 --> 00:01:52.760
It puts it on their calendar and all of
that robustness of what makes Office and

39
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:57.020
Outlook, specifically, so great to use
to organize those types of things.

40
00:01:57.020 --> 00:02:01.360
But appointments are going to go on our
calendar, only our calendar, and so

41
00:02:01.360 --> 00:02:02.310
it reminds us.

42
00:02:02.310 --> 00:02:05.791
So let's just jump down
into Joey's calendar.

43
00:02:05.791 --> 00:02:10.401
And actually I left it right here just
to make sure that we had that reminder,

44
00:02:10.401 --> 00:02:13.932
because I had already scheduled a,
I think it's, well,

45
00:02:13.932 --> 00:02:16.901
it says it's a meeting right there,
Wes [LAUGH].

46
00:02:16.901 --> 00:02:18.875
So I was like, is this an appointment or
is this a meeting?

47
00:02:18.875 --> 00:02:22.945
But thankfully, it let's us know that,
hey, this is a reminder.

48
00:02:22.945 --> 00:02:27.935
It's like an alarm clock that I set on
this particular meeting to let me know,

49
00:02:27.935 --> 00:02:29.115
hey, it's time to go.

50
00:02:29.115 --> 00:02:31.555
It's 21 minutes overdue right now,
so hey, guess what?

51
00:02:31.555 --> 00:02:34.487
I'm late [LAUGH] to the marketing meeting.

52
00:02:34.487 --> 00:02:37.597
But we had had that come up
in the calendar interface, so

53
00:02:37.597 --> 00:02:39.817
anytime you schedule an appointment or
a meeting,

54
00:02:39.817 --> 00:02:45.197
you can put in that alarm clock,
that reminder to tell me hey,

55
00:02:45.197 --> 00:02:48.629
I need to make sure I'm supposted to
be there at that particular time.

56
00:02:48.629 --> 00:02:50.497
And then, of course,
the good old snooze button.

57
00:02:50.497 --> 00:02:53.327
I don't know how many times I hit that
snooze button every morning, Wes.

58
00:02:53.327 --> 00:02:56.540
I have five different alarms and
I have all the snoozes,

59
00:02:56.540 --> 00:03:01.230
and hopefully they coincide to get
me actually out of bed [LAUGH].

60
00:03:01.230 --> 00:03:05.036
>> The only time I've seen a snooze button
work is when I set it on the other side of

61
00:03:05.036 --> 00:03:05.925
the house [LAUGH].

62
00:03:05.925 --> 00:03:07.810
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] exactly,
I would have two alarm clocks.

63
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:10.156
And now, yeah, and that phone,
that stop button and

64
00:03:10.156 --> 00:03:13.040
the snooze button are kinda close
together, I don't like that.

65
00:03:13.040 --> 00:03:15.040
I think they need to change that iPhone.

66
00:03:15.040 --> 00:03:18.930
Okay, so we have our meeting reminder, and
then I'm going to go ahead and dismiss.

67
00:03:18.930 --> 00:03:22.500
Dismiss and dismiss all at this point
doesn't really make a difference,

68
00:03:22.500 --> 00:03:25.020
because there's only one
reminder that I have set here.

69
00:03:25.020 --> 00:03:26.830
So I'll just go ahead and
click dismiss all.

70
00:03:26.830 --> 00:03:27.540
It's just hey,

71
00:03:27.540 --> 00:03:31.330
are you sure you want to make sure
that I'm gonna stop reminding you.

72
00:03:31.330 --> 00:03:34.090
That's okay, thank you,
Outlook, for letting me know.

73
00:03:34.090 --> 00:03:36.878
And yep, I'm 21 minutes overdue anyways,
so I'm good.

74
00:03:36.878 --> 00:03:40.000
Okay, so I'm actually in
the email section right now.

75
00:03:40.000 --> 00:03:43.540
Let's switch over into our calendar,
jump into here.

76
00:03:43.540 --> 00:03:46.695
You can see that today at
the time of this filming,

77
00:03:46.695 --> 00:03:50.314
we had a marketing meeting
at 9:30 in Bob's office.

78
00:03:50.314 --> 00:03:53.650
And so that was something that was set,
and it was reminding me.

79
00:03:53.650 --> 00:03:55.670
This is actually a reoccurring meeting.

80
00:03:55.670 --> 00:03:58.280
And that's another thing that we're
going to be doing with appointments.

81
00:03:58.280 --> 00:04:02.400
Is this a single time appointment that
I only need to have on the schedule for

82
00:04:02.400 --> 00:04:02.990
one time, or

83
00:04:02.990 --> 00:04:07.450
is this something that happens every other
week, every other month, every year?

84
00:04:07.450 --> 00:04:12.490
What time and what occurrences do I
need to set on these appointments?

85
00:04:12.490 --> 00:04:14.600
So how do I make an appointment?

86
00:04:14.600 --> 00:04:15.640
There's a couple different ways,

87
00:04:15.640 --> 00:04:20.398
just like everything in any of our
Outlook or Office products I would say.

88
00:04:20.398 --> 00:04:22.670
You can right-click, you can double click,
you can click on a button.

89
00:04:22.670 --> 00:04:25.140
You can run around the block and
then stand on your head,

00:15:41.066 --> 00:15:45.379
every other Monday is going to be set for
the next two months.

314
00:15:45.379 --> 00:15:49.938
Cuz right now, at the time of filming
it is May 30th, starting June 1st.

315
00:15:49.938 --> 00:15:55.176
That would be, well the beginning of June
[LAUGH] all the way to the end of July,

316
00:15:55.176 --> 00:15:58.253
every other Monday starting with June 5th.

317
00:15:58.253 --> 00:15:59.286
So I picked this.

318
00:15:59.286 --> 00:16:00.119
I always do that.

319
00:16:00.119 --> 00:16:02.920
I'm going to double click on this
cuz I like the double click.

320
00:16:02.920 --> 00:16:05.560
Now, the double click method
does automatically put this

321
00:16:05.560 --> 00:16:07.110
into an all day event.

322
00:16:07.110 --> 00:16:11.270
So when I had right clicked on it before,
it gave me those times.

323
00:16:11.270 --> 00:16:13.610
I just uncheck it and
then I can go ahead and set my timing.

324
00:16:13.610 --> 00:16:16.500
That's just kind of the way
that I've always gotten used to

325
00:16:16.500 --> 00:16:18.550
adding appointments to my calendar.

326
00:16:18.550 --> 00:16:24.416
So I said 9 AM, we'll meet from 9 to we'll
just do a 30 minute meeting, that's fine.

327
00:16:24.416 --> 00:16:29.563
and we'll say meet with bus painter and
the location would be in the,

328
00:16:29.563 --> 00:16:33.640
let's say the garage,
the garage, there we go.

329
00:16:33.640 --> 00:16:35.959
And we've got that, I can add my notes.

330
00:16:36.980 --> 00:16:42.030
But this is going to be every Monday for
the next two months.

331
00:16:42.030 --> 00:16:45.260
Reoccurrence, over here,
I can click on this.

332
00:16:45.260 --> 00:16:49.820
And now it gives me what my
pattern it needs to be and

333
00:16:49.820 --> 00:16:51.090
how I could designate this.

334
00:16:51.090 --> 00:16:52.810
Is this a daily occurence?

335
00:16:52.810 --> 00:16:55.330
Maybe this is something I
have to do every single day.

336
00:16:55.330 --> 00:16:58.840
Or like when I said every other day,
like every two days.

337
00:16:58.840 --> 00:17:02.810
Notice if I choose daily,
every two days, every four days,

338
00:17:02.810 --> 00:17:05.510
however many days it's going to do.

339
00:17:05.510 --> 00:17:10.500
If I do weekly, okay, reoccurs every
how many weeks on this particular day.

340
00:17:10.500 --> 00:17:12.290
It's checked off on Monday.

341
00:17:12.290 --> 00:17:15.380
Maybe I had to meet with him Monday and
Wednesdays.

342
00:17:15.380 --> 00:17:16.830
So I could go ahead and set this here.

343
00:17:16.830 --> 00:17:20.740
I'd open up Monday's appointment and
set the reoccurrence in here.

344
00:17:20.740 --> 00:17:24.810
The range of the reoccurrence,
no end date in sight.

345
00:17:24.810 --> 00:17:28.690
We're gonna be meeting forever,
or after however many occurences.

346
00:17:28.690 --> 00:17:33.310
This could be, hey, we're gonna meet
six times between now and December.

347
00:17:33.310 --> 00:17:35.020
And it's gonna be every month.

348
00:17:35.020 --> 00:17:40.950
So you could go ahead and set after six
occurences and it could be every month.

349
00:17:40.950 --> 00:17:42.880
Or you have a specific end date.

350
00:17:42.880 --> 00:17:45.645
And I'm going to choose that one
because I just know that it's

351
00:17:45.645 --> 00:17:47.360
gonna be until the end of July.

352
00:17:47.360 --> 00:17:51.090
I don't know how many Mondays
that's going to be, so

353
00:17:51.090 --> 00:17:52.980
I don't know how many
occurrences it's gonna be.

354
00:17:52.980 --> 00:17:55.250
I just know that there's a specific date.

355
00:17:55.250 --> 00:17:59.080
And if the Monday like the every other
Monday is that last week in July.

356
00:17:59.080 --> 00:18:01.460
Okay then that's fine.

357
00:18:01.460 --> 00:18:05.254
So it will go ahead and schedule
accordingly based on the patterns that

358
00:18:05.254 --> 00:18:08.739
you're setting and the specific
date that you want it to end by.

359
00:18:08.739 --> 00:18:12.930
So let's go ahead and choose July 31st.

360
00:18:12.930 --> 00:18:16.950
We're doing every two weeks on a Monday,

361
00:18:16.950 --> 00:18:20.570
it's starting on the 5th cuz
that's the first Monday of June.

362
00:18:20.570 --> 00:18:23.990
We have our time set,
looks good, we click OK.

363
00:18:23.990 --> 00:18:26.580
And now you can see at this little note,

364
00:18:26.580 --> 00:18:30.000
occurs every two weeks on
Monday until this date.

365
00:18:30.000 --> 00:18:33.010
It puts the reoccurrence
down at the bottom.

366
00:18:33.010 --> 00:18:33.720
And I'm good.

367
00:18:33.720 --> 00:18:37.620
I will keep this as busy, keep it as
15 minutes, keep all the default parts.

368
00:18:37.620 --> 00:18:42.350
And I think I've got everything set,
and I'll click Save and Close.

369
00:18:42.350 --> 00:18:48.890
Puts it on, notice if I scroll down,
there's my 9:00 AM, every other week.

370
00:18:48.890 --> 00:18:52.590
And all the way down to, yep,
August, it's off my Calendar.

371
00:18:52.590 --> 00:18:55.650
>> Now, Vaughan, let's say that we met
a couple of times with the Rainbow Sparkle

372
00:18:55.650 --> 00:18:56.480
paint company and

373
00:18:56.480 --> 00:19:00.395
all of a sudden we have to make a decision
between pink flamingo and salmon.

374
00:19:00.395 --> 00:19:01.961
>> [LAUGH]
>> And the fact that I know those

375
00:19:01.961 --> 00:19:05.365
colors probably is saying something but
we can't make up our mind, and

376
00:19:05.365 --> 00:19:08.731
we need to have some other people
come on board with this appointment.

377
00:19:08.731 --> 00:19:11.885
Is there a way that we can tie in other
people to an appointment if we can't

378
00:19:11.885 --> 00:19:13.575
choose the right color?

379
00:19:13.575 --> 00:19:15.075
>> That's a great question.

380
00:19:15.075 --> 00:19:16.135
Yes, we can.

381
00:19:16.135 --> 00:19:18.815
Now there's a couple
ways that we can do this.

382
00:19:18.815 --> 00:19:23.355
We can invite in,
here let me open it up for you.

383
00:19:23.355 --> 00:19:25.775
[LAUGH] So then I can read it off.

384
00:19:25.775 --> 00:19:27.155
And this is actually,

385
00:19:27.155 --> 00:19:29.890
there's a couple things that
we're going to cover right here.

386
00:19:29.890 --> 00:19:33.910
Because this is a reoccurring appointment,
right now.

387
00:19:33.910 --> 00:19:36.420
So, when I'm double-clicking on this one,
on June 5th.

388
00:19:36.420 --> 00:19:40.630
It is asking me, hey, so do you wanna open

389
00:19:40.630 --> 00:19:45.440
just this specific occurrence,
or the entire series?

390
00:19:45.440 --> 00:19:48.990
And this is, where like you're asking,
hey, if I wanted to add in,

391
00:19:48.990 --> 00:19:54.020
I really need Lance's help on this, I'm
wanna go ahead and bring him in on this?

392
00:19:54.020 --> 00:19:58.000
And I want him the whole series, that's
where I could go ahead and determine.

393
00:19:58.000 --> 00:20:00.300
We'll go ahead and
do another situation where hey,

394
00:20:00.300 --> 00:20:04.970
maybe the bus driver calls and
says hey that first week in July.

395
00:20:04.970 --> 00:20:08.130
I can't meet on Monday but I can meet
on Wednesday for you but, just for

396
00:20:08.130 --> 00:20:09.380
that one week.

397
00:20:09.380 --> 00:20:13.056
That would be an instance that we
would say hey, just go ahead and

398
00:20:13.056 --> 00:20:17.687
open up this one particular event or
this one occurrence, not the whole series,

399
00:20:17.687 --> 00:20:21.296
let's move that first week in
July's meeting to Wednesday but

400
00:20:21.296 --> 00:20:24.380
then after that we keep on
our regular occurrence.

401
00:20:24.380 --> 00:20:27.060
>> So
that attribute doesn't propagate itself

402
00:20:27.060 --> 00:20:28.730
to the rest of the series as well, right?

403
00:20:28.730 --> 00:20:32.800
>> Exactly, if we choose just
this one when editing this

404
00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:36.600
particular appointment because it says
right here is it part of a series.

405
00:20:36.600 --> 00:20:37.940
So what do you want to do?

406
00:20:37.940 --> 00:20:43.870
The entire series or
just that one particular event?

407
00:20:43.870 --> 00:20:45.710
I had to choose my, I almost said meeting.

408
00:20:45.710 --> 00:20:46.990
I'm like, wait, it's not a meeting.

409
00:20:46.990 --> 00:20:50.340
Gotta use that vocabulary correctly
because we kind of interchange it all and

410
00:20:50.340 --> 00:20:51.950
it all gets blended together.

411
00:20:51.950 --> 00:20:54.190
So let's go with the whole series.

412
00:20:54.190 --> 00:20:55.883
We click OK.

413
00:20:55.883 --> 00:21:02.230
And yes, I can go ahead and
invite attendees.

414
00:21:02.230 --> 00:21:05.192
I keep my switching the i's and
the a's around in there.

415
00:21:05.192 --> 00:21:07.344
[LAUGH] But
there's a lot of e's in there too.

416
00:21:07.344 --> 00:21:09.390
So, [LAUGH] lots of those.

417
00:21:09.390 --> 00:21:13.910
If I invite Attendees,
then it becomes a meeting.

418
00:21:13.910 --> 00:21:18.000
Which is fine, there's nothing wrong with
that, it's just going to once you rope him

419
00:21:18.000 --> 00:21:21.860
in, then it's going to do the whole
emailing him, putting on his calendar,

420
00:21:21.860 --> 00:21:23.460
letting him accept it.

421
00:21:23.460 --> 00:21:26.970
Great way to go ahead and
bring that person in.

422
00:21:26.970 --> 00:21:30.740
Or if you didn't wanna necessarily
bring him in as a meeting but

423
00:21:30.740 --> 00:21:35.090
you wanna let Lance know,
hey, this is my appointment.

424
00:21:35.090 --> 00:21:40.780
And I wanna give it to you as your
own appointment, not as a meeting.

425
00:21:40.780 --> 00:21:42.170
You can do what's known as forwarding,

426
00:21:42.170 --> 00:21:47.570
and when you forward this particular
message, or this appointment sorry.

427
00:21:47.570 --> 00:21:52.760
It's sending it as an item, just like
when we were doing sharing of contacts.

428
00:21:52.760 --> 00:21:56.410
I want to forward a contact
to one of my friends, and

429
00:21:56.410 --> 00:22:02.190
it brings it up as either a A VCF or
an Outlook item.

430
00:22:02.190 --> 00:22:05.040
So either one because
we're all using Outlook.

431
00:22:05.040 --> 00:22:06.130
So I could go ahead and do this.

432
00:22:06.130 --> 00:22:10.220
And notice that the different options
here is forward and forward is iCalendar.

433
00:22:10.220 --> 00:22:12.500
This would be if I was
forwarding it as an iCalendar,

434
00:22:12.500 --> 00:22:16.058
that might be one that where
somebody is not using Outlook.

435
00:22:16.058 --> 00:22:19.840
So I wanna go ahead and give it to them
in a particular format like a generic

436
00:22:19.840 --> 00:22:24.600
format that all calendars and
mail programs go ahead and talk in.

437
00:22:24.600 --> 00:22:27.310
Like if I was doing a Yahoo or
Google for somebody.

438
00:22:27.310 --> 00:22:31.930
But since we're sending it to Lance
as a forward, as an appointment,

439
00:22:31.930 --> 00:22:36.640
I'll just go ahead and use the forward
option here and then click this.

440
00:22:36.640 --> 00:22:40.520
Notice that it does choose
as an Outlook item.

441
00:22:40.520 --> 00:22:45.440
And then I could go ahead and bring this
over to Lance and for this meeting, I can

442
00:22:45.440 --> 00:22:52.660
give him a little note for you to put on
your calendar to know about painting.

443
00:22:52.660 --> 00:22:54.770
I actually typed that all right.

444
00:22:55.870 --> 00:22:56.640
Amazing.

445
00:22:56.640 --> 00:23:02.000
And then I can send that on to him,
and yes I am sending it from Joey.

446
00:23:02.000 --> 00:23:03.370
Always double checking.

447
00:23:03.370 --> 00:23:07.512
I've just got in a habit before you
click that send button, double check,

448
00:23:07.512 --> 00:23:09.561
yes that is to who I want it to, good.

449
00:23:09.561 --> 00:23:11.540
Cuz you don't wanna send
emails to the wrong person.

450
00:23:11.540 --> 00:23:15.352
Cuz you do it once you're like ooh,
all right, [LAUGH].

451
00:23:15.352 --> 00:23:17.830
So I always double check
myself before moving on.

452
00:23:17.830 --> 00:23:22.350
And then we'll go ahead and jump over
to Lance and see what he sees, and

453
00:23:22.350 --> 00:23:25.010
then we can go ahead and
move it onto his appointment.

454
00:23:25.010 --> 00:23:27.850
So make sure I go ahead and
do that there, Wes.

455
00:23:27.850 --> 00:23:28.390
>> Will do.

456
00:23:28.390 --> 00:23:30.390
>> Perfect, so, but back to the,

457
00:23:30.390 --> 00:23:35.039
because we got a couple little trees going
off on here, I wanna get back to that hey.

458
00:23:36.160 --> 00:23:40.600
The first week in July, I need to move
that appointment for just that one.

459
00:23:40.600 --> 00:23:43.770
Okay, so I am in June, there is July.

460
00:23:43.770 --> 00:23:45.130
Okay, there's July 3rd, so

461
00:23:45.130 --> 00:23:48.046
that looks like that is the first one,
because it's 4th July.

462
00:23:48.046 --> 00:23:49.102
Plan that.

463
00:23:49.102 --> 00:23:53.746
[LAUGH] So
he needs to meet with us on Wednesday.

464
00:23:53.746 --> 00:23:56.201
Now I can already tell that
Wednesday's not gonna work for me,

465
00:23:56.201 --> 00:23:59.462
because I'm looking at my Calendar and
it looks like I have a Director's meeting.

466
00:23:59.462 --> 00:24:02.304
So, maybe I've talked to him and
said Hey, well all go ahead.

467
00:24:02.304 --> 00:24:06.371
How about we meet on the 7th?

468
00:24:06.371 --> 00:24:07.990
We'll meet on that Friday.

469
00:24:07.990 --> 00:24:11.330
Because I have to make sure I'm looking at
my calendar that it doesn't work for me.

470
00:24:11.330 --> 00:24:14.560
Now this is all we're talking
over the phone, by the way.

471
00:24:14.560 --> 00:24:18.360
And when we start getting to meetings,
this can all be done by Email.

472
00:24:18.360 --> 00:24:21.369
So, you can see why there might be
reasons why you want to do meetings.

473
00:24:22.560 --> 00:24:28.110
We'll go ahead and open this one instance
of this re-occurring appointment.

474
00:24:29.370 --> 00:24:34.940
Going to move this over to the start date
is going to be the 7th, so that's Friday.

475
00:24:34.940 --> 00:24:37.830
Go ahead and click Save.

476
00:24:37.830 --> 00:24:39.700
Now, you change the date
of these occurrence, so

477
00:24:39.700 --> 00:24:41.380
we get to change all
the dates of [INAUDIBLE].

478
00:24:41.380 --> 00:24:45.211
It is also reminding me right now, hey,
are you sure you know where you are at?

479
00:24:45.211 --> 00:24:48.865
Okay, yes I'm glad that you're giving
me a little prompt to say like hey,

480
00:24:48.865 --> 00:24:51.486
if you like the whole series
to move to every Fridays.

481
00:24:51.486 --> 00:24:54.150
Now, just this one, so I click Yes.

482
00:24:54.150 --> 00:24:57.910
And then that moves on over, but
you can see the regular re-occurrence and

483
00:24:57.910 --> 00:25:00.530
the pattern stays in tact.

484
00:25:00.530 --> 00:25:02.850
So that's why you can go ahead and
move that.

485
00:25:02.850 --> 00:25:07.150
Let's jump over to Lance right now.

486
00:25:07.150 --> 00:25:09.170
And let's go ahead and
start up his machine.

487
00:25:09.170 --> 00:25:12.070
I thought I had it on, but
I guess it, he went to sleep.

488
00:25:12.070 --> 00:25:13.155
He's a little tired.

489
00:25:13.155 --> 00:25:16.080
[LAUGH] Let's go ahead and sign him in.

490
00:25:16.080 --> 00:25:21.110
It'll bring up Lance,
notice I am in Lance inbox right here.

491
00:25:21.110 --> 00:25:26.120
I have that Joey has forwarded
me a meeting with a bus painter.

492
00:25:26.120 --> 00:25:27.850
I can open it.

493
00:25:27.850 --> 00:25:32.886
And once I open it, it opens right
here into an appointment series.

494
00:25:32.886 --> 00:25:36.770
And so, it's giving me the option for
me, look at right at the top.

495
00:25:36.770 --> 00:25:42.623
To copy to my calendar,
not as an attendee of a meeting,

496
00:25:42.623 --> 00:25:46.368
as my calendar for my appointment.

497
00:25:46.368 --> 00:25:48.102
I say OK here.

498
00:25:48.102 --> 00:25:51.140
I come over to my calendar.

499
00:25:51.140 --> 00:25:56.520
And notice that now that same appointment
that was on Joey's calendar has

500
00:25:56.520 --> 00:25:58.970
now been copied over to Lance's calendar.

501
00:25:58.970 --> 00:26:01.994
And so everybody knows, and
it's pretty easy to do.

502
00:26:01.994 --> 00:26:06.671
So I think that's pretty much everything
I have to cover about appointments.

503
00:26:06.671 --> 00:26:09.290
They're for you,
you set up the re-occurrences.

504
00:26:09.290 --> 00:26:10.850
You can categorize them.

505
00:26:10.850 --> 00:26:13.380
Make them all pretty, and then,
go ahead and, you know what?

506
00:26:13.380 --> 00:26:14.401
Get your life in order.

507
00:26:14.401 --> 00:26:16.310
So [LAUGH]
>> A lot of great information there,

508
00:26:16.310 --> 00:26:18.050
Vonne about making appointments.

509
00:26:18.050 --> 00:26:20.880
Now, it does look like one thing
that we're running short on is,

510
00:26:20.880 --> 00:26:22.140
well, time in this episode.

511
00:26:22.140 --> 00:26:25.340
But, before we do, do you have any final
words that you might want to impart to

512
00:26:25.340 --> 00:26:28.290
our viewers about managing
appointments inside of Outlook?

513
00:26:28.290 --> 00:26:32.400
I would say just make sure to organize
them however, it makes sense for you.

514
00:26:32.400 --> 00:26:35.940
You know, your mess is your mess,
as I always say.

515
00:26:35.940 --> 00:26:38.930
Me and my mom would always say, how could
you find anything in that room of yours?

516
00:26:38.930 --> 00:26:42.585
I know which piles are the kind of clean,
and then half clean.

517
00:26:42.585 --> 00:26:44.374
We all have our own organization.

518
00:26:44.374 --> 00:26:48.815
So, use those categories,
go ahead and make your notes.

519
00:26:48.815 --> 00:26:52.495
The notes are really important,
and just try to keep yourself as

520
00:26:52.495 --> 00:26:55.705
organized as possible, because that's
what we're all trying to do, so.

521
00:26:55.705 --> 00:26:56.565
>> All right Vonne.

522
00:26:56.565 --> 00:27:00.115
As always, we appreciate having you in
the studios with us at OfficeProTV, and

523
00:27:00.115 --> 00:27:01.835
we appreciate you the viewer watching.

524
00:27:01.835 --> 00:27:03.595
Signing out I've been your host,
Wes Brian.

525
00:27:03.595 --> 00:27:04.495
>> And I'm Vonne Smith.

526
00:27:04.495 --> 00:27:06.472
>> And we'll see you next time.

527
00:27:06.472 --> 00:27:11.482

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne take a look at creating and managing meetings inside of Outlook. They look at creating a new meeting, as well as meeting attributes, editing, changing the properties of a meeting and the various responses to meeting invitation.
episodes.title: Create and Manage Meetings

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne take a look at sharing and transferring calendars inside, from and to, Outlook. They look at forwarding, sharing, importing, exporting and publishing a calendar.
episodes.title: Share and Transfer Calendars

You have to go into your more options,
so that were,

81
00:04:03.143 --> 00:04:06.603
back in those references that I gave you,
this is on those steps.

82
00:04:06.603 --> 00:04:10.187

what is the date range?

83
00:04:10.187 --> 00:04:14.290
Now this is where do I wanna go ahead and

84
00:04:14.290 --> 00:04:15.235
The next 30 days?

85
00:04:15.235 --> 00:04:17.490
But I want the whole calendar,

86
00:04:17.490 --> 00:04:22.420
because if I was moving all over into
Google and not using Outlook anymore,

87
00:04:22.420 --> 00:04:28.110
I'd probably want the whole thing, or
maybe like from now until whenever.

88
00:04:28.110 --> 00:04:33.100
So you could specify the dates or have the
ones that they have as like the next 30,

89
00:04:33.100 --> 00:04:34.280
the next seven.

90
00:04:34.280 --> 00:04:35.510
So when does it start?

91
00:04:35.510 --> 00:04:36.720
When does it end?

92
00:04:36.720 --> 00:04:42.070
What do I want to go ahead and give out,
so I can go over into that full details.

93
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:44.811
You could also come into the advanced,
and you could see that right there.

94
00:04:44.811 --> 00:04:47.297
Include details of items marked private.

95
00:04:47.297 --> 00:04:51.037
That would be like if you were the owner
of the calendar going into another

96
00:04:51.037 --> 00:04:52.000
account.

97
00:04:52.000 --> 00:04:55.820
You could do this, but of course if you
were exporting this out to somebody else

98
00:04:55.820 --> 00:04:59.600
for them to be able to see in that format.

99
00:04:59.600 --> 00:05:03.570
Rather than, the sharing of the calendars
or the publish options that we did.

100
00:05:03.570 --> 00:05:06.620
You're actually just giving
them the whole file for

101
00:05:06.620 --> 00:05:08.930
them to be able to do
what they need with it.

102
00:05:08.930 --> 00:05:12.880
You might not wanna include these two
different things, or include attachments

103
00:05:12.880 --> 00:05:16.830
within calendar items, because you could
always attach them into the notes.

104
00:05:16.830 --> 00:05:20.860
So those are your options
that you would want to do.

105
00:05:20.860 --> 00:05:23.899
Let´s go ahead and
do just the next three days for now, and

106
00:05:23.899 --> 00:05:26.146
we will do full details and
I will click OK.

107
00:05:26.146 --> 00:05:29.980
I'll put this out on the desktop and
I'll click Save.

108
00:05:29.980 --> 00:05:34.991
So now that file is saved as
that iCal format right here, and

109
00:05:34.991 --> 00:05:41.204
you could see this would be the file that
I would transfer to a share drive or

110
00:05:41.204 --> 00:05:46.515
put up on your Google drive, or
wherever you would need to go and

111
00:05:46.515 --> 00:05:49.347
be able to import it into Google.

112
00:05:49.347 --> 00:05:51.041
I've already kind of hinted on that,
like all right.

113
00:05:51.041 --> 00:05:55.522
Well now you can get stuff out,
what about bringing stuff in?

114
00:05:55.522 --> 00:05:59.806
Maybe you are coming from
Google into Outlook, and

115
00:05:59.806 --> 00:06:02.803
you need to bring your calendar in.

116
00:06:02.803 --> 00:06:07.230
Well the first step would be in Google,
you'd have to export it out.

117
00:06:07.230 --> 00:06:11.770
And then now you'd have to import it in,
okay so there's both sides.

118
00:06:11.770 --> 00:06:13.710
You've gotta kind of get each one.

119
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:16.780
And those steps in the references
like I said will do it.

120
00:06:16.780 --> 00:06:21.010
So if I'm here in Outlook I
need to bring in a calendar.

121
00:06:21.010 --> 00:06:24.010
This is where you do go to open and
export.

122
00:06:24.010 --> 00:06:28.020
You would come into the import and export.

123
00:06:28.020 --> 00:06:31.370
I am going to import this here.

124
00:06:31.370 --> 00:06:34.460
It's not gonna be another program or file,
because it actually has right there import

125
00:06:34.460 --> 00:06:40.900
an iCalendar, the ICS or
the VCS file format.

126
00:06:40.900 --> 00:06:47.630
And this is where you would go out and
find that exported Google calendar format.

127
00:06:47.630 --> 00:06:51.550
Find the file that you want,
click open, go to the next steps.

128
00:06:51.550 --> 00:06:55.091
I'm not going to complete this, cuz I
don't want it to mess up the rest of my

129
00:06:55.091 --> 00:06:58.740
calendar and everything is, I don't
need to import a calendar right now.

130
00:06:58.740 --> 00:07:02.890
But those would be the steps that you
would need to do to import calendar in.

131
00:07:04.430 --> 00:07:08.287
Last thing,
that showing of your Google Calendar.

132
00:07:08.287 --> 00:07:13.935
Over here in Lance's account,
I have already done the steps for

133
00:07:13.935 --> 00:07:18.340
that and

134
00:07:18.340 --> 00:07:25.522
So I can see this and I have Chris,
because pretend this is Lance's calendar.

135
00:07:25.522 --> 00:07:28.860
But the only Gmail account I
have created is for Chris.

136
00:07:28.860 --> 00:07:31.410
And so
I could see the calendar right along side.

137
00:07:31.410 --> 00:07:32.410
I can see all the appointments.

138
00:07:32.410 --> 00:07:34.120
If I try to open them.

139
00:07:34.120 --> 00:07:36.580
Okay, well there's lunch with JC.

140
00:07:36.580 --> 00:07:42.705
Now if I try to make a change,
it's going to not let me change this.

141
00:07:42.705 --> 00:07:44.257
So if you're like, I could get into it.

142
00:07:44.257 --> 00:07:46.350
Well yeah,
that's cuz you can see the details.

143
00:07:46.350 --> 00:07:50.750
But you can't make any changes,
because it is a read only folder.

144
00:07:50.750 --> 00:07:53.570
So that way you can at least,
I don't need to save my changes,

145
00:07:53.570 --> 00:07:55.250
cuz I can't make changes.

146
00:07:55.250 --> 00:07:59.570
And so you can see those,
that calendar right next to you.

147
00:07:59.570 --> 00:08:02.508
And this is Google Calendar,
that's wonderful.

148
00:08:02.508 --> 00:08:06.950
I just want to jump back over to Joey
to give you that reference here,

149
00:08:06.950 --> 00:08:11.620
is that you do have to subscribe
to your Google Calendar.

150
00:08:11.620 --> 00:08:16.630
So that's where, you have to do this
setting in your Google Calendar

151
00:08:16.630 --> 00:08:21.600
to set up that I am going to under
a private address click this button.

152
00:08:21.600 --> 00:08:23.280
Get that shortcut, notice that note,

153
00:08:23.280 --> 00:08:27.330
it says don't click it, make sure
you right click on it to copy it.

154
00:08:27.330 --> 00:08:32.540
And then in Outlook, you're gonna
come into your account settings.

155
00:08:32.540 --> 00:08:39.533
Go on the Internet Calendar tab,
click New, and then paste that address in.

156
00:08:39.533 --> 00:08:44.613
And so that is what, no this is Joey.

157
00:08:44.613 --> 00:08:51.183
[LAUGH] Back over here, this is
where Lance in his account settings.

158
00:08:51.183 --> 00:08:55.914
In the Internet Calendars,
there's that address that I had

159
00:08:55.914 --> 00:09:00.657
gotten from Chris's,
that is the totally wrong computer.

160
00:09:00.657 --> 00:09:04.553
[LAUGH] Okay, sorry guys.

161
00:09:04.553 --> 00:09:07.665
I'm giving you a little,
there you go, there´s Lance.

162
00:09:07.665 --> 00:09:08.525
There we go.

163
00:09:08.525 --> 00:09:10.015
So in his calendar,

164
00:09:10.015 --> 00:09:14.660
this is Chris's calandar,
we are all over the map today, aren't we?

165
00:09:14.660 --> 00:09:16.890
I went ahead and made those adjustments.

166
00:09:16.890 --> 00:09:20.700
So if I made any changes
in the Google Calendar,

167
00:09:20.700 --> 00:09:25.890
it would then update in the view
of my Outlook Calendar.

168
00:09:27.105 --> 00:09:29.785
Sorry, I took you on a couple of trips
around there to all of these different

169
00:09:29.785 --> 00:09:31.445

170
00:09:31.445 --> 00:09:34.995
But that does cover all of the other
things that I wanted to show you about

171
00:09:34.995 --> 00:09:39.037
the importing, the exporting,
especially from the Google to Outlook,

172
00:09:39.037 --> 00:09:40.520
cuz that's a big thing.

173
00:09:40.520 --> 00:09:44.350
And then of course seeing your
Google calendar within Outlook.

174
00:09:44.350 --> 00:09:45.430
>> Well I think you did a great job,

cuz I have a hard time

176

>> [LAUGH]
>> Let alone 4 or 5 of them.

177
00:09:49.485 --> 00:09:52.855
Vonne we appreciate you taking the time to

we have when it comes to sharing and

179
00:09:56.025 --> 00:09:58.213
excuse me calendars,
that was the other episode.

180
00:09:58.213 --> 00:09:59.020
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

181

>> That's right, but

before we sign out do you have any final

with the calendars between

>> Just always make and sure you know

know which virtual machine
you're going into, and

what account that you need to control.

187

[LAUGH]
>> All right.

188

Well, Vonne, as always we appreciate

00:10:17.748 --> 00:10:19.320
