episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne take a look at tasks and notes inside of Outlook 2016. They discuss the interface, arrangement, columns, view settings and more. They demonstrate creating, updating, assigning as well as forwarding tasks. They also will talk about notes inside of Outlook.
episodes.title: Tasks and Notes
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.549 --> 00:00:05.537
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.537 --> 00:00:07.080
Hello and welcome to OfficeProTV.

3
00:00:07.080 --> 00:00:08.510
We're glad you're joining us today.

4
00:00:08.510 --> 00:00:09.890
We got a great episode for you.

5
00:00:09.890 --> 00:00:11.390
I'm your show host Wes Bryan.

6
00:00:11.390 --> 00:00:15.000
In today's episode, we're going to
be looking at more Outlook 2016.

7
00:00:15.000 --> 00:00:18.035
And joining us back in the studios
is none other than Miss Vonne Smith.

8
00:00:18.035 --> 00:00:19.250
Vonne, how you doing today?

9
00:00:19.250 --> 00:00:20.400
I'm fantastic.

10
00:00:20.400 --> 00:00:22.820
So, Wes I have a task for you.

11
00:00:22.820 --> 00:00:24.140
No, goodness.

12
00:00:24.140 --> 00:00:25.340
Is to keep me in check.

13
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:25.845
Okay.

14
00:00:25.845 --> 00:00:27.810
[LAUGH] Deal.

15
00:00:27.810 --> 00:00:28.480
Awesome.

16
00:00:28.480 --> 00:00:30.260
Well, then I can mark you as complete.

17
00:00:30.260 --> 00:00:33.050
Because today,
we're going to be talking all about tasks.

18
00:00:33.050 --> 00:00:34.210
Did you see what I did there?

19
00:00:34.210 --> 00:00:35.390
I seen that, I seen that.

20
00:00:35.390 --> 00:00:37.880
Yeah.
So, we're gonna be talking about tasks and

21
00:00:37.880 --> 00:00:39.230
also notes.

22
00:00:39.230 --> 00:00:43.760
So that the two, I guess, last areas
of Outlook that we haven't covered,

23
00:00:43.760 --> 00:00:46.710
again, if you're watching in succession.

24
00:00:46.710 --> 00:00:50.248
So Outlook is great for
emailing and for calendars and

25
00:00:50.248 --> 00:00:54.579
contact, but you can also go ahead and
create your own to do list.

26
00:00:54.579 --> 00:00:58.590
And be able to track how much you have
completed, what you haven't completed.

27
00:00:58.590 --> 00:01:02.943
You could assign tasks to others just
like I assigned the task to Wesk, Wesk.

28
00:01:02.943 --> 00:01:04.191
[LAUGH] That's right.

29
00:01:04.191 --> 00:01:07.300
[LAUGH] Adding those keys
everywhere around here.

30
00:01:07.300 --> 00:01:08.090
So I could go ahead and

31
00:01:08.090 --> 00:01:12.250
assign that task to Wes and
have him go ahead and complete it.

32
00:01:12.250 --> 00:01:16.520
And then, have him give me
status reports on his progress.

33
00:01:16.520 --> 00:01:20.190
So, all of those different things
you can do within Outlook.

34
00:01:20.190 --> 00:01:23.680
And then notes, notes are just like
notes that you write for yourself.

35
00:01:23.680 --> 00:01:24.380
And you could go ahead and

36
00:01:24.380 --> 00:01:28.490
put a little sticky note on your monitor,
I´m kind of notorious for doing that, and

37
00:01:28.490 --> 00:01:31.840
all my different colors and everything,
they´re like electronic sticky notes.

38
00:01:31.840 --> 00:01:35.460
They´re really just for
you to have some notes.

39
00:01:35.460 --> 00:01:37.870
Now, there is a whole
product called OneNote,

40
00:01:37.870 --> 00:01:40.150
which is pretty fantastic
I will let you say.

41
00:01:40.150 --> 00:01:41.490
I will let you say?

42
00:01:41.490 --> 00:01:45.870
I will let you know, and I will say to
you, but that´s a whole other show and

43
00:01:45.870 --> 00:01:51.560
a whole other topic that I really wanna
go ahead and film a whole series on that.

44
00:01:51.560 --> 00:01:55.032
So stay tuned and hopefully look for
it in your library.

45
00:01:55.032 --> 00:01:59.590
So let's go ahead and
get down into Joey's machine here.

46
00:01:59.590 --> 00:02:00.950
We've got his email open.

47
00:02:00.950 --> 00:02:04.310
And so
I need to get to the task area of Outlook.

48
00:02:04.310 --> 00:02:09.420
Down here in our Navigation Pane,
that's where we can get to our tasks.

49
00:02:09.420 --> 00:02:11.570
We've been through our calendar and
our contacts.

50
00:02:11.570 --> 00:02:16.570
The little checkbox little list looking
thing, that's your to-do list, your tasks.

51
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:20.740
And just like any other area of Outlook,

52
00:02:20.740 --> 00:02:24.370
you can start changing the views
of what you're looking at.

53
00:02:24.370 --> 00:02:29.440
Right now,
this is in I think the to-do list view.

54
00:02:29.440 --> 00:02:32.000
I believe so,
it does say to do list up at the top so

55
00:02:32.000 --> 00:02:33.600
I´m pretty sure that´s what it is.

56
00:02:33.600 --> 00:02:37.287
Where we´ve been going in all of our
different areas, to change our views,

57
00:02:37.287 --> 00:02:38.960
we go over to our view tab.

58
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:44.940
And in this view tab we have the different
types of created, ready to go views here.

59
00:02:44.940 --> 00:02:46.390
There´s quite a few of them here.

60
00:02:46.390 --> 00:02:50.250
A little bit more than we have seen
in our other areas with details,

61
00:02:50.250 --> 00:02:52.600
simple lists, priorities.

62
00:02:52.600 --> 00:02:54.680
Remember, this is your tasks list.

63
00:02:54.680 --> 00:02:56.740
What am I supposed to do?

64
00:02:56.740 --> 00:03:00.660
What am I supposed to give myself,
like reminders of my daily chores?

65
00:03:00.660 --> 00:03:02.610
Now, how is this different
from appointments?

66
00:03:02.610 --> 00:03:05.426
You might be asking yourself that.

67
00:03:05.426 --> 00:03:07.281
Well, not much.

68
00:03:07.281 --> 00:03:09.810
[LAUGHS] I guess they´re really
just in two different areas.

69
00:03:09.810 --> 00:03:12.649
It´s really how you want
to organize yourself.

70
00:03:15.050 --> 00:03:17.456
Your appointments they go in a calendar.

71
00:03:17.456 --> 00:03:19.500
So, you're going to see
it within your calendar.

72
00:03:19.500 --> 00:03:23.693
Your tasks is really just a to do list,
and it can be prioritized or

73
00:03:23.693 --> 00:03:28.134
organized with end dates,
because you can give yourself due dates.

74
00:03:28.134 --> 00:03:31.956
So, it's really just how you want to put
what you need to do to keep yourself

75
00:03:31.956 --> 00:03:32.630
organized.

76
00:03:32.630 --> 00:03:36.840
I like to do something like here,
what are the plants for next week?

77
00:03:36.840 --> 00:03:39.433
Plan JC's surprise party.

78
00:03:39.433 --> 00:03:43.693
I mean that's no necessarily
an appointment that I need to go to be at

79
00:03:43.693 --> 00:03:48.028
somewhere, it's just something
that I need to write down of, hey,

80
00:03:48.028 --> 00:03:49.854
let's go ahead and do this.

81
00:03:49.854 --> 00:03:52.840
I'm gonna go ahead and put some
notes in with this particular thing.

82
00:03:52.840 --> 00:03:55.240
And let me track my progress.

83
00:03:55.240 --> 00:03:57.095
That's where you would maybe
put your stuff in tasks.

84
00:03:57.095 --> 00:04:01.335
But I can see where the line of what
should I put as an appointment and

85
00:04:01.335 --> 00:04:05.750
what should I put as a task it could
be a small blur in the middle there.

86
00:04:05.750 --> 00:04:11.496
So pick and choose which ever
way you feel most comfortable.

87
00:04:11.496 --> 00:04:14.660
Speaking about most comfortable,
what about our views.

88
00:04:14.660 --> 00:04:18.840
The to do list right here, it does give
me the ones that have the little flags.

89
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:23.230
Now we've covered this in our other
episodes when we were doing our email.

90
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:26.385
We could flag our emails for followup.

91
00:04:26.385 --> 00:04:29.144
And that was just like within our emails,
if it starts three red and

92
00:04:29.144 --> 00:04:32.540
it's got that little red flag next to it,
I know that's an indication to me that,

93
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:33.890
hey, this email is important.

94
00:04:33.890 --> 00:04:35.560
You need to follow up on it.

95
00:04:35.560 --> 00:04:39.680
Maybe I needed to do research some things
first before I respond to that email.

96
00:04:39.680 --> 00:04:43.810
That goes ahead and gets flagged,
but it goes into your to do

97
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:48.420
list cuz you're telling yourself hey, you
need to follow up on this particular item.

98
00:04:48.420 --> 00:04:52.960
So that's why we have some of them in
this particular list that are more red,

99
00:04:52.960 --> 00:04:54.890
well I guess they are red.

100
00:04:54.890 --> 00:04:59.440
And some that are black because they
come from either being flags in email or

101
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:04.960
an actual task that I created for
myself within the tasks area.

102
00:05:04.960 --> 00:05:08.730
You can see over here there's some
other icons within this view,

103
00:05:08.730 --> 00:05:10.260
to where it has a little bell.

104
00:05:10.260 --> 00:05:11.770
That means it has a reminder on it,

105
00:05:11.770 --> 00:05:14.310
just like we can put
a reminder on our appointment.

106
00:05:14.310 --> 00:05:16.640
These other icons depend
on whether it came from,

107
00:05:16.640 --> 00:05:19.080
like this is indicating
that this is a meeting.

108
00:05:19.080 --> 00:05:22.980
This is indicated this is created
from a task, this is really small.

109
00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:25.920
But you can see that there's one that

00:29:14.044 --> 00:29:18.360
I could, this is my note,
ooh wow, that's a really good one.

569
00:29:18.360 --> 00:29:23.325
If I want to make a new one,
I could say new note number three.

570
00:29:23.325 --> 00:29:25.115
And all you do is just close it.

571
00:29:25.115 --> 00:29:27.095
And you can move them around.

572
00:29:27.095 --> 00:29:30.920
You can put categories on them, so that
way when you start doing your searching,

573
00:29:30.920 --> 00:29:35.915
it'll search for anything in Outlook
with this particular category.

574
00:29:35.915 --> 00:29:37.315
So you could go there.

575
00:29:37.315 --> 00:29:40.825
You could forward a note.

576
00:29:40.825 --> 00:29:43.563
Just like you could forward a contact and
everything like that.

577
00:29:43.563 --> 00:29:44.995
You could print it.

578
00:29:44.995 --> 00:29:50.820
I could put them into the last
seven days and new notes.

579
00:29:50.820 --> 00:29:53.670
And this is not like as an afterthought,
but

580
00:29:53.670 --> 00:29:58.520
there's really not much more you
can do with your notes necessarily.

581
00:29:58.520 --> 00:30:02.230
It's just your notes.

582
00:30:02.230 --> 00:30:03.225
That's all, really.

583
00:30:03.225 --> 00:30:05.860
[LAUGH] I guess views, right there.

584
00:30:05.860 --> 00:30:08.490
We have the small icons,
we could have our lists.

585
00:30:08.490 --> 00:30:11.140
Just the same way that we've done
with all of our different items.

586
00:30:11.140 --> 00:30:14.980
And I can change them, I can reset them,
and I can categorize them.

587
00:30:14.980 --> 00:30:18.470
And that's about it for notes.

588
00:30:18.470 --> 00:30:20.623
But, it's a cute little feature.

589
00:30:20.623 --> 00:30:21.490
[LAUGH] I like to move them around.

590
00:30:21.490 --> 00:30:25.060
I like to make them color coded, and I
really like to write on physical notes for

591
00:30:25.060 --> 00:30:25.990
myself.

592
00:30:25.990 --> 00:30:27.070
And stick them to my monitor.

593
00:30:27.070 --> 00:30:28.320
Just don't put your passwords there.

594
00:30:28.320 --> 00:30:30.180
That's right,
that's never where we put passwords.

595
00:30:30.180 --> 00:30:33.300
Well, that's a great place to wrap it up,
and also to give me a chance to

596
00:30:33.300 --> 00:30:36.580
hit the treadmill before I
tackle the task of eating cake.

597
00:30:36.580 --> 00:30:41.720
So great place there, remember I've been
your host for OfficeProTV, Wes Brian.

598
00:30:41.720 --> 00:30:42.530
And I'm Vonne Smith.

599
00:30:42.530 --> 00:30:43.762
And we'll see you next time.

600
00:30:43.762 --> 00:30:49.060
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Vonne take a look at groups inside of Outlook. They describe what groups are used for, creating, deleting and modifying groups as well as the resources available to members of groups.
episodes.title: Groups
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:05.789
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:05.789 --> 00:00:07.409
Hello, and welcome to OfficeProTV,

3
00:00:07.409 --> 00:00:09.850
accelerating your productivity
in the workplace.

4
00:00:09.850 --> 00:00:10.746
I'm your host, Wes Bryan.

5
00:00:10.746 --> 00:00:14.835
In today's episode, we're continuing
through our series in Office 2016.

6
00:00:14.835 --> 00:00:17.800
Joining us back in the studios is
none other than Ms. Vonne Smith.

7
00:00:17.800 --> 00:00:18.820
How are you doing today, Vonne?

8
00:00:18.820 --> 00:00:23.890
>> I am doing great,
we have come to the groups episode.

9
00:00:23.890 --> 00:00:28.283
Yes, I have been referring to groups
pretty much through the entire show.

10
00:00:28.283 --> 00:00:29.355
[LAUGH] You're like,

11
00:00:29.355 --> 00:00:33.238
I'm gonna find that episode and learn
about what these groups are all about.

12
00:00:33.238 --> 00:00:38.135
So you are here, we're ready to go,
so what is a group?

13
00:00:38.135 --> 00:00:41.507
It's just like you think of
a regular group of people, right?

14
00:00:41.507 --> 00:00:45.319
We're kinda hanging out, and
we have a group, if you wanna say.

15
00:00:45.319 --> 00:00:47.660
We're the hosts, right, of ITProTV.

16
00:00:47.660 --> 00:00:48.369
>> That's right.

17
00:00:48.369 --> 00:00:51.342
>> And we even have an email address for
that, don't we?

18
00:00:51.342 --> 00:00:55.828
>> That's right, it's allhosts@itpro.tv,
if I can remember what our address is.

19
00:00:55.828 --> 00:00:57.924
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] and I'm like,
it's something like that.

20
00:00:57.924 --> 00:01:03.303
[LAUGH] There's something where it's
not just vonne@itprotv or wes@itprotv.

21
00:01:03.303 --> 00:01:07.222
We are hosts@itprotv.

22
00:01:07.222 --> 00:01:10.530
And you might see these
emails all the time like

23
00:01:10.530 --> 00:01:14.070
support@company.com or what have you.

24
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:16.938
So it's not to a specific person.

25
00:01:16.938 --> 00:01:19.894
It is a catch all email if you wanna say.

26
00:01:19.894 --> 00:01:26.510
And so what you could do in Office
365 is you can create your own group.

27
00:01:26.510 --> 00:01:30.040
And the nice thing is,
is that you can do it on your own.

28
00:01:30.040 --> 00:01:33.108
In the sense of, you don't have
to have an administrator do this.

29
00:01:33.108 --> 00:01:37.125
Now I'm gonna pause right there for
a quick little part of like depending on

30
00:01:37.125 --> 00:01:41.145
your security settings and how your
administrator sets up your particular

31
00:01:41.145 --> 00:01:45.890
network, that might have another thing to
where, well, I can't create my own group.

32
00:01:45.890 --> 00:01:49.657
You told me I could create my own group,
Vonne, talk to your IT guy.

33
00:01:49.657 --> 00:01:54.096
[LAUGH] So I don't want to say a blanket
statement because as soon as I say that,

34
00:01:54.096 --> 00:01:55.820
there's some group policy.

35
00:01:55.820 --> 00:01:57.728
I know you know all about group policy,
Wes.

36
00:01:57.728 --> 00:02:01.680
There's something that can make
somebody not do something.

37
00:02:01.680 --> 00:02:03.742
Wow, that was really descriptive.

38
00:02:03.742 --> 00:02:08.220
[LAUGH] So let's go ahead and
jump into our computer.

39
00:02:08.220 --> 00:02:10.710
I brought up a couple websites,
these are in your show notes so

40
00:02:10.710 --> 00:02:15.980
definitely look at that, and learning
all about what is an Office 365 group.

41
00:02:15.980 --> 00:02:20.713
Just like I said, it's a group of people,
and it allows you to collaborate with

42
00:02:20.713 --> 00:02:25.391
your teammates within the same circle,
if you wanna say, your same network.

43
00:02:25.391 --> 00:02:30.129
Maybe we have a project coming up, like
a big project that's gonna be lasting for

44
00:02:30.129 --> 00:02:32.790
six months and it's for
the marketing team.

45
00:02:32.790 --> 00:02:35.962
And we decided that we are gonna
need to have our own calendar

46
00:02:35.962 --> 00:02:37.049
to be able to set up.

47
00:02:37.049 --> 00:02:39.850
And it's very specific to
this particular project.

48
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:43.201
And we're going to need to have
some of our different tasks and

49
00:02:43.201 --> 00:02:46.816
we wanna be able to collaborate with
each other on all of our notes.

50
00:02:46.816 --> 00:02:49.855
You can create a group and
you can name it and

51
00:02:49.855 --> 00:02:53.839
you get your own email that
is separate from your email.

52
00:02:53.839 --> 00:02:55.753
That you could go ahead and

53
00:02:55.753 --> 00:03:01.060
email everybody at one time like
projectamazingness@itprotv.com,

54
00:03:01.060 --> 00:03:05.150
and then everybody on that
particular group gets that.

55
00:03:05.150 --> 00:03:06.380
You can have conversations.

56
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:09.930
It's a great way to collaborate,
so it's pretty cool.

57
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.990
And you can see in this particular article
or this website that's talking about,

58
00:03:13.990 --> 00:03:17.880
your groups, what do you get in a group?

59
00:03:17.880 --> 00:03:20.810
You get a shared inbox for conversations.

60
00:03:20.810 --> 00:03:22.450
You get a shared calendar.

61
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:26.160
You get your own SharePoint
document library.

62
00:03:26.160 --> 00:03:30.080
You can also think of it
as your own OneDrive folder

63
00:03:30.080 --> 00:03:33.800
that is separate than your
personal OneDrive folder.

64
00:03:33.800 --> 00:03:36.010
Let me clarify that.

65
00:03:36.010 --> 00:03:41.131
Your OneDrive 2016, not the one that's
on your OS on your Windows machine,

66
00:03:41.131 --> 00:03:46.121
your OneNote 2016 that you have all
of your files storage and everything.

67
00:03:46.121 --> 00:03:49.888
But it's separate, so
I have regular work, specific group and

68
00:03:49.888 --> 00:03:54.520
then everybody within that group can
share documents with each other.

69
00:03:54.520 --> 00:03:58.596
You can even have your own SharePoint
team site where you can have your

70
00:03:58.596 --> 00:04:02.257
own website if you wanna say,
your intranet with each other.

71
00:04:02.257 --> 00:04:04.361
And you also get this
thing called Planner.

72
00:04:04.361 --> 00:04:09.335
Planner is another application
within the Office 365 suite.

73
00:04:09.335 --> 00:04:13.617
Now this is what it's saying that you get
as the default settings of creating group

74
00:04:13.617 --> 00:04:14.390
in Outlook.

75
00:04:14.390 --> 00:04:16.310
Remember, every network's
a little bit different,

76
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:18.760
so make sure you contact your
IT people about that one.

77
00:04:18.760 --> 00:04:22.620
>> Vonne, this seems like the concept's
a lot like in a Window's domain,

78
00:04:22.620 --> 00:04:26.310
where we group people together, based
on a level of access they might need,

79
00:04:26.310 --> 00:04:29.580
a certain amount of
resources they might need or

80
00:04:29.580 --> 00:04:31.600
a role that they're performing
within our company.

81
00:04:31.600 --> 00:04:33.790
And it doesn't look like
it's much different here.

82
00:04:33.790 --> 00:04:35.405
>> Spoken like a true techie, yeah.

83
00:04:35.405 --> 00:04:37.838
[LAUGH] I'm like, exactly, yep.

84
00:04:37.838 --> 00:04:42.990
[LAUGH] And that's what they're letting
you do as users to create it yourself.

85
00:04:42.990 --> 00:04:46.398
But you are right,
it does allocate specific resources.

86
00:04:46.398 --> 00:04:49.732
And there are parts in this article
that talks about like, hey,

87
00:04:49.732 --> 00:04:53.340
when you're done with a group,
you might wanna delete it in a sense.

88
00:04:53.340 --> 00:04:55.677
Like, you don't need all that,

89
00:04:55.677 --> 00:05:01.700
because it does take up room on whatever
you're storage is within your big stuff.

90
00:05:01.700 --> 00:05:02.619
Wow, okay.

91
00:05:02.619 --> 00:05:06.180
[LAUGH] But I don't need a tech guy
to be able to create it for me.

92
00:05:06.180 --> 00:05:07.610
So yeah, you're exactly right.

93
00:05:07.610 --> 00:05:09.556
I think that's what they did there.

94
00:05:09.556 --> 00:05:13.010
[LAUGH] So you can see that it's
giving you some information about it.

95
00:05:13.010 --> 00:05:18.300
Now, there are some other products out
there in the Office 365 environment.

96
00:05:18.300 --> 00:05:19.529
There's things called teams.

97
00:05:19.529 --> 00:05:22.297
There's also something called Yammer, so

98
00:05:22.297 --> 00:05:26.800
there's other services that Office
365 does allow people to have.

99
00:05:28.080 --> 00:05:32.460
Depending on whatever level
of Office 365 subscription or

100
00:05:32.460 --> 00:05:34.320
plan your organization has.

101
00:05:34.320 --> 00:05:35.380
You might not have some of it.

102
00:05:35.380 --> 00:05:38.488
But they're all very much
the same flavor in a sense.

103
00:05:38.488 --> 00:05:40.250
It's all about collaborating.

104
00:05:40.250 --> 00:05:44.718
Yammer is like your own
personal Facebook thing.

105
00:05:44.718 --> 00:05:48.940
Teams, it's funny there's an article,
if you search for

106
00:05:48.940 --> 00:05:50.790
what is the difference between teams and
groups.

107
00:05:50.790 --> 00:05:55.270
There's a very interesting article
that they talk about the differences.

108
00:05:55.270 --> 00:05:57.200
And it's like, well, wait,
are there differences?

109
00:05:57.200 --> 00:05:59.760
And groups are part of teams but
teams are an extension and

110
00:05:59.760 --> 00:06:03.191
it goes a little crazier and wait, so
I don't understand what's going on.

111
00:06:03.191 --> 00:06:05.120
That's okay,
let's just stick with groups okay?

112
00:06:05.120 --> 00:06:08.550
[LAUGH] But
I'm not saying that teams are bad.

113
00:06:08.550 --> 00:06:10.880
I think they're very nice,
it's just an extension.

114
00:06:10.880 --> 00:06:13.400
I think they're kind of using
a little bit of the same

115
00:06:13.400 --> 00:06:17.080
terminology that might get people
a little bit more confused.

116
00:06:17.080 --> 00:06:20.020
So we're gonna stick with groups, but
I just at least wanted to mention

117
00:06:20.020 --> 00:06:24.930
that there are teams out there
in the Office 365 world.

118
00:06:24.930 --> 00:06:28.033
Back down into this website, you can see
that, what do I need to have groups?

119
00:06:28.033 --> 00:06:33.042
You need to have a subscription
that has an Exchange outline, and

120
00:06:33.042 --> 00:06:38.520
SharePoint outline, so that's,
I said outline, that says online.

121
00:06:38.520 --> 00:06:42.414
[LAUGH] Wow, my brain was actually
kind of catching myself there.

122
00:06:42.414 --> 00:06:43.427
What?

123
00:06:43.427 --> 00:06:47.610
[LAUGH] And whether or
not it's a public versus a private group.

124
00:06:47.610 --> 00:06:51.490
And how do you manage your groups and
so this is some really good guides for

125
00:06:51.490 --> 00:06:53.982
you to go through, and
check everything out.

126
00:06:53.982 --> 00:06:56.474
Now, how do I create a group in Outlook?

127
00:06:56.474 --> 00:07:02.263
Because I already have one made in
our Office Pro demo co that has,

128
00:07:02.263 --> 00:07:06.800
you guessed it, JT, Lance and
Joey all part of it.

129
00:07:06.800 --> 00:07:10.601
So I can at least show you what
a already created group does, but

130
00:07:10.601 --> 00:07:15.435
to create a group it really just,
you click the new button in Outlook 2016.

131
00:07:15.435 --> 00:07:18.472
It shows you right there on the Home tab,
you can create new group.

132
00:07:18.472 --> 00:07:21.440
I know these are really small but
I'll come to it in just a second.

133
00:07:21.440 --> 00:07:26.286
You go ahead and give it a name and
that becomes your whatever the name is,

134
00:07:26.286 --> 00:07:30.186
at, then your domain .com,
gov, or whatever you have.

135
00:07:30.186 --> 00:07:32.005
I don't know if you'd be
able to do that on .gov.

136
00:07:32.005 --> 00:07:35.330
[LAUGH] We'll leave that up to them.

137
00:07:35.330 --> 00:07:37.430
And then you can then add members.

138
00:07:37.430 --> 00:07:40.943
Add members to your group,
you can also control whether or

139
00:07:40.943 --> 00:07:45.188
not they see the subscription because
you are subscribing to a group.

140
00:07:45.188 --> 00:07:49.330
And it's just like if you like a Facebook
page or you become some type of online

141
00:07:49.330 --> 00:07:52.774
group to where you start getting
those notifications that hey,

142
00:07:52.774 --> 00:07:54.770
you're part of this group.

143
00:07:54.770 --> 00:07:56.953
You're gonna see that in your news feed.

144
00:07:56.953 --> 00:08:01.815
So you can have it controlled to where
you'll see your conversations come through

145
00:08:01.815 --> 00:08:06.126
your inbox So that way you don't have
to go to your group specific email.

146
00:08:06.126 --> 00:08:08.900
So it just kinda comes through,
so it's almost like an alert.

147
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:11.640
>> When you add the members to the group,
when you create them, Vonne,

148
00:08:11.640 --> 00:08:14.200
does that give them access to
the resources within the group?

149
00:08:14.200 --> 00:08:16.700
Rather than having to say, hey,
okay, I've got this one person, and

150
00:08:16.700 --> 00:08:19.150
I'll manually assign them
the access to every resource.

151
00:08:19.150 --> 00:08:21.020
That seems like it would
be a little problematic.

152
00:08:21.020 --> 00:08:22.240
>> That's the cool part about it.

153
00:08:22.240 --> 00:08:23.460
This is all automatic.

154
00:08:23.460 --> 00:08:27.505
You just say, I want a new group,
this is the name, here are the people and

155
00:08:27.505 --> 00:08:31.958
then poof, all the resources are added for
you, so it's pretty, pretty cool.

156
00:08:31.958 --> 00:08:34.667
And then, of course,
I do have a web page for

157
00:08:34.667 --> 00:08:38.830
deleting a group just to let you
know cuz it does talk about.

158
00:08:38.830 --> 00:08:40.295
It says system resources, so

159
00:08:40.295 --> 00:08:44.058
there is that thing that you were talking
about with your techie talk about.

160
00:08:44.058 --> 00:08:44.918
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so

161
00:08:44.918 --> 00:08:48.750
[LAUGH] they do allocate specific
amount of resources within your system.

162
00:08:50.270 --> 00:08:53.360
Let's come down over into Joey's Outlook.

163
00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:58.082
In his inbox, there's actually some,
in his regular inbox,

164
00:08:58.082 --> 00:09:02.550
that are associated with
a particular group that he's in.

165
00:09:02.550 --> 00:09:07.315
So, it says that Joey Fatone, you have
been added to the Reunion_tour group.

166
00:09:07.315 --> 00:09:08.806
[LAUGH] And it says that, hey,

167
00:09:08.806 --> 00:09:12.995
just getting started with it you're gonna
have some conversations, some files.

168
00:09:12.995 --> 00:09:15.790
All those different things that we
said that come along with a group.

169
00:09:15.790 --> 00:09:21.699
So this is his welcome email that
came into his inbox because Joey,

170
00:09:21.699 --> 00:09:25.190
I believe Joey was the creator of this.

171
00:09:25.190 --> 00:09:28.590
And he made this, and
he checked the box on that said, yes,

172
00:09:28.590 --> 00:09:32.410
make sure all of our conversations
do go into each other's inbox.

173
00:09:33.550 --> 00:09:36.970
If I come over here to this side,
folder pane,

174
00:09:36.970 --> 00:09:39.797
notice there is a section for groups.

175
00:09:39.797 --> 00:09:43.850
You expand that out, there is that
IT TierOne that he is also a part of.

176
00:09:43.850 --> 00:09:47.870
This is when Ronnie was teaching
his Office 365 Admin episode.

177
00:09:47.870 --> 00:09:50.720
He was demonstrating
that on the back end and

178
00:09:50.720 --> 00:09:54.690
then this is where Joey is a member of
that, and here is the Reunion Tour.

179
00:09:54.690 --> 00:10:00.510
These are some different items
within this particular inbox,

180
00:10:00.510 --> 00:10:03.620
so it is reunion_tour@officeprodemoco.com.

181
00:10:03.620 --> 00:10:05.480
They have some conversations.

182
00:10:05.480 --> 00:10:08.920
And look at how it's not
like an email thread.

183
00:10:08.920 --> 00:10:11.870
It's like a conversation you
have almost like a text message

184
00:10:11.870 --> 00:10:13.160
where you can see everybody.

185
00:10:13.160 --> 00:10:14.790
And it says, hey guys, what's going on?

186
00:10:14.790 --> 00:10:18.094
You can like different
parts of that conversation.

187
00:10:18.094 --> 00:10:20.868
And then that gets sent back and forth, so

188
00:10:20.868 --> 00:10:25.560
it's very much a chat within Outlook
when you create a conversation.

189
00:10:25.560 --> 00:10:29.321
Also notice the tab across
the top in our ribbon,

190
00:10:29.321 --> 00:10:34.183
the Home tab of our group,
Conversation, Calendar, Files,

191
00:10:34.183 --> 00:10:38.772
Notebook, all of those online
